It's like Kerbal Space Program but for terrestrial vehicles and machines. In KSP the 'goal' is to do space exploration. In Stormworks, the goal is to perform search and rescue missions (for the most part). The visuals are a mix of Windwaker and Minecraft that ends up being more charming than I initially thought it would. I am not a huge fan of the block based construction, it means some geometrical concessions need to be made if a curved shape is desired - leading to things not looking as pretty as they would if there were curves in the toolbox. That being said, this isn't meant to be a Solidworks game, so it's a necessary simplification. Your mechanical imagination can really run wild - if the idea of designing and building the structure and mechanical components of anything you want appeals to you, you'll love this game.

This 1.0 update has basically destroyed all the great things this game had to offer. I can not recommend buying this game, especially not at an increased price!

They removed key components that allowed for rich progression in career mode. New island generation turns a big wide open procedural and explorable world into a 100km x 125km mostly predefined box. Also removed a brilliant dynamic mission editor and spawner.

**Update**
Old Career mode with research and tech tree has been added back into the game. And a new 'test' button has been added to the new lua heavy mission spawner which allows you to forcibly spawn in a single mission without having to use a lua code. These are good steps but the game still has a lot of problems. The old mission editor and spawner was much better, it even allowed you to pick from vanilla missions to play which this new editor can not. You should't have to learn a programming language to access content that was already in the game. Also all the old missions from before the version 1 update were removed, they were super fun and less hardcore. The new first person body system is a great idea but trying to swim with the new physics of this body is a pain, you are constantly below the surface of the water and it is hard to see where you are going. The island generation is still very much predefined and islands stop spawning after a certain distance, unlike the pre-v1 version of the game.
Great game, still needs some fixing but other wise its a great game :)

To be honest, I was kind of interested in this game because of the build it yourself model, but what put me over the top was while reading the reviews I saw that the developers responded so positively to all the feedback they received over its 1.0 roll out. Over all while the learning curve has been high for me personally, the videos online are a huge help and there is a natural progression of learning with the classic career mode. If your into games where your creativeness is set free and you like rescuing people , then I recommend this game.  I have been playing for 33 hours so far and feel I have more than received my moneys worth. Good Job Devs!

Bought on 1.0 release, if you like Space Engineers, Brick Rigs or other [b]building games[/b] but would like more reasonable/realistic creations with [b]complexity[/b] this is totally for you. Small block sizes allow for good detailing, [b]logic/microcontroller and scripting[/b] allow for useful and cool but sometime essential features.
The learning curve is steep but the workshop has ready to go creations to play with (in career/survival mode) and go [b]rescue NPCs, extinguish fires or do logistics per boat, train or aircraft[/b].

UPDATE, September 30, 2020:
Given how quickly and openly the developers have been about handling these issues, I've decided that this game is back on my Recommended list. There's positive changes afoot, and I'd hate for people to miss out on them.

UPDATE, September 26, 2020:
Well I sure didn't expect to have to amend this review after only 8 days, but here we are!

And what do you know, the developers are listening, and making adjustments accordingly.

Key Points: Classic Career Mode and the research tree are back! Hooray! I have a game mode that gives me the sense of progression I made such a big deal about in the first iteration of this review. This makes me happy, as this, I believe, was the biggest issue that stuck out. As of now, there are people reporting that automatic mission spawning in Classic Career mode, which I did notice as well. I'm hoping this will be sorted out in a patch or two.

Custom Mission Spawning Without Coding is......sort of back. Per the dev's patch notes, they added a "Test Location" button, which immediately spawns you into the custom mission scenario. This is alright, but there still isn't a convenient list of scenarios and missions you can readily choose from, and immediately set as active, as there was before. There's just a list that allows you to dictate which missions are in the rotation when you create a new game.

I will maintain that going into the Map screen, clicking a "Missions" button, and being able to view active missions right there, see their time limits right there, and choose specifically what mission, including a custom one, that you wanna load up, was far far more convenient than the Lua route.

Bugfixes and Improving Hose Mechanics, always nice, not much more to say.

I really hope this positive trend continues, and that these concerns continue to be addressed. I'm in a much more positive mindset about the game now, because of the developers showing a desire to listen to concerns, and having a vested interest in keeping players happy. Just keep it up, guys! You're on the right track!


ORIGINAL REVIEW, September 18, 2020 (Not Recommended):
I speak as a person who has sunk hundreds and hundreds and hundreds of hours into this game. Literally 2 days ago, this was a game I would've recommended to anyone who loved adventure or open world or sandbox or exploration games. This game had crazy amounts of depth, a sense of progression, an ability to basically create and destroy and explore to your heart's content. Half the fun I had was putting together custom mission scenarios for multiplayer quests. I could lose myself in this game's randomly generated world.

But then Update 1.0 happened.

Now granted, the update had some really cool things, spreadable dynamic fire, a new toolbar for player items, and hoses. But those new features apparently came at a price, and that price was the removal of tech trees and researching new parts, a severe dumbing down of the game's difficulty to where everything feels incredibly linear and career mode basically serves no purpose, but at the same time turning the normal career mode into a one life hardcore mode.

But worst of all, was the ditching of the mission spawner system. You used to be able to create your own custom missions from a menu that was easily accessible from the map screen, which was incredibly convenient, incredibly simple to use, and more importantly, fun. That doesn't exist now, replaced by a requirement to learn the Lua programming language in order to do custom anything anymore.


They got rid of just about every reason I liked the game, and bought the game, in the first place. No sense of progression, no sense of freedom to do what you wish at any time, no randomly generated maps to discover by seed of your own wit, no easy to access custom scenario system, all of it's gone. It doesn't even feel or play like the game I purchased anymore. Hopefully one day, I can rescind this review when the game becomes a challenge again, but right now, it's just a disappointment.
developer_response:
Dear Stormworkers,

Thank you for this review and all feedback received. We have reacted to much of the players feedback we have received. We have re-added the classic career mode with research tree and also mission spawning UI buttons:

On 17th Sept, we released version 1.0.

On 20th Sept, we re-added "Classic Career" mode back in, with research trees, map fog, player icons, and other settings familiar to the classic career.

On 21st Sept, we added new mission spawning UI without any scripting required. Players can simply load their mission in the mission editor, and click "Test Location". This will spawn that location and all contained vehicles immediately into game.

Thank you to all players providing feedback! Keep it coming.

Much love <3,

The Stormworks Developers

This is a qualified "thumbs down", because it seems that if you're prepared to dedicate a *lot* of time to this game, you'll be well rewarded. Unfortunately, it's an incredibly unwelcoming and buggy experience for a new player, that's led to me giving up on it after a few hours. 

The tutorial is pretty bad - I had to have 3 attempts to get through it as it kept bugging out in one way or another. It also doesn't teach you anything about building a boat - you have to go to YouTube for that. 

Then getting into the game proper, I failed the first rescue because I spent too long building a boat, and then no other missions spawned. I've no idea why.

So it still all feels very early-access and unfinished. I might come back after a few more updates and change my review if it feels like it's come together a bit more - I really do want to like it, but I just can't recommend it in its current state.

I am mostly just building/improving on mu starter boat in hopes the issues can be fixed soon and I can play the game. The devs are responsive, but it seems they have too small a team to fix these issues, not to mention the stress and potential burnout they must be facing. This game has one of the most intricate, complex and fascinating building systems I've seen.  The editor is great, and the amount of functions that you can add to vehicles are overwhelming.  By far, the best builder I've seen on Steam.

[b]Then, when your masterpiece is done, you have a bunch of repetitive tasks to do and realize what you just built is only useful for getting you from point A to point B to perform said mundane tasks...[/b]  That's why I wouldn't recommend this game to you, unless you're obsessive in your compulsion to create something that will ultimately never amount to much, or are a workshop content creator striving to get more "likes" on the thing you've put together.

I won't stop here, because there are a few things that I can think of that would make this game much better - namely, more vanilla variety of missions, actual AI so the game doesn't feel like a completely lifeless spawn-here-spawn-there mess, and maybe an economy beyond just paying for parts you need to have a marginally functional vehicle - there is little that you can do besides "rescues" and putting out fires, etc. that doesn't get repetitive over time.

I'll put more time into it and see if things change, updates make it better, etc. and will update my review according to the progress I see - what I'm looking at now, is a supposedly [i]full release[/i] game that has fallen far short of the potential I thought it had over the months I was considering buying it.  They released it too early, made players mad by stripping features (and suddenly putting SOME back in as response to negative feedback; well done I guess?) and ultimately - it still feels like one of those early access games that has about five more steps to go before it's the dream come true it should be.

There are definitely worse games out there, and this is in general not a "bad" game because it's strengths somewhat balance out it's weaknesses, but the bottom line is more should have been done for this game before it released, and more is still going to have to be done to this game before it's worth the advertised price.

If you want it?  I suggest you wait for a sale.  If you don't think mastering an ultra-complex building system is for you?  There are many 'building' games out there that give you quite a bit more action, and you won't have to worry about them falling short after experiencing the sheer complexity of this one's vehicle editor.

I love and hate this game. I love it because of the building mechanics and the craft and systems you can create in game. I hate it because of the bug ridden world the game is set in and the poorly thought out features and/or implementations.

After almost 300 hours, I've finally created some vehicles I'm actually proud of. Few games can invoke in me authentic feelings of pride, so huge props to Stormworks for that. After all the time it takes creating a structure, filling it with it's required mechanical parts, creating the logic and connecting the systems together, it can be really rewarding to see your creations come to life and operate how you envisioned.

But there's a few problems that are really holding the game back.

Some of the ideas and features in game are good on paper, but the implementation is horrible. A good example is the weather system, which comes complete with wind. I love the idea of wind being a force to be contended with. But the wind in Stormworks is frequently strong enough to blow your craft away from you, making it sometimes impossible to simply get out of your vehicle to do a rescue mission. Even heavy craft with locked landing gear can be blown away. I've also had a few times where I've flown a helicopter full speed into a head wind without being able to gain any ground (and in fact being pushed backwards), making it impossible to reach my destination until the wind dies down or changes direction.

The world that exists in Stormworks is completely devoid of life, with the exception of a few doctors around hospital buildings. The only other people in Stormworks exist only when they are spawned in as part of a mission (people to be rescued). The only other boats, cars or planes you will see are also part of these missions. There are no random NPCs cruising around the oceans, roads or skies, helping to make the world feel alive.

Really inconvenient bugs exist that just confuse me. For instance, you can't swim with a hose in your hand. Pretty big problem for boats that need to be fueled up. Your boats spawn in the water, you have to swim to them to get to them. Your fuel is stored on land. You can't swim with a fuel hose in hand (the hose keeps pulling you back towards whatever it's connected to). So something as simple as putting gas in the gas tank can become an enormous problem and headache.

Character movement is a huge pain. Getting hung up on little lips and edges of structures is common and I'm always having to jump to get over a non-perfectly flat surface. Water tosses your character around like a leaf, making trying to grab a ladder lots of fun when your  swimming in high waves. And clipping through walls sometimes happens, especially when getting out of a pilot seat (instant unintentional vehicle ejection). 

Missions that include putting out a vehicle fire often don't spawn the vehicle, just the fire. So you have to put out a floating ball of fire.

Players sometimes teleports 50 feet in the air when spawning a vehicle, leaving you to free fall back to the ground and take injury. I'm sure dying to this when playing hardcore (save deleted on death) would be a slice.

The 'video tutorials' provided in game open up an external link to youtube, to MrNJersey's page with 4 videos. He does a great job with his tutorials, but as far as I can tell he's not part of the development team. There is no in game tutorial to explain the very in depth systems that are available.

Lighting in dark conditions is comically bad. The hand held flashlight can cast more illumination than the high powered, vehicle mounted spot light, but even it sucks. Facilities like hospitals have next to no exterior illumination. I've been 80m above a hospital in a helicopter at night, and it's pitch black. Literally no indication that a building is there. As an extension of the under powered lighting, night time in this game is a joke. The newly released night vision binoculars help, but the zoom makes them only useful at long ranges. Easy fix would be to add night vision goggles. Or make light sources stronger. Or make ambient light brighter. But nope, stupidly dark conditions is what we have.

It's frustrating. This could be a fantastic game, but it's not. It's almost like if they had 5 employees, 4 were working really hard to make this game great, but 1 was a corporate spy set on sabotaging the game.

If you like building machines and are very patient with development, I am comfortable recommending this game to you. Don't let the 1.0 fool you, it's still very much incomplete and under development. To anyone else looking for a good game, I suggest you look elsewhere.

OLD REVIEW BEFORE THEY MESSED UP THE GAME>
A legendary game that is still under heavy development. It has huge potential. What would happen if Tony Stark was the director of thunderbirds international rescue?

This is not so much a rescue game as a build vehicles game. As usual a vehicle in Stormworks is made up of little blocks and mechanical parts. Except there also needs to be logic connections added in too to make it work. Linking up buttons, engines, dials, throttle control, etc. The list goes on. 

There is even a chance to create complete integrated logic circuits to do calculations or advanced logic functions. If you have no idea of what a PID controller is. Your are about to learn a thing or two. There is even an opportunity to get involved in computer scripting using the Lua programming language. Which give your designs even more advanced features.

At first it looks like you need an engineering degree, but it’s surprisingly simple once the steps are broken down. However mastery takes practice.

Once build you can take the new vehicle out into Stormworks violent weather and attempt rescue missions. The game has a very easy to use inbuilt mission editor. So there will lots of missions on the workshop to add to those already in game. A series of missions forms a campaign. 

With survival mechanics included often a player themselves will need rescued when things wrong. Giving multiplayer opportunity. For multiplayer the in game radio system is amazing. You need to set up a radio transmitter and receiver to talk to the team when separated. That being said the game works perfectly as a single player game.

There also a chance to build new bases in game. These can be introduced as you discover locations in the campaign. Or you could just build bases and have them permanently appear as part of the world. With a workshop to share creations there is plenty to download too.

The catch is of course early access... beware. It is very early and there is going to be issues ahead. This one is going to take time given the complexity of the choices being provided. In game physics are 95% of the way there but can fail sometimes. The good news it there does seem to be a decent attempt build a feedback system to help narrow down technical issues. At some point the developer will have stop adding content to concentrate on smoothing out the whole game. However it is designed from ground up to have endless workshop content.

Thumbs up with early access reservations.

After more than 100 hours of playing time, I now want to write my opinion about the game.

In my opinion Stormworks is a game for everyone who likes to build vehicles, drive vehicles and who likes to plan design and mechanics, like connecting engines and propellers (pretty simple example).

Positive things:
[list]
[*]adavanced editor
[*]many blocks and other components
[*]Extensively developed, easy to use logic system, with which you can create user-defined processes to have control over your 
speed, direction etc.
[*]Integrated editor for microcontrollers
[*]Microcontrollers can process inputs and output them again
[*]for advanced users, there are lua scripts in the microcontrollers. With the scripts you can create interactive maps for example
[*]I have to disappoint people with RTX graphic demands. Stormworks is a low poly game. But if you ask me, I think that the low poly graphics fits to the game. It is a game about vehicles and their mechanics and not about the most beautiful vehicles with 		hyper graphics.
[*]Through constantly changing weather (which you can also adjust manually), you can test your vehicles on e.g. tsunamis and strong winds. Furthermore the weather fits very well to the atmosphere.
[*]Stormworks has with Minecraft and Subnautica one of the best soundtracks which varies a lot with bells and gives a sea feeling.
[*]The map on which you play depends on the seed you enter and represents the ocean with several islands. On this map you can play pre-defined missions, most of which involve rescues or transports. Additionally there is a mission editor and a lot of 			different great missions in the Steam Workshop.
[*]The multiplayer of Stormworks is relatively acceptable, but there are some things to improve.
[*]Storworks offers a wide range of vehicles that can be built, such as aircraft, ships, landvehicles and even "buildings". Stormworks’ focus however is on boats.
[*]With the 1.0 update, many new and long awaited items have been added, such as fire extinguishers
[*]At the beginning the editor is a bit confusing, but with time you learn new things until you get the full potential out of Stormworks.





Negative things and proposals:

[*]When it comes to performance, Stormworks is simply a joke: If you've spawned several vehicles, for example, the game starts to lag a lot. Although there is a despawning for distant vehicles, Stormworks could make some improvements (One game that does this quite well is Satisfactory (which I know from my own experience)).
[*]The multiplayer could be given some additional features, like a multiplayer editor (I know that the devs have other things to do, but I would really appreciate this feature).
[*]I would also suggest a support for custom blocks (Windows are just pain in Stormworks, when you want them to fit)
[*]In the LUA scripts there is already a simple instruction for the Stormworks API, but you could provide an API documentation.


Conclusion:

[*]Stormworks is a well made game with a focus on building, testing and scenario playing and is for everyone with creativity, fun at building and a little patience.

Therefore Stormworks gets a very good rating.
[/list]

Building your first boat and putting it to the test against waves, storms, and even tsunamis, just to barely make it back to the dock for further adaptions, will have you swearing like a sailor in no time.

Stormworks is a decent game if you enjoy building vehicles of all kinds, alongside the various systems like electricity, propulsion and all kinds of mechanical as well as logical gadgets and other contraptions.

Classic career mode has been added again, after players disapproved of its removal in 1.0.
It offers the earning of funds and research points, which can be invested in bigger vehicles and more advanced technology to help you get your fleet started.
A custom gamemode allows for testing of various systems without the restrictions of career.

Editors are an essential part in these type of games. Stormworks editor can be learned quickly, offers a search bar, mirror modes on 3 axes and a selection tool helps to copy and paste bigger selections or entire vehicles.

The Logic system is very expansive, from simple logic gates to fully fleshed out LUA controllers or displays, which can be interacted with via in game touchscreen monitors should keep you busy for a long time.

Stormworks features a huge map, all islands are inside a circle with a radius of ~100km, all available from start on. You can buy islands if you got the spare change, to allow building of different vehicles and even outposts.

The mission system has been reworked, they are now randomized across the entire map and of more varying types. Simple passenger transportation, sea rescues or fire missions can appear throughout mission runtime, distances can vary and you will be hard pressed to make it in time.
Players can also freely engage in cargo transportation, which requires a wide range of vehicles to complete.
Fluid trading might be less daunting for inexperienced players and allows you to buy crude oil from oil rigs.
Refineries will purchase the crude oil for a decent profit off you and allow you to buy other fluid types like diesel and jet fuel, which in turn can again be sold at the airport or fishing village.

Mission success depends on proper vehicle choice, equipment, arrival in time and on environmental factors outside your control. Storms can cause high waves which will force you to sail around them if your boat is likely to capsize. With a submarine at your disposal you could dive just through it.
With 1.0 these storms got even stronger, it's now possible to park your vehicles inside hangars, where wind won't blow them off into the sea.

Currently there are some issues with this game, the developers are pushing out updates multiple times in the week post 1.0 release and are responding to player feedback.
For some reason info about stuff in game is hard to come by, engines offer a power rating, with no explanation how or what that number is supposed to mean, while other devices like monitors, lights or heaters don't offer any info about their power consumption.

I'd consider myself as an avid first person player, this game offers plenty of tools to play exclusively in first person, cameras can give you a better sense of your surroundings, while other systems like radar and sonar act as enhancements to your good old Eyeball MkI.

As of now I can recommend this game, with modular engines on the horizon and already plenty of stuff to do, going through the range of vehicles possible in this game you'll be busy for quite a while.
There's also a Multiplayer I barely got into, as well as an entire LUA based mission making framework, which hopefully will get some documentation soon.

I hope this review was of use to you, at the time of writing I have accumulated around 1.500h in Stormworks and am still enjoying it.

I used to really love this game. The 1.0 updated added quite a few cool things like the first person equipment and the changes to ropes. But, the game has been changed in ways that make it so it just isn't all that fun anymore. They buffed the wind in the game, but did nothing to account for how vehicles are supposed to handle it. If you want to keep your vehicle from being tossed around like a piece of paper in a hurricane at higher winds, you have to put a magall on it to anchor it. I've had boats, cars, and aircraft all get pushed around like they weighed nothing by wind so often the game is virtually unplayable. I used to use aircraft almost exclusively, as a helicopter is far more versatile than a boat. But with the new changes, using aircraft almost feels impossible in anything but 0 wind scenarios, as none of the engines are strong enough to counter the winds, and most craft will just be tossed around like it's made of paper. Sure, in real life, there are times when aircraft have to be grounded because of sever weather, but this is beyond that. The extreme winds have, in my experience playing 1.0, persisted throughout almost the entirety of my playtime in this version making aircraft unusable. Wind was fine the way it was before. Hell, I would be fine with having winds this strong in the game, as long as it wasn't nearly constant like it is now. I remember before 1.0 the winds got strong enough during storms flying was very difficult and dangerous, but possible. Lightning could strike the aircraft during storms disabling it too, making it a risk vs. reward type deal. Now, it's just not even an option unless you use some vehicle with a ton of jet engines, maybe not even then. As for boats and cars, the same problem applies there too, and I have found myself practically unable to even play the game without overriding the wind, as vehicles become completely uncontrollable or are just outright pushed around in the wind like they're skating on lube, or in the case of boats, have a very difficult time turning and almost cannot even move against the wind at all.

Maybe it's just something with the RNG on my old computer. Maybe it's the vehicles I was using are too light. Idk, but I quite miss being able to actually fly aircraft and play the game. I hope the devs reduce the frequency of extreme winds. I don't like the feeling of being in a hurricane 24/7.

This game is very fun, but unfortunately it has major issues that make it impossible to enjoy the game. The more ambitious your creations are, the worse the performance of the game is. No matter how high end your computer specifications are, the game will slow and break down. If you have the desire to attempt a multiplayer match, you might as well forget about it. Multiplayer used to be fine a year ago, but now is just a painful slow motion simulation, from taking minutes to log in, to the constant ping increases and sluggish gameplay. Even in singleplayer, the experience is subpar at best, which is really strange since this game doesn't have the most overkill graphics or requirements.

Regardless, until the performance issues are resolved, I can't recommend this game to anyone, which is unfortunate since when the game runs fine, it's really fun to play and come up with crazy contraptions.

3/12/2020: There was a lot of optimism regarding "The Multiplayer" update, and while I want to say it helped, there weren't any noticeable improvements. The game crashes frequently for any person joining a hosted game, and there is still a lot of lag even for non-complex vehicles. Also, for whatever reason, there is no dedicated Linux server, so for my case, I can't host a dedicated server until that's resolved. Seeing as the game is cross platform, I can't imagine it would take a lot of extra work on the developers' part to make a dedicated server function on Linux, but to my knowledge, there's still no support. I stand by my original review.

9/24/2020: With the recent "Version 1.0 Update", a couple new nifty features were added. While withholding a bunch of minor feature releases for a hyped "one-point-oh" update is a bit questionable, I will admit that the new features are quite neat, particularly the storm systems. While performance is still quite questionable, and server synchronization feels like it's running at 7 TPS, outside of multiplayer (and continued lack of Linux support) the game has improved a lot since last year, and I'm quite content with its current state. Props to the developers for their accomplishments and unique gameplay.

Very fun game with an active and responsive team of developers. The 1.0 update caused some controversy but it honestly speaks more to the cohesion of the community and the devs willingness to listen. Only a few days after the large update and they have already fixed many of the bugs caused by it and reversed some of the changes that the community had issue with. 

The Career mode in this game is fun but lacking a little depth in my opinion. It can feel a little repetitive doing the same missions over and over again just to gain money (and research points if you choose). However this is changing as more missions and different ways to accomplish them are brought into the game. Despite feeling shallow at times I still enjoy my career save. 

The Creative mode (or just building in general) is where this game thrives. There are few games that are comparable to Stormworks in scope when it comes to designing and building various creations. In this game you can build boats, cars, planes, trains, helicopters, submarines, etc. unlike any other game I have played before. Creations can be very small and simple, or very large and complex, depending entirely on the creator. The easy interfacing of logic and lua programming into creations allows for much more depth and complexity than in other games. 

If you are looking for a game to spend 100s of hours developing and building some megaproject, 
or where you can build a few creations and then use them to complete missions in the game, 
or even download some vehicles off the workshop and then use them to RP as the Coast Guard,
then this is the game for you.

After update 1.0.1:
Cons:
Plagued by multiplayer crashes. Both Server and client side.

(Fixed in a new update)
Refinery island (the only place to buy fuel to refill your base tanks) is dead no buttons work.
Missions with fire are impossible to put out using fire equipment both using water cannons fire extinguishers and hoses. Only way to put them out is the run the boats over so the fire is under water for a long time. 

There are often missions where there are supposed to be boats on fire and the fire spawns, but the boats don't so you have fire midair or in the water. 

All wedges/pyramids larger than one block make your water going vehicles slower. (A lot slower)

Pros:

Potentially lots of fun multiplayer rescue missions and with the new dynamics different rescue situations.

Creative outlet building and engineering crazy designs and ideas.

Fun for those that can do programing in lua you have lots of possibilities just in making chip designs for doing stuff like autopilots, UI's for displays etc.

And it is refreshing to have a game where there are no weapons that are made by the developers (i know some people make them in game but that’s just shows what you can do with this game when it works)

So yes I recommend it even with its faults. and now that its released I really really hope the developers can concentrate more on bug fixing instead of new parts for a while.

1.0.10 The game is back to normal for the most part. It is time to revert my opinion to deserved recommendation. The game is in my opinion best vehicle building game on steam. The one thing that I have to mention. It still feels like Early Access. Developers still fix the bugs daily, and promise new features and consider potential major system reworks. If you expect this to be as polished as for example Factorio 1.0, you WILL be dissapointed.

Example: based on developer own annoucement on the game store page. 1.0 change that removed any new game customization outside Creative mode is fine, because you can download mod or write lua script to set your options to what you want. It was part of the UI before 1.0. I don't consider that finished, customer friendly version of the game. 

In short if you only buy released, finished product, consider it still in early access and not recommended. If you are OK with occasional crash, bug, and poorly balanced economy but want a cool vechicle building game. 100% recommended.

I can't not recommend this game. It's amazingly fun with open exploration, rescue, building and a community workshop.

However...

After version 1 dropped, the mission spawner was nerfed. This is a massive blow to many people as it was replaced by a requirement to learn the LUA programming language to insert any missions other than the main menu when you first create the game save. Many used it to spawn a mission that their specific vehicle could do. It was also useful in spawning vehicles that were too big for a hangar and it was incredibly simple to use. LUA is extremely vast and would take many months to learn it fully. I really hope the devs insert a way to spawn missions again without having to enter lines of code. I don't really use missions anymore as the ones that randomly generate are not at all suitable for the vehicle I created and I can't really test its limits.

That being said, this game is fun and I simply cannot recommend against it.

Stormworks is a great example of a game that listened to it's players, and developed nicely throughout early-access. 

It's so much fun to go out on the water, or fly in the skies- or even hop on the rails, and just explore. Then, you throw in the missions, and suddenly, everything feels exciting, tense, and important! I prefer to play the game like a sandbox game, as that's what I prefer, but it would be a sin to not bring up the existence of the missions.

However, this game has a lot of pros, but a few cons as well.


Pros: 
- Lots of content to go over
- 2 Separate difficulties, to get people used to the game
- Easy Workshop Content installation
- Nice Dynamic sinking/water simulation, for what the game is.
- A long list of other things, that I could go on and on about.

Cons:
- This game is VERY resource demanding. I find myself having to lower the resolution of the game, in order to not have physics lag. This is in part, due to my PC's limitations, but nonetheless.

- Multiplayer almost doubles the previously listed issue, and sometimes it's even WORSE.

- Lack of any type of real building tutorials, to help people get used to how the building works.

-----------------------


All these comments aside, I would most certainly recommend Stormworks to anyone with an appreciation for this genre, or even to those who just enjoy sandbox games.
it super good you can do anything and the updated keep getting better you can do mission go under water fly sail travil to the artic and there are tsunamis and megaledons. worth the money

I speak as a person who has sunk hundreds and hundreds and hundreds of hours into this game. Literally 2 days ago, this was a game I would've recommended to anyone who loved adventure or open world or sandbox or exploration game. This games had crazy amounts of depth, a sense of progression, an ability to basically create and destroy and explore to your heart's content. Half the fun I had was putting together custom mission scenarios for multiplayer quests. I could lose myself in this game's randomly generated world.

But then Update 1.0 happened.

Now granted, the update had some really cool things, spreadable dynamic fire, a new toolbar for player items, and hoses. But those new features apparently came at a price, and that price was the removal of tech trees and researching new parts, a severe dumbing down of the game's difficulty to where everything feels incredibly linear and career mode basically serves no purpose, but at the same time turning the normal career mode into a one life hardcore mode.

But worst of all, was the ditching of the mission spawner system. You used to be able to create your own custom missions from a menu that was easily accessible from the map screen, which was incredibly convenient, incredibly simple to use, and more importantly, fun. That doesn't exist now, replaced by a requirement to learn the Lua programming language in order to do custom anything anymore.


They got rid of just about every reason I liked the game, and bought the game, in the first place. No sense of progression, no sense of freedom to do what you wish at any time, no randomly generated maps to discover by seed of your own wit, no easy to access custom scenario system, all of it's gone. It doesn't even feel or play like the game I purchased anymore. Hopefully one day, I can rescind this review when the game becomes a challenge again, but right now, it's just a disappointment.

The development path of the Stormworks game is questionable.
From a very old version, there was minimap that was a fully automatic rotating forward up map with direction compass,
it was removed on some later version.
Control surface for aircraft used to be functioning correctly during early v0.7.x became broken that they only provide drag at higher speed but still far from sound barrier.
Bug reports were there but issue is never fixed or noted.

Critical decision error on v1.0:
Certain parts of the game now uses resource pointer hard-coded in executable (.exe).
For example: custom buzzer*
Custom buzzer is a very creative option for people which allow creation makers to choose any sounds file included with the game to be used in many situations like race start signal horn, car horn, siren or even sound effects for artificial guns or cannons.
Custom buzzers are all gone for now.
Other critical decision error is the game now require all mission makers to code mission script like a programmer.
Non-programmer or non-IT related people might not feel happy with this.

Minor flaws:
Several terms used in game are misleading.


I like the game but just cannot recommend it at this state.
Features got removed but bugs were added.

v1.0.10
Script console/chat box is now bugged
There is no error catching function for in-game lua script
Once error happens, the whole script stops or misbehaves until force a reload
Provided functions (mission script/server script) like server.getPlayerPos() sometimes gives error when target player keeps moving and changing motion/direction.

I highly recommend this title, in fact I cannot recommend it enough, sure it has bugs, but really there is so much to do, and the devs are constantly working on it to improve the experience. Want to cruise the ocean on your yacht? How about fly to distant land in your UH-60 Blackhawk with a side crane for recovering crash survivors? Neither of those got your eye? Feel free to customize your play-world and remove missions and just cruise around, or see how long you can survive sole adventures into the perilous Arctic sea, the possibilities are endless.

Give it a try, if you don't like it refund it, if you do like it, the community welcomes you to StormWorks!

Edit: A bit of an Update, so since they made changes to how Infinite Electric works, I was able to simply replace the engines with Electric Motors instead of my original Engines, and since they made it so Infinite Electric didn't apply to batteries, there was no need to hook anything up with batteries, and with the engines I replaced them with those Electric Motors to have the ship move again without Engines, so with all of these solutions and fixes I am now happy with where everything is with the game right now. Everything below is when I thought everything about the 1.0 Update made it so that my Titanic would not function.

I have put many hours into this game. At around 1,350 hours as of writing this. I enjoyed creating random builds and creating ships in the Sandbox Mode starting way back in December of 2018. This 1.0 Update has completely ruined that. For the past 5 Months, and over the course of 850+ hours, I have been working on one of the biggest projects I could imagine. I began building the entire Titanic. It has all of the exterior details, has quite a lot of Interior including the first 2 boiler rooms, many public spaces, a lot of 1st Class Corridors, a few Cabins, the Grand Staircase, the entire Engine Room (With working Reciprocating Engines btw), and tons of minor details that I spent so long doing research and looking at reference images and blueprints to recreate this. There are even Watertight doors that you could close, and that those Watertight doors were located in Boiler Rooms 5 and 6, and throughout the corridor of Scotland Road itself too. I have also spent many hours messing with mechanics to make it flood and sink accurately, to even have the ship split and everything as well. I have been a Titanic Enthusiast for the past decade. I thought I would have never thought of a project like this, but then starting those 5 months ago, that is when I got it. I wanted to completely revive the ship on this game, because I wanted to make it a once in a lifetime experience, to see what it felt to walk along different parts of the ship, and to feel that you were back in time in 1912 before that fateful night, and to commemorate those 1,500 people who died in one of the most terrifying and tragic ways possible. I absolutely adored this game but with this 1.0 Update it has ruined the Experience for me. I was looking forward to being able to successfully release my Titanic on the Workshop for others to use and be amazed at it for how realistic it was. And tons and tons of other people could agree that they were excited to see me release this gigantic project that I was approaching completion and wanted to attempt to release it for the big day of 1.0. But in this case, 1.0 has completely bricked the experience and bricked my project. With the introduction of the new Mission System, it has all been completely redone and it is confusing. And what I am most irritated about in this Update, is why was Basic Mode removed? My Titanic could only function on Basic Mode, and I see no reason as to remove it because of how necessary Basic Mode could be for newer players. I started building my Titanic on Basic Mode because I don't want to have to hook up each individual component with multiple batteries, then to hook up the 35 Large Diesel Engines that propel the ship with many different pipes and stuff to connect to the necessary components for an engine to work in Advanced Mode. It is just too much of a hassle and Basic Mode was the easiest way to counter this. I personally don't play Career Mode or anything, since for the past 5 Months I have only worked on this Titanic, putting in so many hours of building, testing, and hyping it up for a big release at some point, because I know lots and lots of people in different servers who were extraordinarily hyped to see my recreation of the R.M.S Titanic. I wanted to basically revive the ship itself in this game since it was possible. I am glad to still have the save files and everything, but there is no way for me to make this function and work without Basic Mode, and at the same time it is completely uncalled for to make it so it is almost a requirement to know LUA Coding to mess with Missions and such now. I am only able to somehow spawn it using the new Addon part where you select the Mission after having the ship placed in Environmental Mode, but since the game is only in Advanced Mode now, it will never work unless if I go through the trouble and the hassle of hooking everything up with batteries and pipes. I could imagine the same for literally almost every other creator who are into building large creations such as me. I did look forward to all the other new features but the only thing I could care for in this update anymore, is to please bring back Basic Mode and to possibly revert the mission editor, or somehow come up with a solution where you can have both types. There was no harm to have an option to either have Advanced or Basic Mode, and it was completely pointless to remove Basic Mode. If anyone reads this, please like it or give it attention because I really hope to have the devs to see this. Please help me be able to make my Titanic function again. I know all of you who were looking forward to it wanted to see this project done, but it has been completely halted until Basic Mode could potentially be brought back.

Stormwuuuuurks is a great sandbox game and its fun building and testing vehicles.

[EDIT] As of 1.0.5, the research and (classic) career is back into the game so my previous review/argument no longer stands and I am thumbing this up again. Stormworks is and has always been a really fun and fulfilling game if you are willing to look past the constant game-breaking bugs, and other minor yet extremely annoying issues. 

The development of Stormworks is like a double-edged sword. While the dev team appears extremely competent and quick deploying new features, hot-fixes and responding to community concerns/feedback, they also seem to allocate very little resources to polish or testing in general leading to a panicked vicious circle of bugs and fixes which was more often than not self-inflicted.

My two cents to the developers : now that you are out of early access, please slow down your schedule and take the time to polish & test your releases before setting them free - not every player will be willing to wait for a week or two for obvious, easily picked out and fundamental issues to be ironed out time and time again.

----
[EDIT - v1.0 Review]

Great game with lots of potential ruined with the latest update / v1.0 : the somewhat rough-around-the-edges research system which made career interesting & gave it a purpose and something to work towards was just removed in favour of a completely bland / unrewarding game mode with no progression whatsoever other than making money.

I cannot recommend Stormworks at this point in time - until they reinstate some form of progression/research system, this is a fun sandbox but not the game that was originally sold to me.

I changed this review back to positive again. The old "negative" review and the even older "positive review" can be found below. TL;DR Buy it. It's worth every penny. Dev's listened, a lot of good features have been restored.

 

Old negative review ------------------------ 

"EDIT: I changed this review from positive to negative. The old review can be found below. 

I will mention that this game is fantastic creativity and possibility wise. It's way better than space engineers and similar titles just due to the incredible complexity. 

So why did I change it to negative? Well the 1.0 launch release removed literally all the progression that can be done in the game. If you are happy enough with being creative, or like complex construction, go for it. If you need some sort of story, progression, research system, an endgame goal etc. you can forget it in it's current state. 

They removed the research system completely, and you start with all equipment unlocked. Currently career mode is the same as custom mode, with the difference that you don't have unlimited money. That's it.

Once we get some kind of proper progression system back in career mode, I will recommend this game again. I don't understand why they removed such an important mechanic, instead of giving players the ability to enable or disable a research/progression system in an options menu. "



Older positive review ------------------------ 

This game has near infinite ways of creating whatever the heck you want. Wanna build a realistic boat with cool and stupid features, like a crane, rainbow lightings or cameras, then sure go ahead. Or wanna build a train, but not just a train, but one you could maybe land helicopters or vtols on. And yeah you can build friggin jet vtols! They're like spaceships! And if you pc is beafy enough and you have the time you might even build a flying down made out of many individual pieces.  

I recommend learning the game in advance mode, since then you get the cool stuff like electricity and pipe systems/custom tanks. The learning curve is high, so check out many tutorial videos, but it will be worth it! 

Btw the water physics are pretty cool. Build an capsule with a door, go into that thing and jump into the ocean. No water will get into that capsule, but if you open the door water will slowly flow into the capsule.

Geez, this is a super ambitious game with an incredible dedicated community building amazing things. It feels close to being good, but in reality in its current state its a physics simulator and not a rescue simulator.  The single player experience survival is super bare bones and leaves the player alone after one relatively simple mission.  No effort has been put into crafting something coherent that takes the user on a learning journey with different kinds of vehicles in a variety of more challenging scenarios.  Advice to team, you should try to guide the player to learn the experience step up the challenge and complexity gradually.  The creative mode, drops you in deep and relies on your own experimentation to make it enjoyable.  The vehicle editor is for only the most dedicated of dedicated, prepared to spend dozens of hours in laborious effort.  The editor could allow a less 'atomic' approach to building, (Starting with a single cube is hella intimidating) providing, hulls, frames, and pre-packaged engines and such in the UI (rather than from the steam workshop) would be an easy add.    Overall it could be excellent, right now tough to and I really want to enjoy it.  (Said after crashing my downloaded helicopter for the 19th time trying to rescue people from some boat on fire).

Edit: With the developers re-adding an option for the research tree, I'm changing this review. The game is definitely fun, and I will continue to play it.

Actual review: this game is deceptively complicated, on the surface its a block based building game, under the hood its a complicated balance of dozens of factors each of which have a hood to open up and discover more factors. For me, a lot of the reward from this game comes from building something that works. Getting your first working engine, building your first flying machine, towing your first oil tanker, saving your first wounded fisherman, incredibly satisfying. I've not even done career mode yet, I'm just having fun making more new vehicles.

CONS: You need to be creative to like this game. Of course it's fun to sail through 3 meter waves in a thunderstorm, but you need to sink a lot of time into designing a vehicle to do it. If you don't have the patience for that, there's no game for you here. 
It's very easy to do things wrong and there's almost no indication when or what went wrong. Fuel pump on backwards? Air intake not linked properly? Radiators overloaded? That's is all on you to figure out. There are some methods you can use to problem solve but when I was first starting it was extremely frustrating to not know why my engine wouldn't turn over. You'll need tutorials for this game. Assistance isn't present when your engine blows up from overheating. Only you can prevent forest fires and only YouTube tutorials can prevent engine explosions. 
Multiplayer is more or less just showing off your vehicles to other players. Sure you can build a vehicle to be crewed by several people, but they cant help you build the vehicle. It would be nice if more than 1 person could be editing a vehicle so that way people could customized and optimize different parts of a ship. Maybe I know engines better than my friend and he knows how to use the radar scripting so he builds the bridge of the ship and I build the engine room.

it lets you have fun in your own way without restrictions.

A fantastic sandbox vehicle builder focused on search and rescue operations.

Simply put, the meat of this game is the vehicle building - the breadth and depth of what it allows you to do is unparalleled. Most of your time will be spent in the design phase, especially as you get to building larger and more complex vehicles. If that isn't your thing, this game probably isn't for you.

If tinkering is your thing, though, there's no substitute for this game.
ahh yesssssssssssssss haha very good +1 ok

Just about the only game I play anymore.

Steep learning curve, extremely high skill ceiling. Build anything from an engine that needs to be cranked every few seconds to keep from stalling to fully automated VTOLs and radar-guided missiles*.

The 1.0 release is going a bit shaky, but since the devs have addressed the community's concerns I'd say this is still worth buying, very much so. It still has tons of potential and the devs plan to keep updating it for the foreseeable future.

The very active and friendly community over on the SW discord and the new official video tutorials provided by MrNJersey should help you learn the basics, should you choose to buy the game and start playing.

*to not misrepresent the game, there aren't explosive components, the missiles just thump into things and break stuff.

Great game, decent Buoyancy simulation and good building tools. Missions are good too, flight dynamics could be better but its good enough. MP obv needs more work but its getting there. You can easily spend hours on this game just coming up with cool designs so its worth it for that alone. Alot of cool logic can be applied to your craft as well which really help you refine things exactly how youd want them to be and as simple as the game looks on the cover it can really get complicated with some of the parts like making your own moving map on a screen like a GPS system with LUA.
this games is so awesome i have no words

developer_response:
Dear Stormworkers,

Thank you for this review and all feedback received. We have reacted to much of the players feedback we have received. We have added mission spawning UI buttons:

On 17th Sept, we released version 1.0.

On 20th Sept, we re-added "Classic Career" mode back in, with research trees, map fog, player icons, and other settings familiar to the classic career.

On 21st Sept, we added new mission spawning UI without any scripting required. Players can simply load their mission in the mission editor, and click "Test Location". This will spawn that location and all contained vehicles immediately into game.

Thank you to all players providing feedback! Keep it coming.

Much love <3,

The Stormworks Developers

review: fun gamebbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbbb

I hesitated buying Stormworks for several years and instead played Kerbal Space Program. The two are roughly in the same game category of half-serious games with lots of optimization wackyness. I'm close to having spent more time in Stormworks than any other game.

So glad to have the Classic Career mode re-enabled.

Released from early access with raised price, removed gameplay incentives, drastic changes nobody asked for and added a tons of bugs and a tutorial any game designer would be ashamed of. It's apparent there has been no QA whatsoever.

Stay away for now.

This had so much potential for greatness, I sincerly hope they turn this ship around.
Right now, it's a bit buggy, but that's due to a big update. I'm hearing that the developers are working hard to fix the bugs, and regardless, i tihnk it's a great game!
it goooooooooooood game
If you're into building complicated vehicles and maybe accidentally kill some people with yu=our boat, this is the game for you.

The outstanding response from a clearly caring Dev team has prompted to me to change my review. There are still some bugs in the game however I believe the Devs are working hard to resolve any issues and the game - even with the bugs is a huge amount of fun. I would recommend it to support and Dev team that listens to the community and are set on making their game as fun as possible for all the players in the community. Fantastic job - thank you!

update 1.0 brought us an experimental branch, a weather system as well as procedural missions, but in doing so the devs thought it would be a good idea to take choice out of the game. you no longer can choose how your career mode goes, your locked into all the parts unlocked, no research/progression, and permadeath(from what i've heard). at this time i suggest people stay away from purchasing the game as at 25$ it is in inferior product to what it was at 20$. if it remains in it's current state, dont bother unless it's drops under 15.

update 9/21 - devs have listened to player feedback and have reinstated the old career mode with the tech tree. i still suggest waiting on a sale, if it's around 20$ as theres still other features that are missing that the rest of the community liked. i can now reccomend the game.

Gah...this game is rough. I really wanted to like it, bought it right before release and tried to play a little. Waited for release, they made major changes and it is basically impossible unless you have some sort of familiarity with the game. The initial tutorial barely scratches the surface, and after completing it, I got a mission and took my boat out. I get no navigation or indication for where my mission is (shows up on map, but not in the main screen), map does not show YOUR location, so I have spent 2 hours driving around in circles with literally no idea where I am. I have played Kerbal, Stationeers, Space Engineers, etc for 100s of hours, so I am not a novice to steep learning curves, but this game is unplayable. Forgot to mention the starter boat is constantly full of water (is that per design?) and the build function seems like I would need a doctorate in physics. Maybe I will check back in 6 months.

I have 255 hours in this game, and likely will put many more. However the Development team has greatly hurt the game with their latest update jumping from version (I believe it was 0.1) all the way to 1.0. With this massive jump I assumed that there would be an absolutely monstrous list of bug fixes, and stability updates. While there were many of those it wasnt as much as I had hope for, for a jump this big. The development team took several features out that have heavily impacted many players. I play the game solely for playing with mods made from the community, as Im not the greatest builder ever, and even I have been impacted by this update. The part of the update Im talking about specifically is the mission update. Before this update someone could download a mod from the workshop that was too big for the spawn radius, and you could put it into a custom mission you make, and spawn it where you want, bypassing the workbenches spawn radius. They have removed this ability, and have (to my current knowledge) no other way to spawn ships/places/helis/etc that are too big for the workbench spawns. This has made several ships that I love to use often un-usable for me. Now for anyone who wants to play like me, and just do creative, and play with mods then it is still very do-able, you just cant get some of the larger ships and vehicles. Now if your going to play this as a career mode player(starting from nothing, and earning money to make bigger ships via completing missions) then you will be heavily impacted from the removal of the research tree. The research tree was what you would go to, to research new parts as you (level up? I wasnt much of a career mode palyer) progress, such as larger propellers for larger ship building, larger engines, etc. Right now this game has gone from a coastguard simulator with upgrading, and researching things to make better ships to basically a sandbox mode with money involved. No real reason, or motivation to actually go out and do missions, as you already have everything unlocked. if any and all of these problems are changed, I will gladly re-write my review. Until then I would say if you are planning to play this just to mess with the community made mods its great for that, there are amazing creators out there such as Thales who make amazing creations. But if you want to play this as a career mode type of game its lost that after this update.

poggers

Edit for 1.0 (removed obsolete points from original review):

There is a tutorial... barely.  It walks you through a basic fire extinguish and heal mission, tells you to deliver them to the hospital, and in the end just tells you you need to refuel when fuel is low, respawn ship via workbench and sleep to advance time.  Then it palms you off to the video tutorials... That's all you get.  It seems like about an hour was spent making that tutorial... and even that's a generous estimate.
How do you drop the anchor to stop your boat from drifting?  Where/how do the fuel pumps work?  Did I earn any money from completing that mission?  
I'm in the process of putting out a fire and rescuing some people, oh mission has expired... Like wtf, Im literally burning to death right now putting out an entire ship fire with 1 fire extinguisher....... and then the mission expires!!!  F*@k off...
There were many more annoyances I had with my short time trying this 1.0 version, but I don't want to rant too much more.

Overall, still a not recommend.  Although, I will say that if you have the patience to fight through the learning curve gauntlet, I reckon this is a fun game.  But when a game has you saying in you head and out loud, "this f*@king game" multiple times during just the tutorial; it may not be the right game for you.
(If i manage to git gud, I'll update with an actual review of the content......)

[spoiler]PS.  when i see positive reviews from users with 1 or 2 products and 1 review to their account giving garbage info-less 1 line reviews, I seriously question their authenticity and therefore, the general review score of the game.  Honestly, I feel this is a dishonest and disgraceful practice that should be removed from the industry[/spoiler]

-----------------------------------------------------------

Unfortunately, can't recommend this to a new player.  The bare-bones tutorial and lack of in-game help or hints really hinders new player on-boarding.
The possibilities for this look and sound amazing, and is a genre that is rarely visited in games.  
I have no doubt that if its potential is reached, it will be amazing, especially co-op.  Unfortunately, at the moment, I cannot immerse myself in it without frustration from a lack of in-game help.  

[spoiler]Also, looking at the recent reviews, I am very suspicious of a vast majority of their authenticity....  I could be wrong but as an experienced gamer and games industry worker, my spidey sense tingled..... [/spoiler]

The game has potential to be one of the most fun sandbox games to date. I've got 2k+ hours in gmod (mostly on WireMod sandbox servers) so I knew what I was looking for. I'll start of with the areas where the game must improve in order to be playable and enjoyable:
- Players can only spawn their vehicles on "Workstations". You can imagine this being hell on public servers where 8 players spawn things that clip into each other.
- On creative servers at any point in time players can recall their vehicle to the last used workstation, further amplifying the aformentioned issue. It seems that other people can also despawn other people's vehicles...
- The map is huge, but for each vehicle spawned your client FPS drops by w few fps... the game becomes unplayable with 3 workshop vehicles in the world... I feel like playing Arma/DayZ...
- Sound design must be improved. I had a mini heart attack when I heard the first thunder strike. Most sounds are not directional (the game just plays a stereo sound and decreases volume if you're far away, no left-right balancing depending on your rotation).

Unfortunately the 1.0 release is rushed, but I have my fingers crossed and decided to leave a positive review just to wish the devs good luck and motivate them to improve the performance. 

Great things about this game:
- A great sandbox for roleplay
- A great sandbox to learn programming and automation - the lua integration is awesome (I'd recommend adding more default libraries - matrices, quaternions etc.)
- A huge map to explore (optionally, can also just reveal everything)
- Opportunity for fun co-op with friends - missions!
- Your first cozy flight in a jet with an autopilot is a taste of this game's potential

The sandbox elements are there, but in the current state the performance is ruining the fun.

I love this game. The vehicle creator is the most detailed of any game I have played, allowing users to create microcontrollers and lua scripts.

As of 1.0 I have several issues with what the developers have chosen to focus one. 

The procedural mission generation is perfectly fine in theory but in practice it's riddled with bugs that they didn't bother to fix prior to releasing 1.0. 

Multiplayer connectivity remains garbage. Dedicated server hosting mitigates the awfulness that is p2p, but even configuring a dedicated server for this game has been unnecessarily finnicky. However, it will eventually work.

Building stuff in this game remains entertaining, but if you actually want to use said vehicles to conduct rescue operations, look elsewhere for the time being.

I'll change this review back to positive when the devs correct their course.

I had a huge amount of hype for this game going into 1.0. Me and my friends each racked up over 100 hours. Stormworks had a huge potential. But with 1.0 key mechanics and feature were removed for seemingly no reason. the Research tree - gone, the mission log - gone and the career settings moved from the new game screen to in-game but only in custom games. Gutting these systems leaves the game hollow and an empty expierence from the early access. You used to be able to tweak career mode settings before starting a game but this was moved to an in-game setting in the custom mode (creative) only. the research tree gave needed progression to the career mode starting you out with only the basic and require you to complete mission to unlock more advance parts. This simple mechanic, that was in need of work, to balance for example gave the career mode a strong focus and driving force to focus the player's gameplay. The mission  system in Stormworks is broken. It was broken in early access and from my limited time with 1.0 its even worse. In Stormworks missions are given randomly to the player with set time limits and requirements. These mission's don't increase in difficulty or curve with the players skill or previously what part the player had unlocked. During the early access this lead to you need to spend days in-game sleeping waiting on missions to spawn and hope you had the parts unlocked or you had enough time to complete them. This was really boring and annoying to play. With 1.0 they removed the tech tree, so I guess that fixed the not having the parts issue, but the missions are still randomly given. But worse is that they removed the mission log so you cannot tell how long a mission has left to complete. So you can spend days sleeping, get a mission and then get halfway through it before running out of time and failing. This game had HUGE potential, but the devs squandered it with 1.0, I will update this review if the devs ever fix these big three issues. I really want to recommend this game however i cannot in its current state.

This used to be a great game, now it is just frustrating.

I have spent about 350 hours playing it and it was very addictive. I took a little break from it the last few months and I was really excited when I saw that it was coming out of early access and that it had a ton of new stuff. I gave it a try by starting a fresh career mode save.

My first impression was that the map and navigation feature has been downgraded to almost unusable state. I think they are going for realism, but before you use to be able to select a mission and the mission markers (destination, people to save...) would show up not only on the map but above the actual stuff in the world making it really easy to identify where to go and what to do. Now if accidentally someone that is following you stops following you (which happens often because the NPCs get confused), it could be almost impossible to find them again because there is no marker above their head. Additionally there is no marker on the map screen for your location making navigation really hard sometimes.

After the first tutorial mission I tried two more and gave up because I got bored. Then I decided to just fly around in one of my older saved creations ... and got stuck in it because for some reason getting out of a hatch that is above you now seems impossible even with a ladder beneath it. It used to be tricky sometimes requiring a few attempts (you just fall back in when dismounting the ladder) but now i just can't do it. 

This is my second time just quitting out of the game after less than an hour of frustrating playtime. At least it is no longer addictive.

I also see that they have removed the research progression tree from the game which seems to make the career mode more like sandbox mode that is harder to have fun with.

I hope that player feedback will eventually guide the developers to make it a fun game again.

1.0.1 feels a bit like being hit in the head with a brick.  

Only you don't have that dizzy sense of fog and the unknown.  Rather everything has been revealed.  What once was a career filled with uncertainty and a sense of discovery, perhaps slowly coming out of a fog.  It's now all crystal clear.  "Who the hell would build a railroad like that?"  ...that huge island is strangely square shaped isn't it?  Oh look, north pole place with floaty stuff.  

Anyway, on to the first mission!

Oh very nice tutorial boat.  The career mode is won by simply building the best boat you could possibly assemble across several hundred hours of careful study of logic, robotics, and the most advanced logic concepts the game has to offer!  Must be that brick you hit me with, cuz I didn't realize I created it already and it sits here in front of me on the first tutorial mission.  Turns out I have already won the game.  

This "starter boat" features the technology of SpaceX cleverly disguised as a RHIB.  To complete our perilous tutorial mission we will need the following:  one small boat, preferably with a motor.  One first aid kit, and one fire extinguisher!  Check!

We have:  A Navy Seal Swiss Army Ginsu Knife Rescue RHIB stocked with every damn piece of equipment in the game, along with a two-way wireless radio, electric space heater (always good to keep one in the floor of an inflatable raft!), gyroscopic stabilizer, dual robotic pivot outboards sporting hydroplane stabilizers all managed by custom built micro controllers!  ...is that a radio remote control?  WTH can I talk to it?  "KIT it's Michael... Go rescue those people!"

This tutorial boat seems to be the reason we no longer have a technology tree to discover.  No need for it, just look at this boat!  It sports more tech and gadgets than Darth Vader's bathroom, what is left to discover on the tech tree?  Time Travel?  

Probably mild concussion from the brick but I seem to recall the original starter boat looked more like a running shoe and barely moved.  It was a joy to use because it was the least of rescue vehicles... and just made you want to get back to the workbench to build something better!  A new player looked at that old starter boat in the editor and the next button they wanted to click was "New".  

A new player looks at the logic in this new "starter boat" in the editor and the next button they want to click is "Refund".   

Things were so different before this head trauma...  I hope they have some bandages ready for a quick evac!  I hold out hope the patient can be saved.  ...we are still within that golden hour, but time is ticking.  Will the patient survive?

Edit: as of today, I am changing my review back to recommended!   This is based on the devs confirming the tech tree and career progression will be added back!  ...along with mission spawn/despawn buttons for the mission menu.  Two critical items will return!  Me thinkst the patient will survive after all.  ;-D

The game, "Stormworks: Build and Rescue", is different from what I expected. You should pay attention to that fact when you read the game description, or you might be unpleasantly surprised. Some good and bad points about the game, in my opinion obviously, from most to least important:
[list]
 [*] Bad – The physics are cartoonish. In contrast, in Kerbal Space Program (ver. 1.3.1)  when I build a plane it will mostly behave as I intuitively expect it to. Sure, KSP is not perfect either, but very playable when it comes to everyday Newtonian physics. That is not so in Stormworks. Components in Stormworks will be rigidly connected even when not obvious, water will flood open spaces even when the openings are far above the waterline, you cannot walk or swim beneath the elevated boardwalk because of the boundary box, if your fuel hose is too short it may easily fling your multi-tonnes boat several meters in to the air, and if you accidentally squish yourself between a rock and a boat the boat and/or you go flying too. The worst thing is that if I build a boat or a plane I am unable to intuitively  get a sense of its performance – I can honestly not tell by looking at a Stormworks plane if it will fly or not, and unlike KSP where modding allows you to debug/examine the 3D force components acting on each vehicle part, I do not think you can do that in Stormworks.
 [*] Good – The design of microprocessors is a lot of fun. You get at blue background that is sort of a blank printed circuit board and you can plonk down modules onto it. The modules are logic gates, adders, formula calculating modules, signal delaying capacitors, video signal routers and a lot more. You can then hook up the modules to each other by simple point and click and build your very own automation for your vehicle/vessel creations. For me this is the most fun part of the game.
[*] Good – A standard Steam license agreement, with none of that "sell your soul" stuff. An important consideration when comparing to the price of other games that might despite their low up front monetary payment hide other/further costs, risks or limitations in the EULA.
[*] Bad – The game has been promoted to version 1. For a version 1 game it is bland. I started the game, currently version 1.0.4, to check how the new game experience is. The answer is "without fun". That will probably get fixed at some point. My guess is that once the game sales wind down the developers will be persuaded to update the game.
[/list]
In short, I do not recommend buying the game now; put it on your "check back later" list instead. That way you might even be able to get it at a discount.

Updating my review for 1.0.

The game used to be pretty good, but the update kinda wrecks it. You build vehicles using a block system and spawn them into the world. Building things is still fun.

The gameplay is where the game falls apart in the new update:
- There is a mission editor but no way to spawn or activate the missions you create. 
- There's no dedicated Creative mode anymore. You can achieve the same effect by fiddling with the Custom Game settings, but that's an extra step now.
- There's no in-game tutorial. There are only videos. Because the builder can be complex, it will take you a while to figure out how to make a workable vehicle. 
- the docks in the game are too tall. There's not many low piers for loading small boats or using ramps. Getting off a boat usually means dropping into the water. 
- empty map. Apparently there's some kind of randomization used, but I have never seen it. Most of the map is just shallow ocean with a few preset islands that spawn in the same locations. 

For $20, it's not terrible but without good gameplay, there is not much to do with the vehicles you build. I don't recommend buying it right now.
