game is awsome and fun

I've changed my review from Positive to Negative because the 1.0 release update has been a complete shitshow for server owners and really puts the cherry on top for their complete disregard for optimization. In the change log they claim they've improved multiplayer performance and yet overall it runs worse on the server end then it did pre-1.0 update which is impressive given the already IMMENSE hardware requirements to run this thing. We've got an i9-9900k and we can't even have literally any boats in-server anymore, something we could have at least some of prior to this through having strong enough hardware without major TPS drops. Even large aircraft, something that literally did not affect our server AT ALL prior to this (very little physics calculations required when you're up in the air) can bring the server to a crawl with only one vehicle out.

This is the re-occuring repeat offender behavior that the devs have been exhibiting since the game's release essentially. Tape more shiny features onto the ductape mountain and hope it doesn't fall over. Use more tape to fix it if it does. The only major server performance "improvement" we've seen was the addition of 64 bit servers to duct tape fix the massive memory leak servers see which almost no one uses anyway because building a bigger boat to compensate for a leak doesn't mean it isn't going to sink eventually, and in this case the boat sinking on 64 bit is the entire OS crashing when it inevitably runs out of ram. To their credit though they at least managed to significantly reduce if not eliminate the ram leak with the 1.0 update.

I'll consider changing my review back to positive when the server software doesn't run worse than a fully loaded populated Space Engineers server on relatively top tier hardware.

Side note: They still haven't fixed forest fires causing the server to basically crash after a while which is now infinitely worse with vehicle fires. I really don't see how this update took them 10 months to make.

Hello. In early access I made a review.. I'll admit it was pretty cringe, leading up to me deleting it. This review has been made 2-3 days after full release. They have added things that stormworks players (Including me) Have wanted for years. I am actually amazed on how much the Stormworks devs have done, and its a very... Unique? You could say kind of game. Enough with the speech, (LOL) And lets get to the review.



Well.. 1st of all like I said they added stuff that Stormworks players including me have wanted for years. Tools! We can now repair our ships, as it used to be just "oh crap my ships damaged wheres the nearest spawn point" But now you can put things such as welders, medical kits, etc. On your ship, plane, heli, or sub. They also added spreadable fire. Fire used to just.. Sit there. But now it can spread and break your creations. 

If your reading this review, going "What creations? What what?" Well.. The base of the game is just to make a ship, use it as a coast guard ship, and do missions saving people, make cash, get bigger boats, and it just goes on.
You are just a coast guard. Past this point is pros and cons, only ones I can think of right off the bat..


Cons: Not perfectly optimized, but it could be much worse.
Cons: Multiplayer still crashes alot, even during full release.
Cons: There's still some bugs, (Getting flung off the map, etc.) 
That's not all the cons, but a game will never be perfect, And I like that

---------------------------------------------------------------------------

Pros: Really, really, really, really, really, times 100, times 100, times a million, its really fun.
Pros: If your not in to working alot for stuff, the game has a creative mode. You can toggle everything, Unlimited fuel, battery, no player dmg, no npc dmg, no boat dmg, etc. You can control weather, (wind, rain, fog) You can control time (The time of the day, whens sunrise and sunset, ect.) 
Pros: You can now Teleport the player around. (If in creative.)
Pros: workshop support. Download boats, planes, etc.
pros: You can stand up on your boat, plane, etc while its MOVING. Rare for games.


Summary: I like Stormworks. Its a unique game, and I think there's so much more potential.

I bought this game thinking they were going to have a career mode. I missed that part before they launched version 1.0, which is on me. Reading the discussions, there's a big fracture between the dev's and the customers.

That said, I'm really really interested in this game. It has a lot of potential, but if you like a progression type of game, I'd say wait to buy, because it seems like the dev's are making this into a creative mode only type of game. I was really excited to see all the youtube video's and open world career feel that the game had before, but I was massively upset when I bought the game and read that they removed a the big features I was looking forward to experiencing like:

1. Research to unlock new blocks aka forcing you to explore the map and islands or roam around in between missions looking for crates.

2. Mission map that allows you to accept missions and gives a brief explanation within a menu.

I'll change my vote if the dev's reverse course.

I've had this game for a couple years now, and I have to say that it has come a long way since then. The devs changed it a lot, especially since yesterday, when they took it out of early access. Two claps for them (maybe). I feel like the game is finally moving in the direction everyone wanted, and the game has a new, cleaner feel compared to before when it felt like the structure of the game couldn't handle the load of new features being added to it. I'd say it's still likely that one of the devs is gonna tune the physics just enough to screw up thousands of community-built creations, but I also feel that the devs have finally changed their mindset to fix the issues rather than adding features bringing new issues. The devs put a ton of time into this game, and I respect that. I personally consider this the best sandbox game there is, and if the devs continue to focus on the search and rescue half of the game, I might call it the best in that area. As of right now, I'm going to fix my creations broken from the recent update, and build new ones.

Version 1.0 has caused numerous problems for me, and for many other users, including the following, which even includes issues predating 1.0:

- Removed Mission Menu
- Removed Tech Tree/Progression
- No documentation on DS configuration, such as which starter base is which, or what settings do what.
- Lack of a Linux Dedicated Server (Which is more of a personal gripe than anything as someone who mainly uses Linux, and runs this game through proton)
- Instability (which even Windows users report)
- Poor Physics performance

Stormworks has great potential, but the removal of features long used and appreciated in a vain attempt at simplification has negated that. I even convinced a friend to buy this game before it released in full, and I feel bad because I sold them a game that even I didn't know would end up being screwed up come release. Sunfire - Do the community a favor and address these problems - especially Missions and Progression. I may be a creative user myself, but I can sympathize with those who have been shafted by this update.
awesome

I was looking forward to the game's 1.0 update, but in fact, after playing a bit of the game post 1.0, It's really become a dealbreaker. All the saves I had prior to 1.0 are broken, which I can live with, and is to be expected with a big update like this. What I take issue with, is the fact that sending the tutorial boat to the workbench and spawning it back crashes the game. One of the most important actions crashes the game.  They also removed virtually everything resembling progression from the career mode. You have all the parts right from the start, allowing you to build extremely high-tech vehicles from the start, where previously you were limited in what you could build at first, researching new technologies and building better builds with the new tech. The biggest issue though, is that missions aren't spawning. the missions you build your crafts to complete, aren't even spawning. How can you play the game when the objectives aren't there for you to complete? In short, Pre-1.0 I would have recommended this game, but with the 1.0 update, virtually everything on the workshop is unusable, except for brand new items, they removed much of what made career mode career mode, and there's so many bugs with this build that essential tasks are impossible without crashing the game. I'll continue to play once new updates arrive, and perhaps in time my review will change, but as of now, avoid this game until more updates are out.

you want to do pretty much everything except the missions the game wants you to do, but still have fun. Then this game is for you.edit: I still want to give this game a good review however there are some major glaring issues that I must address. First off is the devs lack of understanding of who is actually playing this game. They seem to pander to children and ignore people who want to actually make high quality stuff. They focus to much on big visions of the future instead of addressing the glaring issues such as the utterly useless multiplayer and broken physics. Next off is that the devs try and remove game exploits the wrong way. An example is that people found a way to make infinite electricity by using pivots, now how would you go about fixing this. Well the devs thought it would be a good idea to make the pivots use absurd amounts of electricity making them utterly useless. A better idea is to simply make it so that a tiny electric pivot cannot move a giant electric generator like real life. There is also the issue involving physics, while good in some ways they are horrid in others, in some cases the game does not even follow newtons basic laws of physics, such as his third law. You would think this would not be an issue! Devs please listen to your actual players, the ones who actually build great things, not the ones who spam "aDD WeaPOns" and build stuff that serves no purpose.Now the only reason I still recommend this game is because it is the only game that does what it does and as long as you ignore the glaring issues it can be enjoyable.

Arguably the best sandbox game available right now. The game of many people's dreams.
Extremely active Discord community and Steam Workshop. Game has been under very active development for the past 3 years and its developers have no intent of slowing down.

Yes there are bugs, yes some things are glitchy, yes there have been some growing pains with the development but let's be honest. The game is already pushing the boundary of what to expect of a sandbox game.

Buying this game is a nobrainer, you'll kick yourself for not having done it sooner.

It is the most advanced vehicle building game, it allows you to work on your machines from the dashboard up to the body, going through the engines (turbine, piston or electric) and many other components, you can control and program them with visual coding and LUA.
The game possess fluid (fuel, water), power (torque and RPS), string (cable, hose, rope), video and audio (ingame cameras and microphones), electricity, fire, sensors and hinge mechanics.
Since the smallest unit is 0.25m blocks, the game is very well suited to build big vehicles such as trucks, trains, helicopters and boats.

The game is updated regularly and there is more to come.

Thee game is amazing, really fun. But the new update as well as previous descions have really called into question the devs descisons with this game. Basically in the new update they removed alot of key features like spawning in missions manually, basic building mode (which alot of creations were built on) as well as making the game a whole lot more unstable. While they added alot of new things the game still feels clunky and not ready for 1.0. 

Plus the biggest issue for this game imo is its not supporting multithreaded CPUs, basically lets take me running the game as an example, i have an alright cpu and im maxing out at 60fps on the game on ultra, but when i spawn in a moderately large vehicle my games frames stay at 60 but the speed of the game is slowed down to half, basically whats happening is my computer is running it fine but the game can only calculate so many objects because it only supports single threaded CPUs, basically meaning no matter how good your PC is large creations will tank performance. And the worst part is they cant really fix it without remaking the entire game.

This was a great game. One of the best, if not THE best, block building game on the market IMHO. Planes, trains, automobiles, jets, VTOLs, speedboats, submarines, jetpacks, helicopters, variable swing-wing jets, cargo planes.....you name it, you could build it, all with missions to use your creations in. It used to be that way.

Then the devs decided to make the same mistakes that Space Engineers made and over-complicate things. Complicated is not the same thing as complex. Winches used to be straight forward. You want a mag winch? No problem, just put a mag end on a regular winch. You want a liquid hose? No problem, just run the pipe from a tank to the winch and put a liquid connector on the end. Now, they use a complicated wiring setup that changes depending on which end you put on it. Want to do a jet powered boat? Ok, but screw physics, people were building boats that moved too fast and exposed the flaws in their physics engine so instead of fixing the engine, they made it so you wouldn't see the flaws by limiting the speed. They nerfed the ever living shit out of the water pumps, and gear boxes now appearantly don't work if you use them on generators. Due to a small but obnoxiously loud set of people who keep banging on the realisim drum, this game has gone from an exceptionally fun creative game to a micro-management simulator where the devs have gone so far out of the way to make sure you don't exceed a set speed limit or build an extremely efficient engine. Oh, and if you don't know Lua scripting, don't plan on building any of their advertised newer features like radar. It seems that instead of doing their jobs and developing a game, they're only going to do part of the work and make the players build the rest of the components for them. The funny thing is, those same idiots that are clamoring about realisim are happy about having to build the game for the devs like a bunch of toolbags. If I wanted realisim, I'd shut the computer down. Additionally, by trying to achieve realisim, they have gone so far in the opposite direction that the extreme glaring flaws and lack of realisim stand out like a sore thumb. I want a game where I can put a radar console on my bridge and a radar antenna on the roof and have it work. Not have to actually program it. I don't want to have to learn a new programming language just so I can fill in the missing game sections the devs didn't make it around to completing. Now it's just another developer making the player create the game via scripting. Any past good reviews this game got no longer apply to this newer version. The devs need to do the work they already got paid to do. Build a game, not a scripting interface with a few blocks. Spend your hard earned money elsewhere on a complete game, not this half-baked crap.

StormWorks is a wonderful game its a great creative and survival sand box. Stormworks is a good game. BUT IT WAS MUCH BETTER BEFORE THE 1.0 UPDATE. They made a bunch of dumb changes and it is super buggy. There is a glitch that makes it where you can't take planes back to the workshop. It teleports you into the plane. I'm pretty sure this isn't intentional but it makes it basically impossible to play the game. Loading in large aircraft is suicide. Because of the bug you won't be able to teleport them back into the workshop to unload them so once you spawn a vehicle in it will stay there forever. So you basically have a limit of how many vehicles you can spawn. And if you spawn too many vehicles the game will crash a ton and lag a lot. And speaking of large vehicles, you can't do large vehicles anymore. Because you can't do missions anymore. So anything you build has to fit within the workshop which is really limiting. LIKE HOW ARE YOU SUPPOSED TO DO AN AN-225 OR A380. THEY ARE BOTH LIKE THREE STORIES TALL. YOU CAN'T FIT THEM IN THE WORKSHOP. And you can't do giant spaceship thingies either without missions. Even the non-workshop missions were super fun. And you can't customize the game settings anymore. And the weather thing is really finicky and only works sometimes. It was really useful for everything. Also, now you have an inventory so you don't have a flashlight all the time which is not fun. And the game still crashes a lot. And the ground is missing in some areas. It's a mess. Also it randomly deleted half my map. I didn't have the creative base unlocked. It was so weird. And now I'm going to have to fly all the way back to the arctic again. Not that I'm going to keep playing Stormworks if it keeps being like this. There are large amounts of changes needed for this game to be fun again. The new update just ruined a great game.

I love building games, so when I saw StormWorks had smaller building blocks than the other games and they had LOTS of building items I bought it immediately.  I'd like to think I'm an avid builder; I use CAD software and blueprints whenever possible depending on what I'm constructing.  Since my builds seem to lag the software a bit, I have to load the vehicle in the mission editor and load it as a mission but it ran very smoothly.  The normal workshop spawn would lag the majority of my vehicle spawns, especially if I had several small ones in at the same time.

https://steamuserimages-a.akamaihd.net/ugc/1584659073427214004/1F014F48270AD0ACB4CC0DC4D76FB120634B3CF8/

Now since Stormworks has been released as 1.0 (out of beta) lots of new blocks have been added that adds quite a bit of immersive rescue gameplay.  Unfortunately they have removed a lot of previously existing features and games modes, including research-Tech tree, loading a mission (what I relied on), rogue mode and creative mode.  The new Custom mode is what creative mode was.  There could also be a LOT more blocks that we can utilize, even dynamic/player-shaped blocks and more utility type blocks.

I am at a stand still in building because I used the mission editor to spawn the vehicles, I could do it repeatidly with each vehicle save.  Until they make the game where I can use the normal spawn & it doesn't lag the game like crazy OR they bring back the mission editor like before, I could continue.  But there are other games I can go to until then.

But as of the 1.0 release date one reviewer said 'If you really enjoy building, testing & running with said design, you'll have fun.  If you're looking for something with meaning and a sense of accomplishment, look elsewhere.'  Hopefully they change that to what we had previously, but I'm not holding my breath.

With the release of 1.0; Stormworks took on drastic changes, some good, many not so good.

The new tools, fire spread system, weather system, and noticeable performance optimizations, especially in multiplayer, really improved the quality of life for the little things. There are also new mission creation tools that allow for player-made creations. 

Now to the not so good. All sense of career progression has been wiped... its creative mode but with money. The map, which was mostly procedural with a fog of war, was a fun thing to explore between missions but is now fully explored. There's now no real goal to shoot for with 1.0.

The entire concept which drove career mode is now gone. The research of new parts was completely removed. It is no longer possible for beginners, such as my self, to learn new components gradually, now they're all just thrown at you

The Devs had an amazing setup for Career Research & progression going for it. You would be rewarded with research points, money, random parts on missions completion and you could decide which pieces needed researching the most for the next potential Job. Just eliminating any idea of wonder and exploration has really ruined the experience for us...me. Quite a few were looking forward too 1.0.0 with everything that has been added...But then for no discernible reason, Research was removed, Exploration was removed... Everything that made Career mode...Career mode, besides money... is just poof. Like it never existed. Why? You broke my gamer heart. Id gladly recommend this game, before 1.0.

A game that rewards creativity in many interesting and cool ways that I have never seen before. The game may appear simple on the surface, given it's look, and premise, but it has some of the most complex systems out there in the gaming world, providing a perfect work space for some amazing creations. Don't be fooled by my recorded gameplay hours, as I have played this game offline without WiFi for the past 6 months, and it has been a god send for those boring hours in the day. If you love building vehicles, with complex systems and freedom of creative liberties, this is a must have.

A super fun and smooth game. Very similar to Space Engineers but with much smoother building and mechanics. Pistons, rotors and moving parts work amazingly. It's 11 days from the 1.0 release, and this game is still a buggy mess, that's not really playable other than for some idle messing around. I keep coming back hoping that they'd fix the obvious bugs that have been around since the game entered Early Access, but they haven't. Worse, looking through the bug tracker, the devs seem to either not care about these bugs, or more interested in telling the community they're wrong when these issues keep getting brought up.

For those pers taking a look when version 1.0 releases in a week and a half, make sure you're willing to put up with a basically broken game. There is some awesome gameplay potential, but I've given up hoping that it'll ever be an actually fun game that you can play career mode in.

Ah, Stormworks. For years I have been looking for a creative sandbox and I've finally got the jackpot. I've played stormworks for over 250 hours now, and I can wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone who reads this. If you like sandboxes, and you like to tinker or build, this is the game for you. First, this game has taught me more about technology than any book or teacher could ever hope to teach. It Explains the physics of objects in very subtle ways, and leaves you with nothing but curiosity and grit. If you don't like self teaching, you can work off of builds on the workshop and later use your new found skills to create a successful resque company. If you are lazy and just want to play around in the sandbox, you can use builds from your friends and play around with the physics of the game. Speaking of physics, I love them. This game almost flawlessly simulates water, ground, and air seemlessly, giving you the most life-like experience a game could ever hope to give. submarines, boats, cars, trucks, planes, helicopters, If it fits within the build space, chances are you can build it. But you may be thinking, "wow this building stuff must be like those battle ship games I keep seeing ads for." First of all, building is super complicated. I whould make sure to watch a lot of tutorials and experiment with the physics first. It's the easiest way to figure this stuff out. Once you spend a couple of days figuring it out, you should be good for your first build. The building is like micro Minecraft, but with 100+ parts and pieces that have to be arranged in very intimate ways. Plumbing, fuel systems, air intakes, all together it might take hours depending on skill. So take it easy. Start small, like a speed boat, or a Tug. So you may be asking yourself another question- why is this game so low-poly? Chances are you have heard of Minecraft before, it is kind of like that, but not the environment, just the vehicles. This gives worse quality, but much more creative freedom. There are enough block types to make everything look beautiful in this game. In conclusion, this game is awesome and it is 4 AM and I want to go to bed. I hope you enjoyed reading and this guide / review helps you decide wether you should purchase this game.

Space Engineers, Factorio, Satisfactory, Rimworld... any game with an extreme amount of depth is utterly crushed by how complex and purely creative driven this game is and can be for the player. You can create absolutely any kind of vehicle, maybe not a space shuttle. All aspects of the game come with complex mechanics that allow for a full heavy multiplayer based gameplay where you can tag along with friends to save NPCs that can follow you, or even be picked up by you. It's impossible to describe the entire game, it's definitely worth the buy.

Stormworks is an achievement in game-design. The physics, components and performance and absolutely astonishing.

Stormworks ruins other clanky games like Space Engineers by proving it's possible to have a rock solid robust simulation with buoyancy, air compartments, lift and drag.

The game by all means with a simulation so good could run at 10fps and I would recommend it - but instead it puts other games to shame by easily getting >100FPS

I don't know how they did it, but you can build rockets, VTOL jets, boats and ships with more components than you could imagine. Even including scripting which people use to make all sorts of awesome HUD displays and systems.

The game is easily a 10/10 for what it set out to accomplish.

Even if that were true the build mode made me quit. I cannot describe to you how frustrating it is to design anything in this. I wish I could just pull up a CAD program, design my boat, and then put it in the game. In two hours I could have easily done this, but in the editor I finally started to get irrationally angry with how clunky and ridiculous it is. I was not having fun, I found myself hating everything about the experience and so I stopped. No, I won't be giving the game another chance, and no, I don't care if you like this game and think I'm not being fair. I didn't like it and I don't want it.

It is a great concept, but my first 120 hours was literally working out how to make things work, with the release just around the corner I thought I would check out how it had progressed. 

Well it has become even more complicated, some simple two click building tasks now require game engine manipulation techniques, for goodness sake they have even added LUA scripting... actual computer coding kind of stuff, to ship components.

The 'Basic' mode is too basic, denying you the ability to make vehicles do what you want, yet the 'Advanced' mode is an under-statement, requiring full knowledge of logic circuits and programming. 
Sure you can browse the workshop for hours to find some pre-made vehicles, most of which are half built asking how to make them work and some true masterpieces that you probably will not work out how to even start the engine.

Good:
This is a very good game if you like in depth vehicles or machines, It also allows you to create some very complicated machines if you wish but I personally mainly use workshop creations. Multiplayer is an option and at the moment of writing the review is relatively stable. 

Bad: it can be difficult to find fixes online for any issues you may have however this should become easier as the community grows, The game is relatively stable but with my specs (i5-8400 and rtx 1660) some larger creations will drop framerate substantially

Overall: The game offers a lot of options for creations either from the workshop or for you to create yourself, for the price of $20 I would definitely recommend this game to other players.

Note* I have barely played the career mode and so I have nothing to say about how fun the career mode is in this game

This game is very entertaining. If you like to create, you can create a lot of different things in different ways. The many different parts makes creating hulls relatively easy. The game has many different complex mechanics. The game definitely needs optimization though, as even on my gaming pc, when spawning large or complex creations the game lags. The physics also need some work, and the game doesn't have weapons, whether that's a plus or minus for you xD. The developers do look at what people want for the game with discord polls and the feature and bug page. The career mode is pretty fun, although it can be time consuming to tediously make a bunch of vehicles for different purposes. For me at least, the game is a bit on the harder side when creating things, because sometimes you see a problem but don't know the cause of it. The game allows for very flexible vehicle controls, allowing you to make a giant wall of buttons to press xD. The game also includes logic and a customized LUA scripting language, which allows you to make GUIs with HUDs and maps with monitors. As of when I'm writing this, they have announced the full release and along with it some handheld items and a new modular engine system. The multiplayer is very laggy when over a few players. Multiplayer in general isn't very good, even after they tried to fix it. The game looks visually good. There are an endless amount of things to do in it. I've seen a few bad reviews saying the game is buggy and the developers don't care about the community. Those are both wrong from my experience. The game has some bugs, but none of them are really a big deal, especially not game breaking. The developers interact with the community and do a good job of adding what people want. To prove this, the update after the full release update is going to have modular engines, a feature voted on in the Stormworks Discord server. I like the developers, some may say they are only okay, which is reasonable. But they are definitely NOT bad.

Star rating:
4/5

Notes: If the game ran well enough to not lag or slow down by creations within the build limits, it would be 5/5.

By far the best game in this genre!
I have played many games in this genre: From the Depths, BrickRigs etc ... and none of the same can beat Stormworks. The variety of the blocks allows an almost unlimited number of vehicles (from ships, submarines, aircraft of all kinds, land vehicles to all-terrain vehicles). Due to the highly frequented updates, the game always remains interesting (even if there are sometimes minor bugs in the updates ;) ... makes the game a lot funnier). The physics in this game are more or less realistic, yet the best in this genre -> only Brickrigs could keep up here. Due to its complexity, Stormworks is quite difficult at first. The "Arcade" mode can help here, as the logic circuits are simplified here. In "Realistic" mode, however, you need some help at the beginning, tutorials are almost indispensable. Optional would be a tutorial for the "Lua scripting" -> because Stormworks also supports Lua. The last point refers to the multiplayer. The multiplayer is unfortunately only partially usable. It works very well in itself ... but only with very good internet, otherwise you are moving in slow motion.

I hope I could help! If you have any questions or improvements, just contact me. ^^

Stormworks is a game with a level of complexity that makes a lack of any built-in / "official" tutorial unforgivable. Youtube tutorial makers are your only source for an explanation for how building, logic and control of vehicles works but at this point in the games life cycle tutorials seem directed more towards existing players looking for more complex designs rather than people getting started. I would not recommend anyone new buy this game because it does not seem interested in getting new players.

Especially with the new updates, I have no regrets buying Stormworks at all! The big problem is how painfully slow multiplayer is with just two or three people (The maximum is 6) without a good computer, but considering it's an early access game, it's really well made! The only thing I'm not happy about is the multiplayer function, because not only is it laggy and slow, but you can only play with friends. Overall this game Is one of my favorites if not my absolute favorite on steam!

This game is absolutely amazing. I have almost 1400 hours in this game and I still haven't gotten bored of it. There is so much you can do in this game, from large scale rescue missions, forest fires to transporting fuels and cargo. Not only that, but you can build your own vehicles, such as trucks, planes, helicopters, ships and way more to assist you while doing missions that vary heavily. There is almost nothing in this game that you can't build. This game is well worth its price as it is now, it even has regular updates every two weeks. There are so many different locations too, such as the arctic, mountains, deep sea, and other islands scattered around such as observatories, hospitals, coast guard bases, power plants and even an old sea fort. This game also has fairly realistic physics and mechanics, such as varying weather that can affect the environment around you such as wind affecting the waves, or lightning that can strike your air vehicles out of the sky. It also has stuff like water pressure, temperature that affects your character realistically, and so much more. There is equipment that you can wear that can help you combat these environments too, such as SCUBA and diving gear, thermal clothing, parachutes, firefighting gear and way more.  This is just me listing off stuff that I like about the game, there is so much more that this game has to offer. To be honest, I don't understand why this game isn't way more popular than it already is. This game is a must have.

[h1] Definitely Worth Getting [/h1]

Stormworks is one of the most impressive build-and-survive games I've seen. Not just in terms of features, but of how hard working and dedicated the developers are, and how they try to work with the community to improve features and add new content. They've made a really unique and enjoyable game. There are options that allow players to choose a low-stress experience, letting them focus less on engineering their vehicles, and more on gameplay, while also having an 'advanced' building mode that allows all would-be engineers make highly specialized and complicated vehicles. While ships and boats are perhaps the primary focus of the game, a player can build ground vehicles and aircraft with relative ease. There's still a bit of a learning curve involved in building an understanding of how different systems work, but learning how to do new and interesting things can be an incredible amount of fun.

Stormworks is a game about building vehicles, and testing them in a trial by fire. 

Somethings to keep in mind:

-There are no "real" Weapons Yet (This is a big turn off to some players - others like myself it's a breathe of fresh air)

-The Map is mostly seas - and although there are rockets there is no "Space".

-Stormworks itself can be buggy (especially in multiplayer); slowly bug surely bugs are getting rioned out.

-Stormworks has succeeded where many other titles have failed in creating a realistic water/liquid simulation, the waves are so realistic they can even drag you under when swimming, or cause your boat to capsize if not properly constructed.

Some of the things you may be called upon to do:

-Deliver Heavy Equipment by Land/Sea/Air to a site and install it.
-Recover Stranded Drones/Ships/People
-Manage Resources including two types of fuel (diseal/jetfuel) and Crude Oil (tradable resource)
-Create and Utilize Highly Complicated Designs of Ships, Trains, Aircraft (both VTOl and HTOL), Submarines, and Land Vehicles. 
-Deal with Weather Events that may range from a simple rough seas to a highly dangerous tsunami

All in all a good game. Just remember to stay below 100m during lightning :P

Basically the best parts of KSP and From the Depths in one game. Great missions, amazingly simple building that can get deeper and more complicated than most people are capable of managing. Great mechanics, and even the flight is pretty good. Its not Arma or DCS but it's better than 99% of everything else.

Edit: at 420 (nice) hours this game has taught me some basic LUA coding and I'm still enjoying it. The flight model isn't as good as I had originally thought, at that time I had only flown helicopters. Now after building a few conventional fixed wings and jets I can say that the air is super thick, there's no such thing as gliding or lift, and thrust is really what keeps you in the air. It's still a lot of fun and not so bad unless you reall want to get an accurate flight simulation.

After 100+ hours of playtime, I believe I can review this game more in depth. Stormworks is an amazing game, with the ability to make anything. You can create your own electronics (microcontrollers) and integrate them into your vehicle. Hydrodynamics, aerodynamics, and all vehicle dynamics play a part in your success. 

I have played some survival, and my only grievance is the lack of totourial. you just get chucked in. I'd recommend playing some creative first.

Multiplayer is almost seamless. It all depends on your internet, and the amount of vehicles/lagginess.

Overall, Stormworks goes above and beyond to give you a gameplay experience no other game can possibly attempt to offer. 100% recommended.

This is a fun game to waste time on especially when you are building something but when it comes to playing the Survival mode the game becomes quickly boring.

It either goes - Go too these select NPCs bring them from POINT A to POINT B get rewarded with some money and research points to gain a few items to put on your boat or build a new one.

Other missions go pretty much the same way in terms of rewards except this time it's a crate above land or underwater (really revolutionary I know)

If you want to play with your friends (if you have any that is) it has a multiplayer mode but the catch is...
[spoiler] It runs somehow worse than a crippled man... [/spoiler]

If you like playing in slow-motion at all times with your friends and can barely play the game the multiplayer is for you! The multiplayer can cripple pretty much a Nasa Super Computer (I run this game on a really above average high-end computer and the multiplayer still runs like shit).

Where the game shines and overweights the cons is its community and the building mechanics. You can go for hours building boats, ships, spaceships, submarines pretty much anything you can think of as long the game does not break on you. You can browse the workshop download a bunch of community-made vehicles for hours. The developers of the game also update the game very frequently (even do it makes the game run more shit).

If they fixed
- THE MULTIPLAYER
- THE BUMASS MISSIONS
- PERFORMANCE UPDATE
this would be genuinely a really good game.

I recommend this game for those who like to waste time building stuff and having a youtube video playing in the background and chill.

The possibility's of your creation is limited to your patience, and your skill of design (trust me patience is needed here, when you need to try get your first ever boat working, without tipping over, its difficult.) Please get this.

This game is fun for everyone, if your a survival/ job-mission guy, or a creative-lover dude who just wants to experiment, and break, I am a creative breaker myself, because hey, if you can break a ship or plane or car, who's to say you can break physics? Anyways, moving on, I personally love sinking ships, and with 1.0 V coming soon, it's going to make this game even more fun, oh and there are 2 disasters, well 1 disaster and 1 big shark so, maybe more disasters to come, because that would be epic, who's to say I can't imagine acid rain? Or raining fish? Just hitting the ship or plane, hurting the blocks, and causing a tiny leak, which can cause a connector to break, causing the plane or ship to stop working? All I can say,  this game isn't a master piece, due to some bugs, but it's a wonderful game, a game that you might enjoy, depending on your mindset for games, this is like brick rigs, but it's not destructive or lego bricks breaking, rather it's a game that anyone can enjoy, if their mindset loves it, as a game in their category, I can say this, this game, is something many enjoy, and maybe you will too, also, there are more than just planes and ships, theres also cars and trains. Thats all I have to say.

REVIEW HAS CHANGED A LOT OVER THE COURSE OF 2 YEARS

Well here we are! 37 hours in and having a blast, I'm giving this a 7/10, though I really enjoy it.
The reason I'm giving it a 7/10 is because:
 - It's not that hard to get into, the building is easy to get into and had me sucked into it for a straight 8 hours, just because I wanted to finish my ship.
 - Though being very early in Development and being rather buggy, you can still have a fun experience, the career mode is fun, and you learn a bit from it, go into creative mode and have a blast building your own vehicles, ranging from boats, submarines, to helicopters and jets!
 - I really recommend this to anyone who likes building vehicles, it has a simple style and it's easy to get used to!


-----------

Here we are again, 1100+ hours, told you it's worth it :)

-----------

Here we are for the 2nd time, 1700 hours, and to be honest it's lost it's replay value, the game is great but it gets boring.

----------

Ait here we are again, I'm changing my review to not recommended because honestly the devs are fu*king garbage, they don't listen to the community, and instead of giving us features and fixing bugs we want fixed they add half broken features every week to shut the community up for a week.

----------

So in a few weeks the devs will release the game, exiting early access. In my opinion, and to many others, this game is in no state to leave early access. It's buggy, the devs dont listen, and moderation in the official discord server is like China, you even try to go against moderation or even talk about it, you'll get instantly banned. And the devs still dont listen to the community. The game itself is playable-ish. It randomly crashes, physics issues, graphical issues, a lot of stuff that is bugged. And they're going to up the price for it... Terrible dev team.

- You cannot edit objects, vehicles,or move them where you'd like
- you can only do and use what others have created for you
- There is no tutorial
- There are no instructions

The only guidance this game gives is a staircase to a workbench if you accidentally start career mode on the starter island. After that you are just supposed to understand.
this is a game that relies 100% on the workshop and 100% on the community. If you want to try and build stuff you can deep dive user generated tutorials on how this games mystery systems work and crack the enigma. You can try to edit existing vehicles but that too is a wild hit and miss. Add a railing to a ship? now it takes on water. Remove an annoying light fixture, Plane no longer flies. 

There is a ton of potential for this game but you are the one to dig to find it. I want to recommend it. But you hit a wall instantaneously if you try career mode or don't first think to use the workshop.

The idea is brilliant again. (i guess lego have invented it :)
However, the editor is a real garbage...
Endless reconnecting and reconnecting of parts, cause it's real pain to move them, so you recreate and recreate. It's not not an editor, all basic functions are missing or useless.
Physics seems ok at first glance, but just built a hundred meter tall 25cm*25cm tower, with a 50x50cm base plate. Its  not even moving at max wind. And still able to push the whole thing it with my hands ???
No aerodynamics (while buoyancy seems good), you can make a box, add control surfaces and it will fly. If you add a tiny wing to your plane then it can fly at walk speed without stalling. All your engines and robotic parts have superpowers. To the space on a hose!
Adding any shape to your vehicle is almost only for aesthetic reasons. I thought it will be fun to build airplanes, but i lost my enthusiasm. I guess ill have to try befriended with ships, which i am not really interested in.

For me these problems seem like conceptual or limitation of the engine.
However the "process control" part is fun, versatile and challenging (building your circuit and add your code to control mechanics and engines, building dashboards, those kind of things)
Yeah, it's a process control game. And they should really fix the editor!

Stormworks: Build and Rescue is an awesome game which immerses you in multiple scenarios with different, realistic vehicles with incredible weather physics, sort of. For the first 50-75 hours the game is great. but as you move on it gets boring. Mainly because there is no one to play with. Then there's multiplayer which has servers that are complete shit and garbage. They are so incredibly laggy and it's practically impossible to play. The game has so much potential with all it's updates. This game is built for roleplaying certain scenarios. It would be awesome if there were realistic response missions that you and your friends responded too, without immense lag. The game also has the potential to be more immersive. The weather physics are good, however, for e.g "Your outside a plane, it's loud due to it's engines, you get inside, it gets much quieter. There is rain outside the boat, you go inside, it gets quieter,m ad you here the droplets of the rain on the roof". This is what I wish would happen instead it's basically the same audio level. I think in some houses across the map if you go into them the weather stops a bit but in some it doesn't, but I want it to stop in vehicles not just houses. There are also several audio patterns from engines that keep repeating it self at an extremely high level, then I turn the game sounds lower which then makes other sounds that I want to be louder that aren't ear-rape engine sounds quieter.
If this game got a massive multiplayer revamp, and you were able to just start lobby's with your friends and not just servers, and it wasn't so laggy and desynced: And if the audio improved itself in a massive overhaul in ways I have explained above. This game would be so darn good, I wouldn't be able to stop playing it man. Oh and also, as a side note, many creations, are extremely laggy and you require a good pc for it, I have a gaming laptop which is alright-ish, kinda garbage and struggles with creations which also make my experience terrible. But this is a personal factor that many of you will not endure. I guess the game could be optimised a bit but whatever, the too main things, AUDIO, MULTIPLAYER. If I could give a thumbs up and a thumbs down I would, like half-half.

This game is excellent. The fact it is in EA is by no means a downside. What is already an amazing game has the added bonus of frequent content updates and active devs. I can't wait to see this game's future. 

***Edit*** I've added some tips below for reducing lag which is probably one of the most frequent complaints as game complexity increases.

Full Steam Workshop integration makes this game truly shine. There are tens of thousands of amazing player creations to have fun with with more added every day of course. My advice is to download ones that have been updated in the last 6-12 months for best compatibility given the frequent updates. VTOL's are my favorite all in one SAR vehicles when seconds count.

Lag tips:

After playing for quite a while now in SP and MP there are valid complaints of lag  by players. Design complexity is obviously a factor and I look forward to future optimization to help with that but I have found a couple key factors to look at to reduce lag.

-Check your mods! Environment and structure mods can stack and cause severe lag, especially in MP. Check to see what's enabled and have a dedicated MP save file with minimal or no environment/structure mods. This was a huge culprit for my MP lag.

-Design complexity can have adverse effects on your game performance but it isn't always the problem. HUGE Titanic sized ships are going to lag - period. But there are some seriously advanced jet liners that hardly lag at all, even in MP, and I think that is due to the mod designer's streamlining of their own design. And again, some are just so massive that there's nothing that can be done without owning a beefy system.

-Try to reduce excess objects in game or turn your draw/spawn distance way down to compensate. Until the game gets further optimization or they change background spawned vehicles if you have 12 aircraft dotted around different bases and a couple of ships it's going to lag quite a bit. 

-My friends have reported good success in lag reduction by turning off VSync. 

-Internet connections play a factor in the MP so make sure whoever is hosting has a decent connection. I host my friends at 100Mbs.

Finally, remember this is very early access! You are not going to get polished AAA performance all the time. Use the developer feedback tools in game to submit bug and feature requests and help make the game even better.

So i dont ussualy write reviews for games on steam so bare with me.

This game is fun if you like sandbox/build your vehicle type of games (i do), if you are more into story driven games than this game might not be for you.

Every now and than (maybe weeks maybe months) a new update commes out ussualy adding new blocks/items and missions (maybe even new land but those are ussualy hyped alot beforehand). It is still in Early Access but it isnt a downside because it isnt a buggy mess like some other Early Access games.

It also has a big talanted community and workshop support with cool stuff being uploaded there daily (with introduction of invaroment mods people are making automatic train lines, bus lines, cable cars etc.). 

Overall this game is not to hard to get into but hard to master (you will make your first boat releativly quick but you probably wont make automatic trains in your first 100h).

It also has lua support and screens so you can code the screens to display stuff (like cctv system and touch screen).

The water physics in this game are quite good (stuff can flood you can close a door to prevent the water to flood the rest of the ship if too much of the ship floods it will sink maybe even leaving air pockets)

If you are into this kind of build your own vehicle games i would recommend it so far it was fun.

Very good early access game. I have been playing career mode and am particularly impressed by the lighting, weather, general atmosphere and physics, you really feel like you'e a coast guard going around rescuing stranded people, hazarding large waves and stormy weather, managing fuel and delivering things. The map appears to be really gigantic as well, so it's good for exploration, and the number of detailed creations on the workshop gives even people who aren't into building a lot of different vehicles to play with. 
If I had to offer any criticism, it would be mostly towards the npcs, or rather the lack thereof. There are npcs in the world but they seem to be mostly spawned in for specific missions. If you just run/drive/fly around random villages, which are all over the place, you will never find anyone in any of the buildings, nor is there any random helicopters or boats around in the world. I think the game would improve a lot if they could incorporate some stray npcs standing around houses, and boats that patrol here and there, the odd helicopter flying around, even just giving the appearance that things are going on. Because the game nails the other elements of immersion like weather, graphics, physics, but just lacks on this aspect of being a little too empty outside of missions. And to tie those two together, more 'stumbled upon' missions, like finding a random person floating out at sea, would be really nice too, instead of the more formal "you got this mission now go do it" variety that you tend to get now.

The building and mechanics are excellent, extremely satisfying. However the mission gameplay is comically bad; you can be assigned missions that you haven't unlocked the necessary equipment to complete, most of the missions are completely uninteresting even if you CAN complete them, and the rewards are frequently disproportionate to the amount of work necessary to complete them.

TL;DR: If you want to play with boats and planes in a sandbox go for it. If you want actual goal-oriented gameplay wait until they fix the missions.

If you like games like space engineers, ships, trains, etc. and/or greatly overestimate your artistic abilities like me, you'll love this game. I spend way  to much time in this just trying to build my first little boat than I care to admit. The devs are also great and provide fairly regular updates and often acknowledge and include player feedback. Steam workshop support means you can also download other (incredibly talented people's) ships/helicopters/etc. to play with in your own game.

So yeah, if you wanna copy a Blackhawk or build your own Coast Guard cutter get this game.

Game design that wastes the player's time.

This game seems like a fun concept, but unfortunately the developers have chosen to design the game in a way that wastes player's time. Specifically, the research tree is a huge problem. Researching a single item at the beginning of the game takes between 30 and 40 real-world in-game minutes. There are about a dozen items to research at the beginning of the game, and there appears to be hundreds total. I'm not sitting around for that!

Further, building large ships is a tangled mess of tedious node connections with no real tools to help organize or understand how large systems are connected. An average player will need to download any reasonably complex ship from the workshop because of how poorly organized the ship builder is, especially data connections.

I regret buying this, and also can't get a refund because it took 4 hours of playing for me to even figure out just how much of my time this game was wasting.

An in depth game with a solid foundation already in early access.
Already very definetly worth the price and it actively keeps going in the right direction.

What sets this game apart from other block vehicle builders is that it has career mode with meaningful and working progression and mission system that supports the building aspect of the game by giving rather freeform goals for builds.

It's Kerbal Space Program but for everything except rockets. Aerodynamics model is (at time of writing) wonky and physics can be a little funny sometimes, but you can get really lost in this game with how many possibilities there are. At time of writing i've barely even scratched the surface, but even as-is in early access i can say this was worth my money.

I absolutely love this game. I personally have had no anti piracy issues, however cannot comment for others. As the game is still in early access it does contain some  bugs, However I have yet to find any that are game breaking. For me personally I find it frustrating that the water level is always visible, even when inside a sealed section of a boat, however I can not be sure if this is a bug, as watching videos on YouTube, the players I watch do not seem to have this, or I simply havent noticed. Also it could potentially be my 8 year old computer with outdated hardware. My PC does not meet all of the recommended requirements, and because of this I do suffer frame rate issues when in ports etc, however this cannot be blamed on the game, as far as I'm aware, it's my old computer. Again, due to the old computer I do have to play with all the settings turned down low.

Some people may find the game difficult to get into, I've found that there is a bit of a learning curve, mainly if you play in advance mode, however there are plenty of tutorials that can be found on YouTube. I found MrNJersey to be extremely helpful and interesting, if you like games such as kerbal space program, I would be very surprised if you do not enjoy this game.

I havent tried any missions etc that the devs have provided, and I dont even know if there are tutorials (had the game a while, havent even looked). I tend to spend most of my time in sandbox mode building stuff. I like how when building there is different options as to how involved you want to get, there is the possibility to add monitors and custom scripts that can be entered so the monitors (or whatever your using) can show/do a whole range of  stuff. Or you can simply connect the monitor to a camera and it works. I also like that there is an advance mode, which means engines need air fuel exhaust etc.. or you can turn this off and simply place an engine down.

 The game is updated very frequently as well which I find really positive, especially as the game has been around for at least a year.

I personally havent looked into multiplayer, I assume my computer wont be able to handle it, however the idea seems like an amazing one. There appears to be a very good community, there is lots of items on the workshop, some big some small some in between, it would be nice for me to one day play with friends.

Thank you to the devs for such an amazing game.

A flaw in the game's anti-piracy system causes me to have a false positive on my pc and doesn't allow me to play quietly as its system is very beautifully designed to annoy you every second of play with fish flying around and destroying everything. 

For a few months I waited in case they fixed it in some update but they didn't, so I ended up complaining in the support but they closed the complaint, they didn't answer me or if they did it was after I insisted asking them for help because I just wanted to play. Many treated me as a pirate (when I have the game bought and never had it pirated) and even the developers ignored me for a long time. When one developer finally responded, she sent me to another developer who again ignored me.

So, finally after months of wanting to play. Here's my negative for ignoring me and not helping me, and for having a [spoiler]s-h-i-t-t-y[/spoiler] anti-piracy system.

The funny thing? I got banned from the discord for pirating! The same developer of the game banned me for a bug in his system, being that I have bought the game!

I didn't expect anything else after all.
developer_response:
Hi all,

We regret this player had a frustrating experience and we always work hard to address issues where we can help.

To clarify a few things:

One of our development team (Beginner) responded to all of this players issue reports starting 14th March and helped this player on 19th March, 24th March, 3rd April via Discord DM (before this review was posted). However, I don't think the player understands that Beginner is on the development team and he has been speaking to the best possible person. 

This player is no longer experiencing this problem. It was solved when our engineer used remote desktop to simply delete Stormworks and re-download. We had already recommended this at the start and do not know why this didn't work when the user had tried it.

The cause is that this player had modified executable files in their install (ie not the version that we distribute). We don't think there was a pirated version installed (as it makes no sense since player has it on Steam), but we don't know why the files were modified. Corrupt download? Bad hard drive sector? Virus that is self-replicating into other files? Some other unusual environmental issue? We simply don't know and can only guess.

We can see other players suggested this player is a pirate on our bug tracker, and from the player point of view, it isn't clear who is making these comments. We have added a color marking for all developer accounts on the bug tracker so now it is clear who are players and who are developers.

We will look into a ban issue and contact player in person again.

Much love <3,

The Stormworks Developers

review:
This is an amazing game if you want to build a vehicle and see it perform, and then spend hours if not days optimizing the design and playing around with it.

The game is also pretty chill for a "rescue" kind of game. You spend a lot of time in transit between destinations and career mode doesn't really punish you for failing/not taking the missions.

If you loved building cars out of LEGO TECHNIC, this is the game for you.

Great game with huge potential. I love it.

Pros: The game is fun, it's deep, flexible and enjoyable even in a somewhat barebones state.

Cons: The dev team is disorganised and out of touch both with the community and development practices. They are quite happy to break the game and go home for the weekend, leaving everyone unable to play. "But it's early access" isn't an excuse, but they use it constantly. They refused to make use of branches on Steam saying "It makes no sense to make multiple versions available via branches". No sense at all, except we would have been able to play while you clocked out.

The project team is so desperate to advertise the game via youtubers who attract young kids to the game, giving them a completely inaccurate perspective of what the game is and what the community is about. They have no clue  who their target demographic is and end up annoying half of the community with every update.

Feature creep is massive and there is a huge reluctance to work on core parts of the game that are advertised on Steam (multiplayer is all but useless still to this day) but are quite happy to start grand plans about the future.

They do not moderate their communities except via automated bots, which are over-zelous and badly configured, muting people left and right who have legitimate questions yet somehow allowing spammers and trolls right through.

I want to love this game but they try so hard to stop that from happening.
developer_response:
Hi all,

We understand that resolving any issues in the game is very important to players and therefore is very important to us. We are constantly fixing issues in the minor updates, and also release hot-fixes for any critical issues as quickly as we can, often on weekends and bank holidays. 

We appreciate there is still plenty of improvements for us yet to make and we actively continue to work hard on the game. We would never use "Early Access" as an excuse and think developers who do so are wrong.

We review feedback continuously on our issue tracker, we keep track and engage in discussions on the Steam forums, Discord, as well as read your comments and feedback from our weekly Steam announcements. We really enjoy hearing what players have to say about their experiences and ideas.

We think communication and listening to the player community is essential which is one of the reasons we recently ran a poll on our Discord - because we think all players should have an equal and fair say on the development of the game.

We don't do any sponsored content - all the youtube videos you see are organic. We do not have any control over which youtubers cover the game and what content they make, nor should we. We don't think youtubers should have any more say over the development of the game than any other player.

We think conversation on Discord should be mature and clean, which is reflected in the Discord rules (no swearing, abusive language, spamming, etc).

Much love <3,

The Stormworks Developers

Stormworks is a type of game where you can create pretty much anything, and then sink it or crash it. After playing it for over 100 hours, this is how I feel about it. 

[b] The Good [/b]
- Open World. The world is randomly generated, but with the same islands spread out around the map, randomly depending on the seed. 
- Interesting Missions. From rescuing trapped scientists to putting out fires on an oil rig, there is always something to keep you occupied.
- Sinking Physics. You sail into a storm and forget to close a hatch? Your ship will slowly take on water, list, and sink. 
- Building. You can build planes, ships, trains and more. From the smallest sailboat to a tanker ship, or, from a small single-engine jet to the A380. 
- Updates. It's almost weekly that the developer adds something new to the game, or fixes existing bugs. 

[b] The Bad [/b]
- Lag. Now, this is going to happen regardless, but the more complex the vehicle, the more lag you can possibly get. This isn't as much of a flaw, more of an issue of an aging graphics card. 

There really isn't much I can complain about this game. It's definitely unique and extremely enjoyable. I definitely recommend it.

I think this game is incredible. The world building is wonderful. The game is simple and intuitive. You don't have to have a degree at Embery Riddle Aviation School to fly or build a plane. The game has been crafted well, and has potential. The problems are the lack of basic equipment. This is your Modular Engines, Weapons, and many others. A lack of customizable infrastructure causes the game to be a bit bland at some point. An example of this is the Blue Hawker V10 VTOL. The vehicle can do almost anything and makes the point of the game bland. This game is similar to Scrap Mechanic, however it does a lot better. I personally recommend the game, however it does need a ton of improvement. 
Now the Facts:
=PC Requirements=
The PC you use doesn't have to be top of the line, but better than average is preferred for good in-game physics FPS, and also the game isn't very stable when running on a low-end system. (Physics FPS is the actual passage of in game time. Stormworks tries to keep a constant FPS by changing the Physics FPS.) Do note that AMD users may have trouble because the game runs on a single core, meaning AMD's pattern of making single cores less powerful and adding more of them will cause the game to be slow.
=Gameplay=
The gameplay takes time to get used to, and rushes you into the game. There is a tutorial, however it is quite bland. I know this because I have over 1000 hours on Scrap Mechanic, doing logic for jet engines. It still took me 100 hours to fully get used to the building and logic system. There is no story, just a career of repetitive missions. Be ready for being frustrated for the first 50-100 hours. 
=Similarity to other Games=
This game has some similarity to Scrap Mechanic. Scrap Mechanic isn't nearly as good as Stormworks, but it is simpler. If you could, start with Scrap Mechanic to learn some basic principles of building and logic. After some time on Scrap Mechanic, you can move to Stormworks. Otherwise, the game doesn't have any other similar games. 
=Multiplayer= 
The multiplayer is laggy, but it does work. It is enough to make it interesting, and I don't think the game would work at all without it. Do not get this game if you don't want multiplayer. It doesn't work without it.

Absolutely fantastic multiplayer-friendly game! After playing for over 100 hours, I decided it was time to write a review. Stormworks: Build and Rescue is an amazing game which allows you to build to your heart's desire. You can be as creative, or as basic as you want. The principle behind this game is to build, have fun, and learn something new at the same time. This can be in the form of basic logic, Lua, or just learning how to create a complicated shape. 

So, now I have done my main part, I will break down what is so good about this game;

Detail: The detail of the map, creation parts and even the water physics are brilliant. They have clearly put a lot of effort into this game, which is one of the reasons why I have rated this game so well. 

Multiplayer Compatibility: The Multiplayer version of this game is fantastic. They have optimised it really well and have created a great capacity server system for people who want to hang out with large groups of friends.

Survival and Creative damage modes: The Survival mode in this game is great. It allows really realistic damage systems, like collision damage from if you get hit by a fast-moving creation or depth damage, for if you are too close to the ocean floor. Creative is brilliant too, with no limits, you can do whatever you want, no matter how dangerous it is.

Creative and Career game modes: The feature to be able to build to your heart's content, or to have to earn money to be able to build things is amazing. I personally have had a really fun time testing out both modes and I can say, They are fabulous.

The cost: I would say that the cost of this game is a very fair price. The amount of effort for this game to be created has payed off very well, and would urge anyone who is thinking 'this seems expensive for a game like this' to buy it. It is very much worth the money and I would like to say a massive CONGRATULATIONS to the developers of Stormworks: Build and Rescue for creating such a well-thought game.

Overall, I would say to anyone having any doubts over the quality of this game that it will make you extremely happy, for a very long time.

I love this game!

Most of your time is spent creating and fine tuning creations to use in the open world. This will suit you if, like me, you prefer to be creative in a technical way. It's very satisfying to build something and tweak it until it is perfect.

The live gameplay centres around search and rescue scenarios such as rescuing swimmers or stranded tourists. There are also logistical type missions requiring you to move a large container or install equipment on the ocean floor etc. These will require you to create a variety of vehicles to complete.

Now I've pretty much exhausted the missions (~200 hours play time) I've moved on to the creative mode where you can create whatever you like. I'm absolutely loving the freedom to make whatever I can imagine.

There's a bit of a learning curve if you want to take full advantage of the game but well worth it and very satisfying once you learn.

The community associated with this game makes it. There are very active discord and reddit channels dedicated to the game, meaning lots of the advanced features have been well documented by savvy players and there is an abundance of content on the workshop to either learn from or just play with.

Stormworks is not without it's fair share of problems and you have to be mindful it is still early access. Be patient and open to adapting to changes made.

Absolute steal at the price and would recommend to everyone.

Stormworks combines fun a engineering sandbox with a mission and progression system.

The engineering side delves into systems engineering to a greater depth than Space Engineers, and perhaps Stationeers, but feels more intuitive that either of those other games (which both stand well on their own).

I enjoy a good engineering sandbox, but without good incentives to do things, they tend to fall flat for me. Stormworks provides missions that encourage you to solve problems with both engineering and piloting skill. Missions reward you with both money (for buying parts), parts (which you may lack the research for), and research points (to spend one researching new parts in a research tree).

The (optional) research tree benefits the game in that it provides a sense of progress, but also in that it helps avoid feeling overwhelmed with the sheer variety of parts. Typically you'll start by making a basic boat, and move upwards from there. There's a learning curve, but a comfortable one - and that's all part of the fun.

Create new crafts (boats, cars, aeroplanes, helicopters, ...) to solve a problem, or adapt a previous creation to new needs and as your research progresses.

The game itself adheres to a mostly textureless aesthetic, to beautiful effect (somewhat reminiscent of Japoly, but even more beautiful). Stormworks is a great game, in theory and in practice. Love it, the art style is perfect for this sort of game, and it tends to be fairly simple in building. However, since it is early access, it hasn't received a certain quality of life update that, before any major extras, it needs. The builder's copy/paste feature, important for any large-scale blueprint, is unintuitive and slow, as is the camera in both modes. 
It plays great, and honestly I'm impressed with the physics engine for handling whatever I can throw at it. There's plenty of materials to work with and it works beautifully.
However, this game LOVES to show off, and could do with a more simplistic option for building - objects animate their rotations and fly in from offscreen when building with them. Generally, this gets in your way. It can also be difficult to troubleshoot your engine or figure out which way things go, since there usually isn't much of an indicator and many parts show two "inputs".
However, the game looks beautiful, plays beautifully, and has an excellent physics engine, and can only get better from this early stage as time goes on. I definitely recommend it for anyone with a bit of patience and a moderate computer.

I was in a plane, on a plane. The pilot did a fly-by for me at the coordinates and I detached my miniature plane to circle around. I assessed the ocean emergency by flying overhead. I saw a large research boat, stationary. When relaying over the radio to HQ, I recommended a passenger boat to come pick up three passengers and reported that I could only remove one - my plane was only a scout that can float. The rescue boat reported he was only 4 km away before I could even prepare to board my passenger. Right before I was about to take off with my one, a tsunami came out of nowhere and wiped everything out.
I quickly dove to my sinking plane, equipped a diving suit, and grabbed the passenger from my plane. I surfaced, left the passenger floating, and dove to grab a passenger from the bridge of the research boat. The rescue boat was closing in on us now, but there was one passenger left - the engineer. I dove a third time, went into the hallway of the now upside-down research boat, and sealed it off. I realized I was now walking on the ceiling of a sinking boat. I walked on a smooth surface with stairs above me on the ceiling. I ran past the kitchen and then the engines, got the engineer, and ran back to the hallway. I opened the door, and instantly the hallway was flooded. I busted to the surface and the rescue boat helmsman and I started to make our way to the rescue boat with the passengers following. all of the sudden, the game crashed.
This is a common and recurring theme. Whether the game crashes because you sent a chat or because whatever code is broken, it crashes often.

This is a great engineering game, thats fun to play with friends.
If you like tinkering with machines and building stuff, I especially recommend it.
Fluid dynamics and engine simulations are quite involved and you will probably have to build many iterations/test benches to figure stuff out.

Positives: 
 - very free form editing, 
 - detailed piping for engines and electronics 
 - environment (waves, blizzards, fogs) looks actually very pretty despite game's no-texture approach
 - you won't run of things to build for a very very long time (boats, helicopters, rockets, trains, trucks, forklifts, flying jet-turbine powered submarine with giant claws, you name it..)

Current negatives are:
 - editing tool are in some ways extremely tedious and inflexible. Rotating part takes about 6 clicks and usually multiple camera adjustments. 
 - there is no easy way collaborate on design with your friends in real-time
 - while part content is great, mission count is limited and unless you mod, you will be repeating them eventually
 - map, despite being huge, does not contain that many locations (mostly empty ocean)
 - there are numerous glitches in multiplayer (client side prediction failures - random crashes, teleporting boxes, glitches on ladders killing NPC, dedicated server not being visible for some etc)

I love this game. Here are the main reasons:

1. The Physics. I have spent some time on boats and I have to say: the physics of driving boats are very well captured here. It feels very real and this makes it a lot of fun for me, just seeing my creations gracefully ride over the waves (or turn upside down when touching the throttle when I put too much power into tiny boats). The waves change with the weather, getting higher when it gets worse and the further you are from shore. Also you can walk around in/on your vehicle while it is moving and even have mutliple layers of subgrids.

2. I have played a few build-your-own-vehicle games and Stormworks' build mode is the absolute best! It is easy to get into, while having great complexity. You can build boats, submarines, cars, trains, planes, helicopters and anything in between.
Also you have to wire the functional components together to make them work. This is simple to use, but you can make it very complex if you want to, with all the logic gates and whatnot. Player character height is 8 blocks.

3. Not only can you build cool stuff, you actually get to put it to use. I feel like most games that try to do this get one of these two wrong. 
Not this one.
There are 32 missions that put your engineering skills to the test: rescuing people, transporting urgent cargo, towing tankers and putting out fires is a lot of fun. You can build highly specialised vehicles or try to come up with one design to rule them all.


And here are some things to know, before you buy this game:

-You are going to spend a lot of time traveling to missions, rarely up to 5 minutes IF YOUR BOAT SUCKS. You can, though, teleport yourself and your vehicle back to base at anytime in standard mode.

-If you easily get motion sickness and insist on using first-person-view then you will get motionsick from the movement of your boat (which I think is awesome, you actually get seasick xD). Third-person-view is just fine, since it is not affected by roll/pitch.

So, all-in-all, this is the vehicle building game I always wanted! The DEVs are quick to respond to their community and the weekly updades keep coming! Thank you DEVs. Please keep it up!

The reviews on this are deceiving and here's why.

The concept is great. The world is great. There's a lot of great ideas with this game, but it's lacking two major things.

1) A tutorial or some sort of help for beginners. I literally had to go searching out YouTube to find help. And unless I missed something, I had no clue what I was doing until I downloaded some vehicles from the steam workshop. But the starter boat didn't do anything. Am I supposed to build it into a working vehicle? Tooltips, hints, or SOMETHING needs to be added for new people coming into the game.

2) This game runs horrifically. I have a decent system but everything ran in slow motion pretty frequently. I did a Google search on this, and this has been an issue since 2018?! It seems like a block game such as this needs to have more optimization. It's disappointing that a game with low end graphics runs like this.
