I have been playing Stormworks since the early stages of development, so I have been lucky enough to see this game evolve. I even quite enjoyed it myself, having over 100 hours into the game at the time of writing this review. There are limitless options for you to experience in this game, from hardcore permadeath survival to creative mode, and everything in between. You can build your own cars, trucks, boats, submarines, airplanes, helicopters, and really anything you can think of. If you're not as creatively inclined as some people, you can take a look at the Steam Workshop and download any of the community created vehicles for your own use. This game has been getting more and more optimized so you are able to use larger and larger ships, as long as your PC can support it. If you want even more possibilities, you can play with friends on your own private server! You can act as a crew for your ship or you can even bring out multiple ships and have a convoy, and even run the ships into each other. That brings us to another unique aspect to the game; ships can take damage, take on water, and even sink completely. Have a collision with another ship? You better hope you didn't take damage below the water line! Did you find yourself running into shallow rocks? Your time above the water is limited so get to your base as fast as you can. Some ships even have their own lifeboats in the event of an emergency!
So what are you waiting for? Add Stormworks to your cart and start playing this amazing game!

Updated 05/24/2020

Finally.... FINALLY!  The developers have moved this resource-heavy game into the realm of 64 bit, which has been an absolute game changer.  Before this update you could easily get the game to lag even with today's high-end gaming PCs.  Now that the game can utilize everything a PC offers, you can get into some very complex builds without worrying that you won't be able to actually play them.  This game is now one of my top 10.

-------------------------------- Original Review Below --------------------------------

I was on the fence for quite some time about buying this game.  Even with the wonderful "sales" videos there was something that made me a little cautious.  I felt like the game was going to be really cheap and be just another horrible boat simulator with a "build what you want" twist.  Boy, am I ever happy to be proven wrong.

This game (simulator) functions on one premise.  If you can think it, you can build it.  That said, if you just want to make a box and slap a propeller and rudder on it then you can do that too.  The complexity of your designs are entirely up to you.  That said, there is a bit of a catch.  More on that later though.

Starting out you'll find a lot of customization in this game.  You can take it as far as you want, from almost completely realistic with fuel requirements and ship damage to total "my helicopter can work underwater" safety.  You can even mix and match, for example have no fuel requirements yet allow ship damage (or vice versa).  There's even a creative mode.  In addition to the wide open build creativity, these additional world options open up some MAJOR replayability.

In creative mode you have unlimited time to come up with designs, which can use either the "safe" or "realistic" settings depending on what you select when you first create the world.  To build something you simply walk up to an associated workbench and use it.  You'll be taken to the build interface, which is a VERY well thought out place to get creative.  There are too many options to list them all, but some of the features include;

- The ability to mirror your placed blocks on either the X, Y, or Z axis
- Full 360 camera movement around a 3d grid so you can see your build from every angle
- Ability to move the camera anywhere you want (hold alt)
- Ability to zoom in, through objects, to work on interiors
- A well organized parts catalog and the ability to drag parts to a quick-slot type location
- Well labeled tool-tips
- Ability to label components
- Color coding when connecting up the "logic" of the ship (eg. lights to switches)

Ok, so what's the catch I mentioned?  Well, it specifically has to do with the campaign mode of the game.  During this setting you'll be tossed random missions from time to time.  Completing missions gets you money, research points, and occasionally even parts for your crafting.  These missions usually have a requirement that goes along with your available technology.  Oh, did I forget to mention?  Yea, most of the technology is locked behind research.  Thus the research points.  At times you might even be tossed missions that you aren't capable of doing because you decided to follow one tech tree and ignore another.  For example, being required to rescue a submariner trapped in his submarine, when you don't have dive gear yet.  When this happens you have to either forgo the mission, or figure out a creative build to get the job done (like maybe a claw on a winch to grab the sub and bring it to the surface?)

So the catch is this.  You'll be endlessly building, which requires endlessly doing missions to make money and earn research/parts.  Don't think you can come up with one ship design that will do it all either, because it won't happen.  The second you setup a ship to do one thing, it'll need you to do something totally different and thus build another ship, or helicopter, or airplane.  You'll never have a "can do it all" vehicle.  Believe me, I tried.

Ok, so it's not much of a catch... That's actually where the fun is in this game.  Coming up with endless creative designs to "get the job done".  On top of that, the physics engine is rather exceptional.  I've never seen better water dynamics in a video game.  Everything from waves to currents has been very well done, and even how water behaves in storage tanks.  Flood your ship?  It'll sink.  Make a solid ship?  It'll sink.  You have to design your ship with enough air pockets that it'll stay afloat, but not too much so it'll float high and be unstable...  Ballast is also a thing, you can use pumps and actually setup true to life ballast tank systems.  Oh, and did I mention the logic?  Not just connecting switches to lights, but there is also a full array of "And", "Or", "Not" and other logic gates that allow you to literally build whatever you want.

This game is, quite frankly, the best all-around building game I've ever played.  It should be a top rated game once it's optimized and out of early access.  At least that's where it's popularity should reach.  What are you waiting for?  GET IT ALREADY!

I would ABSOLUTELY recommend this game, the possibilities are almost endless in this game. The creations can range from a beautiful ocean-liner, to a futuristic skyscraper! The creativity and the workshop are almost unmatched!

Im going to review this again after more than 300 hrs played. I return to this sim very often as I think it is the best boat sim ever. BUT, there are still some really annoying things with it:

1.- PERFORMANCE: Unless you have a super end state of the art PC, FPS will drop so much when you load a detailed boat thay will make you press ALT+F4 immediatly

2.- The fact that is so difficult to move through the scenery: unable to climb ladders and not falling again and again, cant teleport to an existing vessel ending in having many unreacheable spawned boats, faulty ilumination even at noon (you always need your spot light on), not having workbenches where you really need em, harbours with no ladders if you fall in the water... add a low fps to this and you will have a really annoying experience.

3.- Spawning vehicles system is horrible through these workbenches.  At least in creative mode you should be able to do more things and having more movement freedom.

4.- MAP is huge and even has no detail at all I like it, but: Why do we have this FOW if all sceneries are the same for every player? Is not possible to add a "Remove FOW" or "Discover map" option?

I could be hours writing features that should be improved in this game. I love it, but it needs much more development...

Okay first 5 hours in this have proved to be extremely immersive. I have spent a couple of hours streamlining and perfecting my first passenger boat. After a few re-designs my boat is ready (mostly making it less top heavy and taking into account drag)  I did the initial mission picking up some tools to bring to a power station. Hard days work over i decide to go to sleep. I am awakened to find out a sailor is sick aboard a remote tanker and needs medical treatment. I spring into action, the night is dark and stormy and only the lightening punctuates the blackened skies. I'm 300m away from the tanker but all i see is pitch darkness then, BOOM the sky is saturated by a strike of lightening, I see a large oil tanker with a red distress flare emitting a red glow. I see my target and proceed to board him onto my vessel and get him the treatment he so desperately needs.

Great so far if you like KSP or any other creative problem solving game i can't recommend this enough.

Stormworks is a lovely game, with so much to do! 

It's addictive, in the sense that there's a never ending need to explore the entire map and it's fun, too! You can choose from hundreds, maybe thousands of parts to create ANYTHING and if you aren't too good at that then you can check out community creations.

Plus, the game runs well on pretty much any device, 32 or 64 bit, cheap or expensive so you don't have to break the bank to have a good time. 

The only drawback is the game its self is 32 bit, meaning it has weird core utilisation so you do need a high-end cpu to run big creations without slowing the game down.

Overall, I'd give it a 9.5 out of ten, with lots of room for improvement in that 0.5!

This game could've easily been a simple coast guard simulator with pre-built vehicles that you unlock over time. Slap on a few modification options and you got yourself a game to waste an afternoon on.


That's what I thought it was when i first discovered this game. 


What lies under the hood, however, is the most complex, deep, and robust vehicle creation system I have ever experienced. 


I'm 93 hours in, and i'm just scratching the surface of what's possible in this game. 


This is what some people made in the game from scratch:

1.) a remote controlled drone with a built in camera transmitting the feed to a monitor. 
2.) A helicopter pad on a ship that is fully retractable, and can be controlled remotely by the helicopter
3.) Radios that can send messages back and forth to other players in the game. The messages show up on in-game monitors, and can be transmitted using in-game keypads
4.) A windmill that automatically directs itself against the wind, thus producing energy for your creations. 
5.) A giant vessel with a runway that can fly in the sky, similar to the helicarrier from the avengers. 


Robotic hinges/pivots, lua prgramming, composite data, electric/mechanical components, microprocessors, etc. This game gives you a set of tools, and you can utilize them to make pretty much anything you want.

This is a game I've always wanted to play.  Ever since I was a kid I wanted a game where you could build any machine you wanted.  But there's never been a game like that.  Games like Kerbal Space Program, Simple Planes and Brick Rigs get close, but (with the exception of KSP) they never got their hooks into me.  

Stormworks however has me hooked like no other game.  The level of freedom that you have to make what ever you want is outstanding.  Wanna make a amphibious Tank?  Go for it.  Jet Powered Train that can go 600mph?  Sure.  A flyable Submarine?  Uhhhh I'm working on it (It sinks fine, just doesn't... un-sink).

I highly recommend starting the game with advanced mechanics off until you get a hang of building and general controls first, but the moment you're confident enough with the game turn on Advanced mechanics. It will be frustrating for the first few hours, but when you finally get that machine that you've been working for ages it's one of the most rewarding feelings I've ever had with a game.

Kerbal Space Program with a search and rescue component - I highly recommend Stormworks even in it's early access form. The ability to not only create all manner of air, sea, and land vehicles but then see how they stack up to generated missions in world is fantastic. The editor is a bit daunting at first but with some practice you'll find that it is well suited to building and provides a good balance between gameplay and realism. I can't wait to see what the Devs continue to do.

Some notes of caution - it is framerate intensive, mainly due to the physics, and there are still some bugs in world, which the Devs warn about with a message in the lower left corner of your screen.

If I were you, I would get it!

Come for excessively deep engineering, stay for the joy of building the craft of your dreams. First thing i built was a tilt-rotor heavy lifting chopper. It was pretty and awesome and a culmination of my first 50 hours of gameplay and learning.

Pros:
- Deep mechanics imitating real life engineering
- Fun when using the craft, stimulating when building the craft
- Solid campaign progression
- Weather, wind and waves makes missions interesting and varied.
- Extremely robust collision system; craft can carry other objects, such as cargo at high speed
Cons:
- Lacking wiki and poor tooltips in-game requires you to search for tutorials in the internet for most things if you want to save time.

I wish Steam offered a 5 star system, I would give a 3.5 star rating.  This game is awesome when it's not driving you crazy with bugs.  It's and Alpha so my "No" recommendation is for now.  If you don't mind putting hours into creating a vehicle, run that vehicle for hours then have some random bug break it, then absolutely play this game now.  The technical detail in vehicle builds is amazing, testing seasoned technicians with building their own logic controllers etc.   However these builds take a lot of hours to complete.  I have had two ships that I built, and they really performed well that have broke with no easy fix now.  The first I added a stand alone custom tank to, not integrated with the ships fuel system.  The second I change my medium size fuel tanks out for large tanks.  In both cases the ship simply will not start.  I have checked and checked all connections / controls etc on both ships for too many hours now.  There in lies my reasoning for the "No" rating.  

Secondly, game play bugs are plenty at this stage in development too.  Tanking liquids for money is a prime example.  Build a tanker and take it out for a few runs, you'll soon be frustrated.  Your first run will work without a hitch but the second you'll have a hard time offloading, pumps have to be turned on and off to offload, and the sell point leaves a miniscule amount in your tank that you can't pump out.  This means you're now stuck with only carrying the last fluid type in your tanks as the sell points won't say put crude oil in when you have .06 diesel in there.  The only workaround at the moment is to take the tanker back to the shop despawn and respawn after your first run.  Again, here in is my reasoning for the "No" rating.  Wait until the game is ready for prime time and I think you'll save yourself some frustration.

Cannot believe that this game went under my radar for so long. Its really great for creating exciting vehicles. The generel sea rescue setting is very interresting and the mission system gives you a purpose for creating different vehicles. Even in this early access stage it contains a ton of possibilities. It takes some time to learn the mechanics, but there are many good tutorials on the internet. The game is in active development and there are many great creations ready to be used in the workshop.

If you enjoy a creative sandbox and the ability to make your own vehicle air/land/sea this is for you.  Great game you put together!

Awesome, you know why? It is kind of Minecraft meets SpaceEngineers meets Kerbal Space Progrram. Okay, the physics engine of KSP is probably better, and SE looks better, but this game makes you feel like you want to build the biggest baddest flying submarine that can climb mountains. Yes it is challenging at first, it is technical, but after playing alongside with some youtube tutorials you start to get the feel of the possibilities and the best thing is; you have a goal; there are missions. I admit that with only 6 hours on the clock, MC, SE and KSP are hard comparison especially given the development that have gone into these games. But I think StormWorks has a shot if they keep developing this game, the be added in the line next to KSP, SE (and in some sense MC as well). I recommend you try this game together with a friend

Very fun and open in what you can make and operate. The Steam workshop allows you to download and drive any imaginable thing. There are some very cool and impressive creations to find. I would highly recommend you find go on youtube and watch videos of peoples creations in action. Building has a learning curve but is simple relative to the things you can create. It's open world allows for hours of just messing around like in GTA or minecraft. The game isn't stunning but still has smooth and comfortable graphics. Lastly, the devs and community are very active and responsive. I would recommend this game to almost anyone.

Be warned, this isn't a simple game. The learning curve at the beginning is very steep and you'll either love the game or hate it. There are a vast number of great tutorial videos on Youtube but it feels like the game developers have pulled up a bit short not including any sort of building tutorial in the game. 

I've had a great time with the game so far. I wouldn't know what else to compare it to, it's some sort of mix of Minecraft, No Man's Sky, GMod and a few others. You're given an objective and that's it. How you solve it is completely up to you. The missions so far have been interesting and varied, they open up as you unlock further islands within the game and your selection of parts increases. 

Games that have the freedom of Stormworks but still manage to provide the player with a satisfying progression arc and interesting objectives are really rare. Stormworks has got the balance perfect for me.

k

After the time I spent in the game. I am frustrated.

I moved from boats to air vehicles as the focus of my designs and I feel unrewarded in both categories.
There is nor gliding in this game, hence the physics for airplanes are inherently broken and most of the lift essentially comes from an engines that constantly overheating without the bugged 1x3 custom water tank. 

I wanted to make racing style airplanes, but the components that you need to make them flyable are big and destroy beautiful designs that work in the real world. Yet the way Physics works in this game, shows that your fun design that has a real life influence won't take off.

To have all of the fun in this game, you will have to make: 
- A ships that has to do everything. Bigger ships tank the FPS.
- A plane with jet engines, or a normal engine that is full throttle all of the time.
- A helicopter, which is the only clear way to complete most of the campaign missions.

Making any vehicle that is fun is out of the question, and I hope that you're the type of person that likes to spend 2 full days on one vehicle design, then spend the next 40 minutes floating or flying around in a broken physics engine across a vague and uninteresting landscape.

There is a level of the community that wants the physics fixed. Yet, the developers seem to be working on the campaign that has impossible mission time constraints.

If you are willing to put in the hard yards on a virtual engineering degree, you will love this game.
If you are looking for something that isn't a full time job, look elsewhere.

Amazing building system and not only that but I get a real sense of adventure when going out and exploring. My advice to anyone that would like to play the survival is first to play with automatic refueling and NPC and player damage off, as well as vehicle damage off. This will give you chance to learn the building system without having to worry about other things that could retract from the overall experience. fun

Simply fantastic.

TL;DR; Build vehicles, complete missions, has PVP/COOP multiplayer. Easy to learn, difficult to master. Superb complexity, nice UI. It's EA, has rough edges but gets regular updates clearly made with love from the devs.

 The premise of the game is that you are Search And Rescue (SAR), but you don't have any vehicles or tools - you have to build them. To borrow the words of the Youtuber Squirrel - "this game gives you a reason to build things." However, the "storm" in Stormworks means that sea is not your friend. There's fog, wind, rain, big waves, it's cold, sharks, etc. Your vehicle needs to survive if you're going to survive.

Please take a look at the workshop for a peek at what people have built. It's astonishing - and those vehicles aren't just pretty. They have outstanding complexity. For technical folks, there's an oustanding set of logic pieces to program fascinating machines. There's radar, lidar, lasers (not the scifi kind), sonar, etc.

The bad news? It's Early Access. There's rough edges. The mission system is being worked on to create more flavor and spice. The fidelty of some things like the characters needs some love. There's no tutorials - this bites because if you start with advanced difficulty your going to get stuck on some aspect that needs more self-explanation. Youtubers like Squrrel, MrNJersey and Stealth17 have great tutorials. The Discord community offers some help, and the devs post a lot. So - all of that offers some solace. 

At $22.79CAD at time of writing I think is a very fair price for the current state of the game on premise that the game continues to get the care and attention it's recieved from its developers so far. Buy it now.

I am absolutely addicted to this game. There's too much in it to put in one review, but if you like designing/building vehicles of any kind, then this goes into stupendous detail. You shape your vehicles with a block system like lego, build your drivetrain, connecting all the working parts together, wire up your electrics and program your controls. You can even program on board computer systems for your creations in lua, or their onboard visual language which is incredibly easy to use. I know there's about a million more things I have in my head to build in this game, so I'm gonna get to it.
Not much to do at the moment, but fun to test out cool vehicles and do missions. Has a ton of potential.

there are 2 sides to the game:
1: building-This part of the game is thriving with an active community creating some amazing vehicles. The developers are always adding and updating the components available.  
2: Missions-You will see a lot of people unhappy with the level of missions in the game at present and while I agree this is an area that, as I understand it, will become a focus once the build and world is complete.

The "advanced" mode is really the only mode worth using as it is the most supported by other players and the developers. There is a steep learning curve to learn how to build in this mode if you have never used such a system. there is a vast network of support available on the Discord and steam discussion.

 Would highly recommend

Though similar to other games like [i]Kerbal Space Program, Space Engineers[/i] and some aspects of [i]Factorio[/i], what this game does very well from the outset is to give you a purpose for creating these vehicles in the first place.  As part of an air, sea rescue organisation, you need the right vehicles and tools for the job hence the design.  

I'm not saying these other games gave no goal but rather STORMWORKS provides more of an immediate motivation for certain things.   Need to transport that relief worker to that base on the other side of the map but running out of fuel?  Time to learn about fuel efficiency!  In this respect its quite like Kerbal Space Program.

The depth of the game is outstanding, I was blown away by the way components are wired up both electrically and data channel-wise and then again when I discovered the logic/circuit board stuff.  The fact that some clever people have made auto-pilots for helicopters is a testament to the potential and freedom of this game.

This game is not only educational but also incredibly addictive and fun.  Whilst Factorio taught me all about logistic efficiency and circuit networks, STORMWORKS teaches me engine RPM, torque, fuel efficiency and how to safe souls at sea.

Buy it now!

[b]EDIT:[/b]  Google the creations by [b]MrNJersey[/b], he is an absolute genius

Well.. you will like this game if you enjoy mathematics, (very unrealistic) physics and building complex engines all by yourself without any help.

You will NOT enjoy this game if you like a tutorial that explains you even just the basics of how the game works, what to do or how to build your a simple engine.
There is zero tutorial, guide or even a hint on how engines work in the game, how to use the different parts, what they actually do, and so on.

Thus you spend most of your time trying to figure things out by trial and error, and by reading through mostly outdated and unhelpful guides.
Oh did I mention you need to know actual programming to build more complex vehicles? Yeah, I wish I had known all of that before I bought this.


You really have to be a hardcore fan of all these things, because the game itself is really empty and outside the missions there isn't anything to see or do.

To be honest, if I want to learn complex engine mechanics, I will just learn the stuff in real life instead = not having to worry about wonky physics that change with every bigger update.

My god. If you're buying this for singleplayer, then it's ok. If you want to play it with your friends in Multiplayer, stay far, far away from this. 

I should clarify that i have some experience with this because i'm an admin on a dedicated multiplayer server.
First of all, the crashes. Oh dear god, the crashes. It doesn't crash very often in singleplayer, but in multiplayer, constant crashes. I literally do mean CONSTANT. 

You send a chat message and the game doesn't like it? Crash. You spawn a vehicle in a workbench and the game just doesn't like you? Freeze or crash. You adjust a keypad? Crash. You look at this buggy pile of dogshit the wrong way? Server crash. Literally anything happens? Crash. You're doing something cool? Crash, plus many, many more i haven't named.


But don't take it from me. This is what the owner of the server i'm on said about this's game's crashing:
"It makes my pp soft"
"I just don't like that the server can be 50 out of 60 fps, a few good vehicles, and the game still crashes"
 
At the time of writing this review, i only played for a few hours, and i must have crashed a minimum of 10 times.

I talked with someone today. They said that they wouldn't listen to him about the crashes because it didn't make a crash log. He also said someone named "Ra Ra Rasputin" was being quite rude.
They recently released an update claiming they "Fixed" the blank message crash. Their "Fix" was not showing the blank message in chat. It doesn't stop you from crashing AT ALL. It literally just doesn't show the blank message that indicates the crash.

The optimization is dog shit. The owner of the server i'm an admin on said that even when the FPS is 10 on the server, the CPU usage never goes above 17%. It never uses more than 3GB of the 12GB RAM at 3200 MHz.
Stormworks devs, I don't want "First person ropes" or custom winches. I want your goddamn game to be tolerable in Multiplayer. People are always saying "Oh it's just an early access game, there are going to be bugs" This is Bethesda level shit. They didn't get a pass when they released the FO76 beta, why should these devs?

I hate to be that guy, but releasing a feature like this, even in early access, is fucking bonkers.

Stop being dumbasses and stop adding more shit that can cause bugs, and fix the shit that's already broken!

Alright after 60 hours i think i am ready to make a review of this game. First of all this is a really fun and an addictive game, it definetly needs some fixes. The game at it's current state is stable and playable but you do need a good system to run it smoothly. However this will probably change in the future since its not that optimized at its current state. The game is really smooth and fun in single player mode.
Now, multiplayer is a different gameplay experience. Its fun but really unstable, when playing with friends the game is very unstable massive input lag spikes and the game slows down beacuse its really not that optimized for multiplayer especially for big creations. However i still love playing in single player mode.
The game has a slight learning curve but once you get the hang of it its really easy to create a vehicle.
The map is really huge and there is wildlife which is nice. The game's graphics are really nice even though there's very low amount of textures in the game. But i think its perfect for a polygon based game. There is no round shapes in the game so no curves, only wedges. The water is well animated. Which reminds me the weather settings are really well done. There's even a tsunami spawn option which is really fun to ride with a boat however its really not that tall they need to change that. There's even a wind option where you can set the strength of its drag, and the waves on the water get alot bigger and rough. You can also set the rain strength. Its really fun to be on a boat when there is a thunder and a tsunami is coming it really makes the game come to life also the sound effects are really good!
That's about it for my final rating i'd give it a 8/10 beacuse of the bugs and crashes and it needs more content.

This game is incredible in my personal opinion. It's very addicting! You can explore the map to find bigger places for bigger boats and autos! And if you don't like to build or feel in the mood you can go over to the Steam Workshop to find autos that people have made and posted for you! Maybe not for you specifically but for Stormworks and for like the 15th time I do recommend this game to anybody really. Especially people who like automobiles. My opinion: (The physics are insane! 10/10! Hands down my favorite game.)And it's multiplayer so you can enjoy the game with friends!
yes.

Absolutely love the game.  It does have a somewhat steep learning curve when trying to make vehicles that perform efficiently but, once I mastered the fundamentals, the enjoyment level rapidly increased.  The missions and campaign give you purpose to your builds, unlike some of the other sandbox-only building games out there.  Although the missions can get a little repetitive at times, I use the opportunity to improve on my builds or try different approaches.  Multiplayer just makes the game even more fun to play, although there are still some bugs to be worked out in multiplayer mode.  All in all, I would highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys building / engineering / programming.

This game is awesome, as Todd Howard always says, "it just works" the vehicles you create seem to always behave the way youd expect them to, in a good way of course. Building vehicles is super fun and satisfying especially when you get every little detail down and every feature of that vehicle working perfectly, There is so many things you can build and thats really where most of the fun comes in for me at least. the missions are repetitive and arent very rewarding but the developers are working on making them more unique and randomly generated which is nice. I wish I could give something between a "Recommended" and "Not Recommended" but leans more towards Recommended. The concept, gameplay, almost everything is absolutely great. The concept of being a coastguard and being able to build anything, I mean ANYTHING is something I've never seen before. Onto the gameplay, it's amazing as well. As I said, you are able to build anything you want, if you have the skills that is. Every component, every block, every mechanics, has their own different functions that completes each other. Want to build a speedboat? Sure. Spaceship? Go ahead. An exact scale replica of Battleship Yamato with fully functional cannons and torpedoes? Say no more. The possibility is endless. The only limit is your skills and imagination.

Now into deeper details and technical stuff. The graphics and art style is absolutely great and works together very well. The flat-color low poly style mixed with soft lighting is something very lovely to look at. Not to mention dynamic weather and daylight cycle which is a nice feature. The physics are great, but aircraft physics could've gotten some more realism put into it. Multiplayer isn't that great, it's pretty unstable, lags often, and even makes the game crash pretty often (and is really annoying). But good on the devs that are still working on it. The performance isn't low-end friendly, it could've been more optimized, in fact. But I guess it's quite understandable, as the game is still going on early access. I wouldn't recommend running it on low-end PCs though.

So, do I recommend this game? Yes. Score? 8.5/10. Should you try it? Yes. Definitely. It's worth the money you're paying.

ORIGINAL 
~500 hours

What a fantastic game. I'm going to try to avoid using too many superlatives in this review, but the fact that I have to do so should be indicative of its value.  Only a week or two before I became aware of Stormworks, I was musing to myself that some sort of coast guard/salvage operation game set at sea would be great fun; this game is so much more than that already. With the development team releasing nearly weekly minor updates this is the best value for money I have had in a game for a long time. Well done to the devs and thanks to the vibrant community! Do yourself a favour and buy this game.

UPDATE

As 3000 hours approach, and my time in this game is now double that of a previous record holder (KSP) I thought I ought to write once again about how this game is the best game ever made.

If you like the idea of a coast guard style game where you have to brave the elements to rescue those in need, this is the game for you. If you prefer building vehicles, solving complex mechanical, logical, and logistical problems; this is the game for you. If what you really want to do is build your base like you used to do in Minecraft, but with moving parts and monitors and comparatively high resolution, this is the game for you.

In short, it can be whatever you want it be (as long as what you want it to be isn't a combat simulator). Considering I passed the one cent per hour mark 700 hours ago, if you like any of the above you should get similarly mind-boggling value out of what is, I repeat, the best game ever made.

Stormworks build and rescue is a lot of fun, but its also mind numbingly boring.

How is this game both fun and boring? building things is fun, seeing if what you built works is rewording, then bashing it agents tsunamis and megalodons is always a treat. you will find yourself spending hours in creative and if your really looking for a building game for primarily for ships I highly recommend this.
How is this boring it sounds like a blast right? Its when you get to the traveling, going anywhere takes forever thats not bad I like an adventure that takes some time but based on how powerful your ship is and the layout of the world's seed it can take around 30 minutes to an hour through empty boring ocean to get anywhere meaningful.

Saying the map is big is an under statement  

You made it to the main Donkk island and you want to get to the Arctic? Your looking at a three and half hour journey by train. ships are a little slower then trains. planes are the fastest mode of transportation in the game but are highly finicky. you can also build cars but unless your on Donkk Island you have very little reason to use them anywhere else.

What do you get for your long journey at sea when you finally reach a place like the Arctic or the isles of Donkk? not a crazy lot most of the islands you'll find are quite flat and barren unless its a terminal. 
The main island of Donkk has two terminals one is a little airport and the other is a train shipping yard with a dock for large ships the rest of the island though is nearly completely empty other then the two VERY small villages one of which is unnamed and compared to the rest of the island are very decorated and lively. 

The islands are so bare they don't even have trees other then for the rare big dead oak tree on about two or three small islands. the reason I feel this is so important is the fact that after you've been at sea for say an hour and then you see an island you have no incentive to dock and explore because you don't feel like you arrived anywhere.

The main con of this game is the fact it feels so empty outside of the building and thats sad because the building is this game's best feature and it does it really well but whats the point of building a massive ship if you have nowhere to go.

 here is a list of things I'd like to see for the future that I feel would help with the empty world problem

1. Adding trees to the islands. "Update! This has been added!"

2.Adding a full fledged town with a terminal meant for cars and missions based around the town, "Update! this has been kinda added but I feel like it can be improved on"

3.Adding a world option for NPC controlled ships to freely roam the seas, I know that not every computer could handle two or three large ships being near by thats why I feel this would work best as a option when creating new worlds. the option to have other ships at sea with you would make the ocean less empty and would make traveling for long periods of time more enjoyable.

4 and 5 are more for fun.

4.adding Flare Guns, "Update! This has been added!"

5.add some civilian style clothes and hairstyles. my lady needs a floppy hat, a sundress, and a new pair of heals if she has ANY chance of putting out that oil fire!


If you made it to the end I thank you for reading.

I cannot possibly understand why the freaking UI freezes & enters slow-mo when the MP session is unstable... How did you make it function this way? At least make it laggy but still usable? (I play this with my friend overseas. My friend said it worked perfectly well with his domestic friends, but come on!)

Content-wise this is a no-brainer. However, I would never enjoy this alone, and the horrible MP performance is really disappointing me and my friend. It's been a pure suffering.

Still, RECOMMENDED if you are looking for MP gameplay and have confidence in you & your friends' p2p connections.



Look, I still wish to enjoy this game. Plz at least don't freeze the game in the building workshop under unstable connections? Is that too much?

*Literally just saw the MP update, going to try it later today, fck yeah! (Not out yet, will see)

*The update is a disappointment. Instead of the whole game slowing down, now the game only slows the results of your actions. It still takes me literally two minutes to open the cabin door; instead of the door slowly opening for a long while, now it takes a long while until the door suddenly decides to swing open. I was also teleported back to bed from the hanger once, 2 minutes after I tried to go to bed and failing. My friend saw my character model running while lying on the bed. (Japan-China, private dedicated server with a direct lag of 80ms. Yet the in-game lag still managed to reach over 2 minutes. I and my friend can enjoy DCS from the same server without any problem, wth)

*After a night it got better; we have no idea what was going on. Anyway, it has become a much better game imo. Looking forward to further improvements! (Feb 26, 2020)

I have to say, I was impressed when I first got this game. I immediately jumped on the workbench and created a boat.

Stormworks is a weird mix of awesome and horrible. Sometimes when I play it, I'm having a great time driving a small rescue vessel or flying a helicopter. Other times the game is extremely slow or just crashes out of nowhere.

In this game, you build vehicles to accomplish a task or just explore the ocean. Or you play the same way I do and just download the top-rated vehicles on the Workshop, only to find out the boat was buildt in 2018 and no longer works as it should, and snaps in half and sinks.

With its huge open world and near infinitely generating world, it's a blast to explore until you realize the islands are being copied over and over again. Then you see a huge fin in the background, only to have your cruise ship capsize and your spirit crushed, as you get banished to the desktop.

That's my biggest problem with this game. It's the most unstable game I've ever played. While stable when using smaller creations, the bigger stuff will make your game play in slow-motion, or just crash to desktop the second it loads. That or it will crash out of nowhere while you're sailing in your small fishing trawler.

Now, this game is still very much early access, so it still has some problems to work out. Other than the less-than rare crashes to desktop, Stormworks is a great game with a very active Workshop, and some incredible creators. I would go as far as to say the Workshop creations are what makes this game. Creations like huge cruise ships, submarine aircraft carriers and incredible vtol aircraft are what almost makes all the crashes worth it. Almost.

Overall, Stormworks is a great game with a lot to explore, and even more to explore in the Workshop. Add the crashes, and the game drops to being a good game. Buy it if you are interested in boats, the ocean, or are interested in the Workshop creations. Just make sure your PC can handle it.

You start this game thinking it's going to be simple or even easy. Later, you find yourself drawing systems and blueprints for your ships, researching real ships, reading ship blueprints to find dimensions for your ship, programming micro-controllers to automate ship functions. All while both learning about ship design and use, and having fun making your own.

A truly unique experience, and I cannot wait to watch its progression out of Early Access!

This game is not perfect by any stretch of the imagination.  In fact, I would hesitate to call it a game at all in its current state.  The fun of Stormworks right now lies solely in its building mechanics.  How fast can you make a boat?  Can you even make a helicopter that can fly?  Building your own vehicles in a semi-realistic physics environment is a blast—especially for people who were obsessed with titles like Kerbal Space Program (like I was).  

Unlike Kerbal, in its current state Stormworks gameplay is severely lacking.  One should consider the missions to merely be tests for the capabilities of the vehicles you build.  There is no real story or motivating factors other than research.  ALL of the fun lies in constantly building and refining/tailoring your vehicles to perform specific tasks.
Advanced mode is the only way to go to really enjoy this in its current state.  The feeling of dumping 10+ hours into a helicopter build after dozens of rounds of test flights, and then finally accomplishing a mission with it is rivaled only by the feeling in Kerbal Space Program when you finally successfully land on the Mun.  The game is hard and takes many hours of trial and error, YouTubing, and reading to get your vehicles in good working order—but man do you feel great when it all comes together.

This game is simply fantastic. 

For a EA game it's well fleshed out and contains very few bugs. 

My only gripe is that the barrier to entry is steep, given the shear complexity of of the building tools (i.e you can build anything from trains to speed boats to cruise liners) and given the detailed engine functionality (especially in advance mode) the initial few hours are a nightmare - at time of writing i'm C.20 hours in and have only just got a fully functioning ship designed, trailed and built - I fully accept that a tutorial would not cover all areas so would suggest some sort of in game encyclopedia, this would replace the miriad of youtube and forum posts that need be viewed to grasp some of the concepts. 

This all being said the complexity is required and the game (once understood) is ace - 9/10 will easily provide 100+ hours entertainment.

1) If you play singleplayer only: buy this game now and it'll be the best money you ever invested into a sandboxy/creative game and ignore everything below. Really, if you are only interested in single player, buy this game right now!!

2) If you're interested in multiplayer, even on a small scale, do not buy this game. It's absolutely horrible in multiplayer. As a matter of fact, as they released updates for multiplayer, the game has gotten worse. While overall performance went up, they introduced gamebreaking glitches of the sort that show you, that they don't really playtest their own releases.

The developers of this game do not understand that multiplayer, at the very least 4 player coop, is vital for the game's longevity. Instead, they celebrate themselves constantly by releasing updates that they hype up to solve problems but then it turns out that those updates are in fact making things worse.

I will revise this update if they ever get their shit together and actually write netcode that's worth a damn.

I thought Stormworks would be a coastguard sim with a few light building and creative mechanics thrown in.  I couldn't have been more wrong.  It's actually the greatest, most detailed model building game that's ever existed.

     Whether we're talking aesthetics or engineering, the scale and depth of Stormworks is absolutely incredible.  At half the size of the smallest block in Space Engineers, Stormworks allows you to build small.  Of course you can build huge ships, planes, cars, submarines, helicopters, and even trains, but you can fill them with a level of aesthetic detail that's impossible in any other building game.

     That's not where it ends though.  The actual engineering in Stormworks puts Space "Engineers" to shame, and I love Space Engineers, and I mean 3,000 hours love it.  Where most games would give you an engine or power block and call it a day, Stormworks allows you to create your own cooling systems, electrical systems, fuel systems, air intakes, gearboxes, clutches, all with a nice sprinkling of options and sliders to adjust them to your preferences.

     But it doesn't end there... Hooking these components together is just the beginning.  Stormworks gives you the option to make these systems do EXACTLY what you want with a powerful and intuitive logic editor or Lua programming.  Want to add interior lights that come on when you open the door to your car?  Want a door chime?  Do you want a climate control system that you've designed yourself?  Want a crane to deploy your lifeboat if your ship starts to sink?  The creative options in this game are endless.  Truly endless.  Like I said, the depth of this game is like nothing else.  There is almost nothing you can't build, almost nothing you can't do in this game.

     Oh, and there are also cameras.  And monitors that display video.  In real time.  You can remotely control things and talk to your friends on the radio that you've built yourself.  I could write a novel about how much I love this game, but you should really play it for yourself.

     Long story short, if you're looking for the best building game on Steam or anywhere, or if you just want a game that allows you to sail beautifully detailed ships and drive interesting vehicles, you've found it.  Buy it right now.  Tell someone else to buy it right now.  Saying I can't recommend Stormworks enough is underselling it, and that's the truth.  Of all the games I own and play, I've only ever written a review for one:  Space Engineers.  It's an amazing game.  I love it dearly, and Stormworks absolutely blows it away.

[h1] Overview [/h1]
Overall, Stormworks is a game with a lot of potential. It is still in development, which is very much noticable when playing the game, but I am enjoying the game when I play it nonetheless - especially the creative part, designing not only boats, but planes, cars, helicopters or new, crazy designs no one thought of before. The building system is in general well made and you have a lot of creative freedom. 

[h1] Missions/Survival Gameplay [/h1]
The missions in Stormworks do leave a bit to be desired. The NPC's are very barebones, they are mostly just dummies that can at most follow you around when asked to. The missions system [i] is [/i] being remade however, so we will see what evolves into. Still, they are not horrible, but I feel like there is a lot more potential here! Right now, I mostly just make designs in creative and I get the impression that this is the case for most players.
   I am a volontary sea rescuer in Sweden (SSRS, google it if you want to see what it is) and from that perspective it is worth noting that the missions are semi-realistic at best. The most common thing we do is to go out to people who are stranded with engine troubles and whatnot, meaning we have to tow them back to the dock where they can look over their boat. Right now, there is no realistic way of towing crafts. If it doesn't have a connector that lets you connect the ship securely, you need to rely on silly magnets that can easily get lose. And hey, getting it on there in the first place is a challenge in its own. They tend to end up in the water, sinking down to the bottom of the ocean. It doesn't feel complete and it doesn't feel realistic.

[h1] Creative/Ship Building [/h1]
To start off here, we need to get something clear. There are two modes in which you can design your ships and play in: the standard, easy one where you can simply place an engine and it just works. Then, there is the "advanced mode", which in my opinion is the one you should be playing, but it is also, understandably, quite a bit harder. You may need to spend a substantial amount of time to get things to work as you want them to, especially in the beginning. You should be able to put together some basic stuff after watching some youtube tutorials though, and setting up an engine and using the "composite" nodes and other things to set up control panels and advanced ship systems will become fairly second nature when you have played around a bit with it.
   My favourite part about Stormworks is the possibilties it offers - the creative freedom in the building system. You can script, make remote controlled drones, set up advanced control panels, radars, GPS systems, autopilots, autohovering and so much more. Pretty much anything you can imagine, you can also create if you put in the time for it.

[h1] Performance [/h1]
The topic of performance is always a fairly important one in games, and even more so in sandbox games where you build large, physics based creations. Stormworks is a 32-bit game, which does not help. I personally don't have much issues, but my hardware consists of a 2080 and an i7 9700K and so on... I never experience any lag with the highest settings while doing sensible things, but I know a lot of people do even with lower settings - physics calculations on this scale needs some beefy hardware and good optimization. 32-bit isn't exactly helping here.

[h1] Graphics [/h1]
Having already talked about the performance of the game, it is only right we talk a bit about the actual looks of the game. I must admin, I am a bit split here. Stormworks can look good. I love the way the ocean looks and the art style overall looks decent. Sometimes, the graphics are a bit too simple for my taste though. It is not a game because it is beautiful, because it rarely really is. I wouldn't say, on the other hand, that the graphics are a turn-off in any way either - the overall looks of the game are still ok. Ok is a pretty good word the describe the graphics of this game to be honest. Ok.

[h1] The Future of Stormworks [/h1]
I wanted to bring up the topic of what the future might bring for Stormworks and the developers behind it. First off, I want to say that the developers are making a fantastic job of constantly pushing updates. They are a small team, but yet they manage to release something almost every week, in addition to more major updates every once in a while. They are good at listening to the community and it is clear that they are passionate about the game. They are not perfect, but they want to bring something unique to the table. At least in my book, they are certainly succeding on that point.
   Multiplayer was announced to be the focus of the next major update, which I am glad to see. The performance in multiplayer right now is horrible. If one player has a slow PC that cannot cope with the calculations, the simulation speed is slower for everyone connected. This will change. Personally, I am hoping for the possibility of dedicated servers that could be hosted by the community.

[h1] Should you buy it? [/h1]
Do you want a game to sink into on a saturday evening with some good music in your ears to build that cool boat you saw at the dock yesterday? Or maybe make that nice plane design you always wanted to make a reality somehow real. Stormworks is unique and it is unique in a good way. I like it. If you're like me and like to build stuff, I'm pretty sure you will too. Besides, it's not that expensive. Pick it up and see for yourself! Just remember not to give up from the beginning, it may seem a bit daunting to you if you are not used to these kinds of games. Once you get into making the more advanced stuff, it's a hell of a lot of fun though!

If you read this far, thank you! I certainly hope I helped you out a bit in deciding whether to get into the rather addictive world of Stormworks.

My current computer is nothing of the gaming sort so I cannot experience the full game until my new one arrives, will update my review once it does.

Okay so this game honestly is everything I've looked for, its got custom building where you decide how complicated or simple your craft shall be, the Simple mode is very useful for beginners, when later on you can go to Advanced which is where the real fun happens.

The overall physics of the game are very satisfying, and the different features like flares, cameras, open up unlimited possibilities, I saw someone make a cockpit with no windows, instead he used cameras and screens. 

This game lets you create any type vehicle, submarine, boat, jet, shield helicarrier, you name it, its possible.

I no longer dis like anything about this game, the only issue was multiplayer but they've heavily improved it, overall worth the damn money, but make sure to get some friends on board, everything gets a lot better with a mate to come with you. 

Oh and the career mode is very good, its not too easy, but its not too hard as well. You have to complete rescue or service missions with your own craft to make money and unlock more components, allowing for a very exciting gameplay experience, and roleplay is a lot of fun in this game too

I won't say too much more, you experience it for yourself, but trust me, if you're into a space engineers / kerbal space program on land, this game will be perfect, but for anyone not into those games, its still worth a try. One of my better games in my library!

I initially disliked this game for it's lack of tutorials and complex mechanics, but now that I've learned and improved the game's true nature revealed itself to me as being boringly boring.

see, I tend to gravitate towards career modes in kerbal space program and space engineers because they're more fun when you have a goal and something to (literally) build towards. but stormworks's campaign missions are... well... absolutely awful and boring. spend 15 minutes holding down the W key with a coin or something before getting to the island, spending longer than necessary loading the sick-patient/stranded-tourists onto the boat before spending another 20 minutes delivering them to their destination. I'm sure there's more to the missions than this but the early part of the game is consumed by this boring, samey garbage and so it doesn't really grip me.

"Despite the bugs I really like this game, it's fun."--> (Me in June of 2019 only 6 hours played) Now I have had more experience in Stormworks' nature playing for as long as 6...HUNDRED and 90 hours.

 I have experienced lots of game crashes (probably because of either my computer, early access reasons, or maybe even both) that I have gotten used to appreciating them a bit more and just think it's like "daily lag."

 Besides the game crashes, the stuff you can do in this game is amazing. For example, an immense thank you to GERUNIMO for building his "Calypso" owned by the legendary Cousteau, GERUNIMO probably put the most complicated engine startup procedure, to exist, on the ship. It was really frustrating at first but you know, beginners when it comes to the "Triangle of Confusion" which yes I made up lol. It inspired me to build a vessel similar to his only a few minor and even major differences, an easier engine startup procedure included, because I still got a lot to learn from the "God of Engines and Electricity." 

Furthermore, stuff like JPShips' massive yet interior lacking "Titanic," just immense. Of course there is hardly any interior in there, but putting so much in the ship would kinda make sense to why it would lag. From small ships yet with engine startup procedures that make your brain rage in confusion to humongous creations like JPShips' "Queen Mary" that could probably tower over the Empire State Building lengthwise, let's face it, regardless of what the game tortures you with, you can basically do anything you set your mind to.

 I would also like to point out that the game also sometimes forgets what physics is, when I used GBDanny's "Canopus" and sank it, it split in two and the bow stood on the mast of the stern. Of course, it did collapse at some point, but why did it have to stand on that one mast first? 

The speed of creations is also basically "unlimited" in this game, GBDanny's "Exocet" could sail at a whopping 135 knots. Of course it had hydrofoils, but even his last hydrofoil ship never went that fast, at least I think. 

In conclusion, there is probably other stuff to talk about but I am too lazy to do so lol. However again, in conclusion, despite it's bugs and game crashes like I said in June of 2019, I see Stormworks as a game everyone, who loves engine making and all that jazz, will play in the future. Again, the bugs are understandable, this game is still in early access, or maybe it is just my computer is all. However, if you want a cheaper price but a full release, I suggest getting the game in early access but waiting until full release; prices will increase once the game is completely finished. All in all, I suggest those who like this stuff to play this game.

First time leaving a review. I do not know how this game has been out since 2018 and I have never seen it until this week. Meanwhile steam has a bunch of  crap barely playable games in my Que????? 

Anyways this game is just what I have been looking for, it has the career mode so you have the research and progression of making money to progress into larger better equipped crafts. 

Multiplayer is fine compared to what me and friends lived with when Space Engineers first went to Multiplayer. Is the lag when people open research and such a pain sure. But something I hope the devs can sort out. 

The advance mode is what really has been keeping me so hooked on this game. Mainly because I love to test things and troubleshoot. With Hardcore mode it is punishing but when you build your first boat from nothing and you are out on the water and you do not sink before leaving the harbor that is a pretty great time.

Down side so far is the not being able to build together. My friends and I just used a stream in discord to work together as a work around for now. But once you expand from just 1 boat it is cool to kind of have your thing you mainly work on. One guy boats, another heli's another planes and so on. 

TLDR- Great Game wish I had found it sooner. Looking forward to what these guys bring in 2020!! Would recommend if you like building your own crafts with physics and systems involved.

I bought this on a whim. After 200 hours I can honestly say this is one of the most satisfying games I've ever played.

If you go for the advanced route (which I encouraged everyone to do) you will at times pull your hair, curse at your screen and watch an endless amount of Youtube-videos. BUT! When you've done all this and your creation finally works as intended and you go out and rescue those fisherpeople, you feel immense satisfaction AND you realize that you've used your head and learned something along the way.

It took me 3 hours to get a working ship, and another 5 to finally build one that wouldnt flip over when i turned too hard at speed or angled into waves wrong.

Loved every minute of it.

Im now starting to build larger vessels, and am looking forward to solving the problems that will inevitably occur. only had two small fires thus far, one of which happened when i connected my air line to my fuel line. oops. Anyhow,
Yes, i greatly recommend this game, if you have patience, and enjoy solving issues

As an avid Space Engineers player , and a shipbuilder who works for an IOT company the concept of Stormworks made it an instabuy for me. 

It's almost like two games: 
The main game is exploring, adventuring, problem solving multiplayer game that you can play with a huge catalogue of player designed , satisfyingly complex vechicles, where you can choose if you want to play with easy to use 'automated' vechicles OR you can use vechicles that operate very like thier real life counterparts, (i.e. 12 steps just to start the main engines) the physics are good enough to make it fun, but not highly realistic so the joy comes from operating the vechicles.

The other game is a building game , which unfortunately is not multi user. The 3D building itself is in someways intuitive and efficient but requires getting use to. However this game excels in its logic building and ability to desing and build control and automation loops. I am not clever enough to master this element of the game but am totally amazed at what can be done, see Boka Vanguard ( a heavy lift ship by MrNJ that can be operated like its real life counterpart. 

This is the Digital Twin game that will change how young engineers will work in the future!!!!

Orginally I had a thumbs down due to muliplayer lag and connection. After the last couple of months I noticed improvement and the weekly updates to keep the game spicey. So not only will I change to thumbs up to a thumbs down, I'm gonna go ahead and recommend the game as it sits.

Good:

- The game lets you use your imagination, theres no limit and thats what I love about this game.
- The weekly updates, every week I never know what I expect from Stormworks, new blocks, new sensors? You never know!
- Most of everything in here is pretty realisitic! MOST.


Bad

- Still multiplayer connection issues and lags, but no nearly as bad as before.
- Career mode, ok so I feel like the missions are pretty okay, it's mostly about the danger... yeah, it's to easy to make it to point A to B. I want more danger, more sharks more IDK, just anything that'll try to sink my boat or will. TORNADOS? HURRICANES? Megladons spawn once in a blue moon, tsunami triggers on only one mission. That's honestly my biggest downfall really.
- This is something for new people and still for myself because I still don't know how to correctly use radio RX or even microcontrollers that good.. They need their own beginner tutorial for this stuff. I know theres TONS of YT videos to watch ( Which I have) some are OUTDATED and no longer work, so sometimes I feel stuck in a creation I can't complete.

OVERALL, the game is amazing! Recommend.

After around 1200 Hours it's probably time to give this game a small little Review. Due to the Game currently being in early access, things mentioned in the review might've changed by now. Written at game Version 0.9.20 (early 2020).

Starting off I'd say that this Game was worth the money I spent on it. If you're into vehicle sandbox games like Kerbal Space Programm, Besiege, Simple Planes and Space Engineers in a semi realistic environment then you should definetly give this game a try as well. 

[b]Gameplay and Building:[/b]
Building Mechanics are very simple, you can build your vehicles from basic blocks (a bit similar to minecraft but with 25cm blocks), shapes, mechanical parts etc. - This can either be used to create simple vehicles or complex master pieces full of moving parts to create more complex or smooth shapes. The games complex logic system allows to create a ton of useful features from full scale autopilots to working radar screens. It mainly consists out of simple Logic Blocks (that can also be arranged in a programmable micro processor) that are connected via a simple drag and drop system. (similar to scratch or programming learning tools). There's also lua scripting which allows for even more complex Logic. 
The current actual gameplay is a bit lackluster at the moment and mainly consists out of "ferry" missions (fly this there, deliver his to there, recover this ... etc). The main fun comes from actually playing around with your vehicles. There's a career mode which requires you to research components, manage your fuel etc., I personally play only creative due to the career missions getting boring quite quickly. 

[b]The World:[/b]
The World is a (somewhat) randomly arranged combination of pre-made Islands. It offers a pretty high variety of terrains (mostly water tho) and plenty of space to explore. Sadly the world feels very empty and lacks story telling. 

[b]Graphics:[/b]
The overall quality is very pleasing in my opinion, this is mainly achieved through the low poly look that works very consistently through the game. Reflections and Lighting are very beautiful and don't require to much hardware power. 

[b]Performance:[/b]
The Performance is quite okay. As long as you as you keep your Vehicles reasonable sized (and detailed) the performance stays very stable. When spawning a lot of vehicles or very complex vehicles the game speed will drop quite harshly tho. As long as you have a decent Computer you should be fine Performance wise. 
[Played on: i5-7500, nvidia 1050ti, 24gb RAM and on i7-9750h, nvidia 1650, 16gb RAM both averaging at around 60FPS with nothing to demanding being spawned]

[b]Multiplayer[/b]
Stormworks currently features Multiplayer via Steam Friends. There's no dedicated Servers and Multiplayer performance can be quite bad, especially when playing with someone who has a bad Internet connection or a bad pc .

[b]Early Access[/b]
In my opinion this game currently is what early access is supposed to be. There's regular updates, the devs listen to the community (not always but quite often) and there's quite a lot of stuff which get's broken regularly. Don't expect a final Product, expect a work in progress. 

[b]Realism[/b]
It's a game. Not a Simulator. Hydro / Aerodynamics are very cruedly implemented / simplified. There's only basic and generic components that wont allow for everything that you may want to build. - You usually have to adapt to the game mechanics when building real life things. The Water simulation is good and probably one of the best I've seen in the Indie / smaller game. Although it lacks in the actual Buoyancy simulation. There's no proper wakes or water displacement and vehicles will only float when they're air tight. 

[b]Conclusion[/b]
I would definetly recommend this if you like vehicle sandbox games. It lacks a bit of content in the actual gameplay department but the overall building mechanics are really good. The current Physics are working somewhat well but have a lot of room for improving. 

If you have any questions or remarks feel free to leave a comment.

I't simply amazing what you can build and how well the physics engine holds up, I simply love this game.

The game stays fun by allowing you to change activities whenever you like.
Bored with boats? Make an airplane! Airplane crashed and started a forest fire? Start building a fire truck!
The missions are currently a bit bland and there's no real choice of what you get to do, but they are fun enough to keep you occupied and the devs are actively working on making improvements in the mission system.

The devs do an awesome job interacting with the community on discord and bringing weekly updates.
As always with early access games, things change, bugs happen but the devs are really quick on fixing game braking or majorly disliked changes.

My only annoyance with the community is people asking for weapons in a damn search and rescue game.
Luckily those people seem to have moved on or quieted down since the rocket update (the solid rocket boosters actually have some real utility like JATO and ejector seats).

For me this game has completely replaced both Garrys Mod and Ship Simulator Extremes.

I also struggle with building the base of my vehicles, but that's just me. Overall, I think it's fun to play because it's different and because I like the co-op aspect of it.

TL:DR Not necessarily a bad game, but too fiddly for me.

I bought the game with my primary interest being in performing search and rescue operations and have a decent to good degree of vehicle customization. With co-op available, I was hoping to also wrangle a couple of my old buddies into the game to pull off some missions in some stupidly designed flying machine. While that is all available, it ended up feeling to much like work to achieve it. After a hour and a half in game I had yet to successfully start a vehicle, much less do any missions and I lost interest. Is this the games fault? Not necessarily. I personally feel a tutorial on vehicle assembly is sorely needed as it really lacks the pick up and experiment gameplay of something like Kerbal Space Program. You need to know what you're doing before getting in the game proper or your're going to have a rough time. Also I feel the description page doesn't fully describe what is needed to build and operate a vehicle to perform the missions. The PC Gamer quote in particular felt a bit disingenuous to me. But it does have a very intricate logic and simulation system, so those with the knowledge and desire can do some amazing works in this game as demonstrated in the Steam Workshop. But when I realized I was rapidly approaching the 2 hour and had to come to a decision, which ended up being to ask for my first refund. It's just to fiddly to deal with when all I want to do it jump in, tweak a vehicle to environmental/mission conditions and do some SaR.
This game is really fun to play when you need to just relax, fly a plane, or even drive a boat.  I love the rescue concept and the idea of surviving tsunamis or megalodons.

If you like to be cozzzzzzy in your chair while you're in the middle of a raging storm, this is the PERFECT game for you!

Though the game is in development, they have done some great work with it so far. Bugs here and there, but it is to be expected.

I would recommend this to all my friends, but I cannot give them a 10/10 in the fact that it is still under heavy development.

Just a simple review, not going in to much of details, though I could do that for hours.

I LOVE THIS GAME OK, I dont mean to hurt it in any way. Im going to let people know that frequent updates are not made and tested properly and frequent bugs happen almost everyday you will play. 

There is no point in asking the devs if they can add something you and your friends want because even after you ask for the most useful things that still give the players a challenge, they decide to add useless things like "Ropes" that do nothing but "Look cool" they are also very buggy and have broken my game more than once. 

Creators on the workshop are cool and very nice people but dont mess with their stuff because I and my friended creators have noticed they tend to overreact to items that are sometimes not theirs and end up getting your item banned just because they are "more famous" than you and "deserve more" than you, they should at least ask the item publisher if they have something that shows its their product than banning it unfairly on the spot. 

I dont mind how long an update will take to create, but the devs rush it and end up with more problems than there already was. I have noticed that every update seems to break the game more and more, I would like them in my opinion to work and test the product as long as possible and test everything to make sure that it is safe to publish.

I WOULD ALSO LIKE TO STATE THAT SHORTLY AFTER MY REVIEW, A SHARED IMAGE OF A SHIP I WAS WORKING ON, WAS REMOVED. THERE ARE "4 UNIQUE VISITORS" SO DEVS, IF YOU REMOVED THE PHOTO, OR SOMEONE "BETTER THAN ME" DID, YOU BETTER WATCH YOUR BACK. BIAS BUILDERS.

Took me around 16 hours to figure out how to build my first functional boat with advanced engine system for the campaign mode. Had to design my own ingame processor to translate drivers w/s acceleration input in to the separate inputs for clutch control, engine throttling and a cruise control system so that I can walk around the boat while it drives itself.

UPD: Spent another 40 hours messing around various design concepts and finally building my own starter boat powered by a nice hybrid power system. Took experiments to figure out how to make it the most fuel efficient system possible. After 50 hours in game went on the first mission to try out the craft.

This is literally the game of my dreams...

Survival: build your craft with limited resources and technology. Use that craft to complete missions and earn money and research points to further your tech and fund new vessels, then progress to air and land vehicles completing missions along the way in a fully simulated day/night dynamic weather environment that constantly changes in hostility.

Creative: build and spawn any craft you desire, tweak the weather to your needs or wants, spawn a tsunami and/or megaladon to spice it up, and break everything with no consequences!

Play exactly how you want to: adjust the difficulty by further limiting your starting cash, or disabling certain difficulties to make it slightly easier. You can choose whatever options you want, to suit your play style.

The game is beautiful, astounding at times when the sun rises or sets, or when your ship's traffic lights glisten in the night, underwater wonders, morning fog... crashing storm waves, it's just perfect. The only negative is with larger more complex ships lag isn't a problem, but sim speed is; add a few big craft and it begins to slow things down to an almost unplayable state. Make sure to optimize your creations.

I would recommend this game to other players, because it is a fun game to play. At least, when you have a creativity greater than the lord himself or just really enjoy using other people's builds. If you are not good at building and you do not have any workshop creations, you're pretty much screwed. Keep that in mind. You will as a normal person need to be carried by other people's creations.

It most certainly requires good PC specs, because it takes a lot of frames to load big workshop builds. The community on Discord is absolutely amazing. You can contact the developers at any time if you have questions that cannot be answered by everyone who is in the Discord chat by default.

If you are here for the campaign, there is no campaign. There are a few missions tho and you can also download missions that other people made. You can also create them yourself, but I would suggest watching a tutorial, preferably by MrNJersey, before doing anything.

If you want to learn anything, join the official Stormworks Discord or watch some tutorials by MrNJersey. They are really helpful.

Now you might be thinking, hey, is there no multiplayer? Yes there is! The only downsight is that the connection will not be as pitch perfect as when you're playing Squad on a 40v40 player server. When you make a multiplayer game, you my friend, are the host. If you don't have that much RAM, you usually don't really have a lot when you have just a normal PC or laptop, don't run multiplayer games! Let the other guy run it. Running a multiplayer game requires a lot of RAM and a pretty stable internet connection.

If you don't have any friends to play with, this game might not be the best option, as you will not always run into a lot of people that want to play with you. (As I said, all servers are running on the PC of the guy that started the multiplayer world, so people don't do that very often.) If you are a lonewolf that likes to play alone and likes a quiet and abstract environment, this game will most likely be a go to!


Before you buy anything, take a look at some reviews and watch some YouTube first!

I love this game and play it daily. There is only one problem for people like me that don't have gaming computers. The game tends to crash when big things or workshop items are loaded in the hangar. I want this to be fixed because it happens often. However, this game is recommended and this crashing may be fixed in future updates.

To be honest, this game keeps evolving and surprising me. Horrible game, and here is why


After almost a year of development, the developers have repeatedly seen my advice for how to fix their non-thread-safe code, and they continue to ignore me until this very day. Today however, I posted an image twice on their discord server. For this, I received a ban, without any further justification. While spam is pretty objective, I would argue its foolish that 2 messages is spam. This is direct censorship against users they disagree with. I was questioning their choice of designing their own inferior engine, and as a result I received a ban...

The developers do not value the feedback of their community, and are simply trying to continue on their own ignorant path, without learning from their mistakes.

Purchase only if you like to invest in these horrible developers who don't even listen to what people have to say.

It  is a good game, if youre willing to learn. Learn a Lot. Its not a quick "go rescue some people". In Fact the Missions are more or less just to test your Designs. The Game requires you to learn a lot and not all of it is intuitive. Most is undocumented. If you like Youtube Videos, there are some. If you dont like Tutorial Vids (like myself) youre on your own. You need to know or learn Lua (at least the Basics) to do good stuff. But its worth it. You might need to polish up on your math skills, but its still worth it. You can build really great things. If you learned games like Space Engineers and Factorio in half an hour and are easily bored by Games like Raft, this might be your thing. Its better than Stationeers, because the Building Workshop is much better than the "realistic" stationeers building and the whole thing is less repetitive. However if you just want to relax after a hard day of work, this is not the right game.
