Easily the most detailed physics sandbox/construction game out there. It has REAL depth-based buoyancy where every other sandbox I have tried has on/off buoyancy. It has simulated wind and dynamic weather. Strong wind causes strong waves which make capsizing a real threat. Fog makes it dangerous to move quickly in shallow waters. It's slew of aerodynamic parts make aircraft fun to build and fly. Did I mention dynamic wind? It has train components and large rail systems that spawn in the world. It has wheeled AND tracked land based parts to build anything from sports cars to large tanks. It has fire fighting with fire suppression AND rescue. It has cold weather survival. It has sharks and a wonderful array of sea creatures. It has oil rigs which need crude oil shipped to processing facilities which will in turn produce diesel or jet fuel which you will be consuming. It has computer screens which you can program with lua code to display anything you want. It has all of this and functioning multiplayer.
This game has so much going for it the fact you haven't bought it yet is sad. You'll never realize how sad you are with other physics sandboxes until you buy this one.

Stormworks, in short, is an excellent engineering game with challenges and physics not seen in many other games. With its custom modes and wonderfully versatile library of parts, one would be hard pressed to be at a loss for something to do, or some way to get the cogs in their mind churning.
From helicopters to ships, rickets, drones, trucks, all-terrain vehicles, trains-- whatever you want to make, whatever function you want it to have, it can be done, and there's always a mission to go with it. Can't find it? Go ahead n' make one, yourself! The game just added custom buildings, and before that just added forest fires. This truly lives up to its name: build and rescue.
Now, if you're into engineering machines of all kinds, taking on all manner of different jobs, saving lives and weathering storms, go ahead and pick this up. You won't be sorry, I assure you!

The Stormworks Devs have been extremely busy because this game has progressed so far since I got it around a year ago. They didn't even have jet engines at the time. Now you can have jets, HUGE planes, ships, etc. When I got it, Stormworks was not really optimized for some computers, you needed a beast of a machine to run the Titanic, but now I can spawn the Titanic and run at around 20-30 FPS on a low to medium end PC. What I love probably the most is the building aspect. Once you build, lets say a ship, you have to run the wiring, water lines, fuel lines, exhaust and air intake (On advanced mode. You don't have to do advanced). A little hard to understand at first but there are plenty of videos on how to "program" you vehicle. Plus it makes you feel like you've accomplished something in life once your vehicle runs and survives a tsunami lol.

You might think all those postitive reviews can't be true, but they are.

You can build complex or simple machinery for hours. Then you will get a quest, try to improve your craft and when you completed that quest, The game will reward you with research points. Research nodes (unlocked by a certain amount of research points) then give you new parts and you will (try) to improve your craft again and again and again - or build a new one because the old one can't handle the new quest. :D

Things that can happend to me in SP and some in MP:
- Boat ran out of fuel 400 m before you reached the target
- Friend left your boat and got shredded by your (still) spinning propellers
- You cruise with multiple ships to tug home a tanker
- You wrote a microcontroller for you clutch (because you didn't wanted the workshop ones, you want to build your own) and reconfigure the PID controller for 2 hours before it works
- Then you do it again, because propellers have more resistance in water then in air
- You deliver a package
- You check the radiation from the nuclear power plant nearby
- You forgot to set the a constant in the microcontroller and beached yourself
- Suddenly it's two am and you don't want to go to bed yet, because this time your microcontroller could work ...

Multiplayer is pretty fun, it's like garrys mod where the fun stuff happens because of your friends playing the game.

Sidenote for Multiplayer: Physics syncs to all the clients. Sometimes it gets a bit slow (matrix slowmo style) when something happens and the game can't quite calcuate it in one go/frame, but after a few seconds it is all fine and dandy again. Oh and also when somebody is in the researy tree xD.

Updates come weekly afaik.

"The one that lets you be proud of your construction until you see the Steam Workshop."

---Graphics :
Wonderfull.

---Story :
There is no story but missions really immerse you in the game.

---Gameplay :
I love it, it's challenging, relaxing and very technical !

---Game length :
Infinite, as long as you challenge yourself building the best vehicle possible, this game has no ending.

---Bugs :
There are some, but as long as you save...

---Price :
Really decent for what you get.

===IN GENERAL===
It is a challenging engineering game. Missions are captivating. I really love this game !

Albeit the physics are not perfect due to how much it tries to do at the same time, this game is just amazing. If you have a thing for overly complex multi crew machinery that can do several things at the same time this is one of the most perfect games besides submarine simulators and star citizen.  The game isn't fault free, and you need some supercomputer tier CPU to run this perfectly with huge vehicles, but its just amazing. Although it has no weapons whatsoever and there aren't many things to do with creative vehicles besides doing the same missions over and over again, i still consider Stormworks to set a pretty high standar for this kind of multiplayer vehicle sandbox. The updates are constant and the devs work hard, and it always feels so good to see what each update brings. Honestly this is one of the few times im very glad i bought an early access game since there are almost no games like this that combines sandbox world missions with multi crewed huge vehicles with first person controls, switching seats or being a passanger, and being able to build any vehicle yourself.

this game is very good

Really good game for an alpha. Updates pretty much every week if not it has a huge workshop that releases stuff all the time. There are a few bugs but those are getting worked out all the time. A few things are. One the lag when near shore or with big ships. This has gotten a ton better over the last few updates but is still a problem. Two the water texture glitching through the ship. Also happens less but still not gone. Three the semi rare crashes. Also have improved but still can strike if you really push the game. Water texture is cartoony but actually plays in the games favor as it can look really good without having to be photo realistic. Story mode can be as hard or easy as you want with tons of missions. Only thing I wish would get some love that really has not is the damage model. While yes if you hit something you damage the ship and the texture changes. It really does not feel realistic due to the lack of bending and holes. If the damage model would be similar to space engineers then I feel like it could be really improved. Instead of just changing the texture the ship could bend and break. It would also allow for a repair or referbish type of game play by adding a dry dock style dock that would allow for the player to fix the underside of a ship. Overall a great game but needs some things before launch.

I used to live in Morgan City, LA and I worked for Cal Dive International as a commercial diver and tender. We performed mostly routine rig maintenance off New Iberia in the Gulf of Mexico. We also placed beacons/sonar on the ocean floor to locate and map out pipelines. I had a chance to pilot the Cal Dive II, a diving/support vessel that had a moon pool in the middle of the deck that divers could descend through to get to the job site. One night, as we were going down the Atchafalaya River, the Captain insisted I take the helm...I think that's what he was saying...not 100% sure. Then, he started jumping around, pointing at the radar screen and was yelling, "Poo doo! Poo doo!" Evidently, we had sailed straight through a flock of about a million or so waterborne little rubber duck looking...uh...ducks. I didn't see any casualties in our wake. When I dove, I used a Kirby Morgan Superlite(R) 17 mostly and sometimes a Rat Hat. I also ran the internal, on-ship hyperbaric chamber, complete with BIBS.
 Interesting factoid: I can tell you from experience that a Mag Light Mini will fail at approx 129 ft below the surface. I will also say, "Whatever you see down there, you better keep your head because it can smell fear."
I never understood a word my boss, MC Boudreaux, said. He would point at what he was talking about, but his pointing finger had been chopped off. I would look at his finger that wasn't there, as if it may suddenly appear and he's scream at me, "Wtf you lookin' at, college boy??" He was cool as hell.
Also...deep sea divers breathe "air," not "oxygen." Oxygen, breathed at pressure, will burn your lung tissue over time. Like destroy it. At very deep depths, a diver can breath a mixture of gasses fed through the divers umbilical and controlled topside, that can include helium to prevent nitrogen narcosis.
This game makes me feel like it's just another day going to work in the Gulf of Mexico. I loved everything about that job.*

*Except the drunk coon-asses at the Rathskellar who always thought they could beat me at pool. Pfft!

Well, I guess they were pretty cool.

Update: Nov 2019
Some of the issues I describe below seem to be getting addressed slowly. Its still far from what i want with what feels like far to many sync/lag issues, but I remain hopeful now that some attention has been given to this area of the game. Thanks Devs <3 I hope multiplayer remains an important focus of your future development of the game.

One of the best physics, make and do type games I have ever played. A lot of depth, and options available in the games mechanics that allow you to make so many unique creations. 

My only major gripe with it as of late, is the lack of attention to the multiplayer, that is now barely playable, which is a shame because that is by far my favourite part of the game. Playing, building, and solving missions with friends. The player who is hosting is fine, but it has gotten to the point where any other player is in an absolute lag fest, with rubber banding, freezes, and other really unpleasant issues that spoil the fun. We have decent internet and PC's, single player runs a dream, but any kind of co-op on missions is pretty much impossible at this point.

Fingers crossed things regarding multiplayer get fixed sooner rather than later.

My most played game on steam. I love it. Its a great sandbox simulator angled around coastguard sea&rescue. A setting that works really well in my opinion. It also feature mulitplayer, so you can play with your friends on steam. 

Is the game worth it? Yes. Is it good? Yes. Does the multiplayer work? For the most parts, but there is bugs. However, with weekly updates/bugfixes from the devs it should not be a hinder for your purchase. 
It is a very active community around this game and the workshop features new creations all the time. 

I would recommend this game to anyone fan of sandboxes, and also love a little roleplaying. Its a great setting for it.
epic

So this is an update (11/3/19).  Games looks like it's made a lot of progress. Looked forward to jumping in. Stared a new game. Got a mission.... ok.... now what? No game hints, no direction. If you didn't already know to spawn a boat from the workshop you'd just be running around. So I spawn an existing boat (no little tutorial to build anything). Now I look at my missions.... oh... great.... a mission to delivery mining equipment. One problem: the god damned way point is over a half an our (in real time) away!!! I mean... it's fun to simply hold you finger on the forward arrow button for 30 minutes or so but eventually that gets pretty dull. I'm sure if I sunk hours upon ours into the game it would be fun but this is just stupid. And I mean stupid. Have tried to start several new games since it's been a while. Each mission tat pops up requires me to ave advanced in the game and know how to use things like winches and other contraptions. Plus the distance to these locations is always well out of the immediate starting area meaning I will have to take an ungodly amount of time to reach it.

Ok, so the game is fun for a while. Building the ships and doing the missions gives you some purpose in building. However, the game just feels empty. There's this massive ocean with nothing in it. No other traffic, not even a bird in the sky. There is the occasional fish, but they're kind of generic and pointless. Not that I don't appreciate them, it's nice to have a little something to make the world feel alive. I know it's early access and only been out for a while but the developers don't seem very forthcoming on what exactly they intend with the game. There is no death in the game. Boats cannot be destroyed. You can land your helicopter in water or run it into a wall with no ill effects. So while it's cool when you build your first ship and then unlock the helicopter it kinda gets meh after that. There's no danger in the game. No fuel. No anchors (ships drift away). The game has serious potential but right now I can't recommend it.

Cos to o mě doprdele řekl, ty malá sračko? Abys věděl, byl jsem jeden z nejlepších žáků ve třídě na střední, zůčastnil jsem se mnoha CS1.6 LANparties a můj poměr zabití a smrtí je 3000:0. Umím házet kameny a s prakem to umím lépe než kdokoliv jiný ze Stínadel. Ty pro mě nejsi nic jiného než další cíl. Pošlu tě do nemocnice s tolika boulema, že tě tvoje máma nepozná, si kurva pamatuj. Myslíš, že ti projde, když mi budeš říkat takový sračky přes internet? Zamysli se znova, píčo. Zrovna kontaktuju celorepublikovou síť mých ajťáckých kamarádů, kteří vysledují tvou IP, takže se připrav na smršť, mamrde. Smršť, která ti vezme to ubohé malé něco, čemu říkáš tvůj život. Jsi mrtvej, kámo. Můžu být kdekoliv kdykoliv, a můžu tě zmlátit na sedm set způsobů, a to jen mýma holýma rukama. Nejenom že mám spousty zkušeností v boji beze zbraní, ale mám konexe a přístup do jednoho skladu policejních obušků a pepřových sprejů a využiju toho k tomu, abych ti pořádně nakopal tvojí blbou prdel, trotle. Kdybys jenom býval tušil, jakou pekelnou odvetu ti tvůj malý "chytrý" komentář přinese, možná bys držel svou nevymáchanou hubu. Ale tys nevěděl a nedržel, a teď zaplatíš, ty zatracenej idiote. Naseru ti můj vztek na hlavu a ty se v tom utopíš. Jsi kaput, smrade.

If you're looking for a game that will suck you in for hours with creative problem solving and continuous expansion, this is the one. I consider this the other half of Minecraft that never existed before. Although the game is still young and constantly updating, it is still very fun to build and test your creations. The creators accounted for a lot of build options and really give you a lot to work with and learn. The only negative side to this game is the missions, while random, seem to be very similar in nature and get repetitive but I like to think that is simply because the game has not been finished yet. There is room for much more in the way of missions and goals. But for now I am very happy with what this game is and continually find myself returning to check on new updates and try my hand at building a new interesting vehicle and testing it out. Again, beware of being sucked in for hours when starting a new build. You will build and test and build and test for hours and hours.

A very good game for building vehicles. The logic building in the game is really well done. The community is great in this game and on the discord. Asking for help on the discord usually gets an answer pretty quick. 

Just a note for those wanting to buy the game, keep in mind that its in early access for a reason and does frequently get updates that may bring the game in a buggy state that could otherwise make it unplayable for some. These bugs usually get fixed soon but if you want a game with little to no bugs and a game that feels complete then this may not be the game for you.

Now that the performance part of this game has been fixed its so much better. Couple of things. Stormworks is an amazing game, the art-style is really awesome as well as the creations are so cool. I am going to break this game down by category IE Boats, cars, helicopters, planes and misc.

Boats-- So boats is kind of what started this game off. The water physics is actually really good and sometimes is too good and leads to you say "WHY THE F*** IS THIS BOAT NOT FLOATING" until you realize 1 block is missing. The fluid physics is really good and when it comes to making fire equipment it really shines, oh yeah did I mention there is vehicle damage. You can 100% blow you creation up because you forgot to connect the radiator, and then you can start a forest fire and have to put it out. The only thing that lack in the boat department is better wakes and bow waves, there are underwater places to explore and if your good enough you can build a submarine.

Planes/Helicopters.---- The aircraft in this game have recently started to get really complicated with the addition of cameras screens and LUA scripting. The creations being made by people like Boeing 777 aircraft with Glass Cockpit designs or people making Coast-Guard Helicopters to recuse AI on missions is amazing. The flight physics are somewhat lacking. As you can build a jet aircraft that take off with 0ft of runway and than somehow shake violently because your going to fast and the GYRO does not really like it. Auto-pilot systems are amazing and useful when your playing alone, or if your with friends. Yes there is Multi-Player and they are improving it alot.

Ground/Misc/Trains.---- The Ground vehicles are amazing, I have spent more time trying to build land speed record cars and weird bus's and tracked things that I sometimes forget how to build boats. The addition of radar/Sonar to the game has added alot for people to work with. Lets say you want to drive an old school car, well all you have to do is hope on the workshop with thousands of creations and well subscribe to one and next thing you know your driving it around a map. Now microcontrolers can be your friend or enemy. I suck at making Micro-Controllers, all they do is basically they act as a mini computer, they allow you to use logic functions to make things work well. If your not good at making your own go browse the workshop for what you need. Oh and Lastly the missions are really fun, sometimes can be really frustrating and annoying but really fun. 

Advanced mode/ Game modes.----- So this game features a really awesome creative/survival game mode. As well as an amazing advanced vehicle mode. With advanced vehicle you have to connect everything from air to coolant to a radiator as well as connecting the drive-lines to the tires.

In conclusion if you want a really good building survival, mission technical and mechanical game to mess around with seriously pick this game up!

1.5 hours in game and ZERO FUN.

One of the worst gaming experiences I have ever had. Nothing works or at least is next to impossible to figure out. 

Items are too big for area to load or do not work when they do load. Get in boat, click the one button available and still no power to drive boat. 

Game looks great, but it just isn't intuitive at all.

Amazing game, lots of little technical details to get lost in.

Hampered by a mutliplayer that doesn't work properly.

If the multiplayer actually worked properly I'd top rate it. But as it stands the netcode does not work well at all when connected to two or more other folks, expect constant slowdowns due to physics engine (not related to lag or framerate issues) wigging out when someone tries to use a gas connector or picks up a crate or other physical item, strange desync issues (times on completing missions not always synced among players), and simply laggy response times on controls which can be mood killing with vehicles that require responsive controls such as helicopters or when trying to align to a dock without smashing into a cliff. 

Single player works perfectly fine. No issues to report there. If you want to yoink this game to play alone go for it, but you'll have to watch online tutorials on how to do stuff as nothing is explained in game. But this game would have so much potential as a co-op hit if the netcode was a bit better. 

Another serious issue is it being limited by being 32 bit instead of 64. With the friend I was trying to play it with it hammered his first core hard on his CPU while leaving the other ones fine. Why the devs are insisting that is the route forward I have no idea but that also hampers playability.

If those issues were fixed it'd be super super fun, and would top rate it. As it stands, bitter love hate relationship with it as I want to play more of it, but continue to get exceptionally frustrated at the netcode.

At only 17 hours in I can already say this is probably my favorite indie? on steam. It scratches a gameplay itch that has bugged me ever since Ship simulator become a mess. The fact I can build my own vehicles and bases with that much freedom is amazing! I even got a couple friends interested who plan to get it so we can play together. 
When i first showed one of my friends this we had a blast and lost track of time for a good 6 hours.

The biggest issue for me is the lack of controller support. its hard for me to play keyboard and mouse effectively and at times is downright painful due to physical problems, other than that this is an amazing game.

For new players it is important to understand that you will enter the game with no instructions, even in the career mode. The boat building is impressively complex, with an outstanding amount of freedom and customization. However, there is nothing in the game to explain how the boat reacts to the physics of the game. 

For Example: Make sure the bottom of the boat is fully closed (umm duh right) well not exactly, the engine and exost pieps need special pipe blocks to ensure water does not enter the bottom of the boat. If you boat is too heavy it will sink, you need to set the electric up in certain ways, or you will kill the battery and be lost to see. 

The point is, this game is fasinating, but does not explain how to get started. I have spent 8 hours in game trying to build this boat, and another 8 on youtube. I know I might be a bit slow, but I feel the game should put some effort into assisting new players on how to build their first boat-you start with nothing btw,

Stormworks Build and Rescue is onto something. But the game is missing a fully realized multiplayer + survival world. Currently the map is gigantic taking hours to explore even at high vehicle speeds. The game also tends to lag and crash in multiplayer. Most vehicles have at least 2-4 seats and some have dozens of places where people can sit or even assist in piloting or doing other tasks. Nearly all of the vehicles I've subscribed to have been made with multiplayer in mind. But the game doesn't seem stable enough to support it.

Even playing with people at home hardwired to the same network we were crashing at least every 5 minutes. As a game developer myself I am guessing part of this has to do with the enormous world size. I wonder if a smaller world size would cause less issues in multiplayer?

Another thing I'd suggest is a Multiplayer Survival Mode WITHOUT the ability to spawn in vehicles. Instead, vehicles can be found on the map in various states of disrepair. You find the components to fix them (start with a simple collectible component called 'vehicle parts' that works for all vehicles) and then you can accept rescue missions.

Rescue missions would then become a way of introducing new vehicles that could be repaired and claimed by the player. Claimed vehicles can be locked by setting a code near their start key. This code can be used to unlock the vehicle by teammates. 

In addition to these mechanics I'd also suggest a way to hunt animals (a bow for example) and a way to gather, cook, and eat them. 

Having a hunger and thirst system would add to the drama in the game. If you're going on a long sea voyage you would pack storage compartments with food and actually be able to cook inside some vehicles with kitchens.

This, along with the ability for other players to damage your player with weapons intended for hunting will add a whole new dynamic to the game. 

In addition I would make it possible to "take over" found buildings and ports. You would place a lock on the door, set a code and then it would be yours. Then only you  and your team could open and close the doors.

Other players would have to seek out buildings in other areas of the map to call home.

This would be a lot to add, but it would be a controlled environment where the map size and number of complex vehicles could be kept to a minimum. By losing some of the complexity of the full creative mode the game could be optimized better. 

Having a mode like this could grow the games popularity and would also require some official and community server support. It would be a big move but I think Stormworks is worth it.

I absolutely LOVE this game. I have spent hours upon hours searching for good engineering games and this has topped them all. I just wish it ran a little better on lower end computers but even with low frame rate I still absolutely love it.

It is the most creative game I have ever indulged in. I have always wanted a game that included not only the ability to create, but also optimize and dive into the actual mechanics of the aircraft. Every single time I create a vehicle I face numerous challenges, tuning every aspect of the vehicle to my liking. I like the idea of creating autonomous systems from scratch, such as auto pilot. I typically only look things up to double check my work after I spend hours failing at something, but I love the hussle in between, and the ability to say "I made this".

Please developers, don't ever give up on this game, it has a very very promising future, and it delivers a great deal of education on top of everything else. Thank you.

Things that could be improved:
* More window options (angles, sizes)
* Fluid workings/ items need to be ether segregated completely or treated the same way (I can not use a valve to cut off 
   power supply, and I can not use one way valves on power pipes causing a combined system to unevenly spit power, 
   meaning the only way to distribute equal power is through clutch on every  separate outlet pipe)
* windows take up space in in inconvenient ways. 
* doors should still lock without having a complete frame (AKA custom sliding doors are hard to seal)
* Eliminate invisible blocks, people are creating things that they should not physically be able to, make it to where any 
   floating blocks are not merged to anything, thus eliminating impossible structures outside of the intended boundaries.
* Make the cut/ paste process easier (where you can select blocks and slide them over and automatically create a new 
   section, like an actual cut and paste, the current cut/ paste process is way too complicated and time consuming)
* Make connectors that can be spawned connected ( I was trying to make a detachable weight that would sit in my boat 
   until I needed it for my water crane and could not figure out a way to do it)
* Make crane hose/ cable a real object so that when we pull the cable back up the node does not get stuck under the boat. 
   (Or at least create a crane wheel attachment we can merge the cable to so the wheel can guide the cable to keep it from 
   getting stuck under the structure of origin)

* Make more use of hotkeys in creation mode, they are super handy and keep players interested. A lot of time is wasted 
   trying to figure out how to do everything with a mouse.

It's certainly a fun a game, but damn is it laggy. Nothing THAT complex is ever going on either, but expect fairly slow gameplay. I have an i7 5820k with a GTX 970 and its choppy after spawning in a decent sized ship. It's not the computer, it's the game. But if you can deal with that and take the time to learn the complex building system then I'm sure you will have a lot of fun with this game. Haven't tried mutiplayer yet, but if I lag this much in single player then I can imagine multi is a shitshow. Game needs optimizing in the worst way, land vehicles are nothing similar to anything you have ever experienced in your life and are comically hard to operate (helicopters are easier to fly and land on the back of your boat than forklifts are to drive down a runway). Maybe I'm just bad but this is a difficult game to just pick up one day.

That being said, if the full release runs smoothly with large complex ships and multiplayer gets the kinks worked out this game is well worth $20.

I gave this game a fair shake put plenty of time into trying to play it, but I've given up on it pretty much completely. I was hoping that the mainland update would've fixed some issues with it but it hasn't, it has the worst ground physics I've ever seen, I mean literally skating across the ground with massive tires that in the real world would never loose traction and slip and slide around, but that doesn't matter at least there's trees you can get pinned up against when you slide 1,000ft off the road and can't get back out, but at least there's forest fires that you can't put out because you are preoccupied with sliding off the road down a hill into the water. I will say the flying and boating is pretty good, the land based vehicles are terrible however. The system for controlling engines in this game is atrocious as well. They give you a clutch that just stalls everything so you cannot build anything unless you can code using the microcontrollers which I'm sure 75% of people don't know how to use. I hope that the game is fixed upon proper release I might even consider trying it out again but until now its not worth the time or the money unless you want to smash you keyboard over your knee in frustration.

I do somewhat enjoy playing this game so far, but there are some glaring problems you can see right away.

Pros: Very versatile building tools
         Fucking around with friends

Cons: Not much to do
          No tutorials for how to build (you must rely on reverse engineering, and the in game builds aren't complex enough to learn anything useful from
          Simple things like tire rotation are way more complex than they have to be
          They change how things work so often that online tutorials are often outdated, as well as most of the popular workshop builds
          The internet is basically required to learn how to do anything (Sometimes its easy to find what you're looking for, and sometimes there are no good tutorials out there for what you're looking for)
          Engine power levels are all over the place, some are too powerful and need to be limited, and some are too weak.
          

This game has a great concept! The execution just currently isn't there

Before I begin:
Graphics: 9/10
Performance: 9.5/10
Audio 7.5/10
Replayability: 9/10
Price: 9/10
Detail: 10/10
Physics: 9.5/10

Initially I will admit I was sceptical about this game and even the first time I played I was still unsure.

But then I started to explore the sheer depth of the game. The logic, the physics, the building, the freedom! It is a pleasure to play this. I do quite like the cartoonish graphics and this also means the performance is flawless (except the odd frame stutter) even on my low end PC. 

Missions are varied, interesting and immersive. The first storm I encountered and the first flash of lightening I jumped out of my skin! The physics is very well modelled and causes you to focus on a developmental process of design - your vehicles although complete will be modified, adjusted and improved upon through several iterations as you learn how your design will be affected by the forces of nature.

It is rare to find a game that delivers good performance, exceptional immersion, fantastic physics simulation, a detailed, varied and unique open world all while allowing you to build your own vehicles. 

A* for the alpha, let's hope the first release is a fully polished masterpiece...

Stormworks is a really innovative, creative and fun game in which you can design your very own vechicles (sea, land and air!) or you can download amazing creations from the community workshop, and use the vechicles to complete various missions, in a range of epic enviroments. I just recently was able to buy a copy of the game (I've been watching a lot of YouTube videos on it for the past year and wanted to get it) and I finally did! It is even more amazing than I expected it to be!

However there is one slight optimization issue.
Now I am fully aware (because I've researched the issue) that I'm not the only one to experience it. I also know the issue is not on my end. A lot of people experience it differently.  How the issue looks for me is that whenever I spawn in a bigger vechicle (or a vechicle with a really high amount of advanced components) I experience lag. Now I know that this isn't the usual lag you get, because when I press F1 the FPS count is usually in between 30 - 40 FPS. The character moves really slowly (it looks like slow motion) and the waves also usually move very slowly. I have done various things to prevent this, I went into career mode (I thought the issue was something to do with islands and the creative options), I even disabled Advanced Vechicles, and while it did help, I'd rather play with Advanced Vechicles on. I also turned every possible performence setting down to the lowest option.

Despite this issue, the game is absolutely incerdible and it is 100% worth the money. Looking forward to some optimization updates (hopefully).
Good game with A LOT of functions. It can be run on desktops or normal laptops but on lowest settings. It is a good game but you need good graphics to really experience it.

Okay I think I have enough hours in this to comment on it. 

I really like the game. There is solid building tools but it's not required to be an engineer to have fun, you can use the workshop to find crafts that will work at any point in the campaign. There's a good variety of missions to do and you can make your own missions if you want to.  This reminds me of those old eurojank "ship simulator" games but this actually has good quality. Anything you can think of you can do, except spacecraft.  There is no combat as of me writing this review which is fine, although it's a controversial subject for people in the community. 

TL;DR I think anyone who likes building things and being immersed in a gameworld with simulator style mechanics will fall in love with this.

Too much to say, too little time. This is a great game overall, and I say this with certainty given my 1,231 hours. Fun with friends, fun on your own, and just fun anytime. The devs can be like your little brothers sometimes, breaking things in updates or nerfing everything, but you gotta respect them for this game they built. I have not played any other game consistently since I bought Stormworks. Best $15 I ever spent. EVER. 10/10 recommended to anybody.

Yes, it's early access and it has a few problems here and there with submerged buoyancy physics (some strange behaviour at times) and the multiplayer side of it is very hit and miss and doesn't work more than it works. But I have spent so many hours making just 2 vessels and making them progressively more and more complex with various features and enjoyed every single minute doing so.
Keep it up devs!

=========================

Update to review: 

I feel I can no longer recommend the game anymore.
It is no longer the game that it started off as - it seems to now attract a much younger player base and as a result they have their own wants / needs from the game and are voting for stupid and pointless things on Discord which then get added to the game.

Things such Giant Sharks, Trains (is a sea rescue game?), Oil buying and selling (? - ok, I suppose I can build oil tankers instead of rescue craft ?), solid rocket boosters - all the while there are long term problems with core physics (water doesn't even behave like water anymore) and the way that objects interact (the game engine doesn't allow most types of boat builds that work in real life, for example a simple "row boat" would sink in this game).

Some of this was acceptable when the game was in its infancy, but now it is just plainly being ignored and brushed under the carpet, which is NOT OK.

Just one example of strange physics behaviour that seems to be accepted: I have built a large ship with a small custom door on the outside of the hull. When I open this, the physics sometimes decide that it will make my large heavy ship do a roll into the water because the door gets stuck on "nothing". I believe the devs often refer to this as phantom robotic behaviour or something similar when the problem gets raised, with no mention of them fixing it - it just seems like an accepted feature of the game whereby you can have something that weighs mere KG's that can then force something that weighs hundreds of tons to rotate around it and with no obvious way to repeat it or stop it from happening as it seems to be random.

I would like to give this game a good rating and I have been playing it on and off for a while but the lack of tutorials or guides, kills me. As they update the game, they add more complexity to it but with no detailed explanation. They rely on the community to figure it out and then put out tutorials. an example would be the sonar. It has an adjustment for FOV and elevation angle but I have no clue what way should it be facing, and as far as the sonar head itself, I have no clue if the top bottom or one side is the "front" for the FOV and what is the reference point for elevation? It says Max input number is .125.....great,  .125 what? This is just the latest thing as there are plenty of other systems I still have no idea how to use. As I said, the community has been the backbone for tutorials but even they dont get it all and for some things, I still have yet to find any that answer my questions. Frankly, putting out a game and then hoping that people will figure it out and spread knowledge while you just go off to more shit, seems a bit off on priority. If you made the game, then make a proper dam guide. No one knows better or can go into more detail then the ones that created it. Either laziness or misguided priorities. I am rating this as a "No" because its getting worse with every added feature and even some of the community that did help have all started to drift away from the game and so answers come slow or not at all. I hate that my first review of a game on steam is going to be a negative one.

I've yet to play a game that i'm anticipating a massive multi feature in more than this. The building is outstanding, the missions are entertaining, the environment is great. 

It does have it's problems, there are glitches and you will get frustrated with some of the mechanics as they stand. Clicking on ladder for you not to grasp it is a pain in the ass. Picking things up and moving them with your character can be annoying. The AI isn't very intelligent and half the time on rescue missions you'll have to move them around manually by picking them up. 

I can go on with some of the negatives in the game, but why would I? It's an early access game and the devs are working hard to keep adding features. It's not a finished game and nobody is saying it is. That being said, for what you get it's damn entertaining. 

Building your own vehicle (and that can be a tiny boat to the literal RMS Titanic) is a blast. It's unique, thoroughly entertaining, and will keep you coming back with every update. 

I give it the highest recommendation, and will continue to play as long as it keeps receiving updates.

This game has soaked up a lot more hours of playtime than I originally thought. If you like tinkering around and making things that work, this is the game for you. It fits a whole lot of what I wanted as a game, a physics sandbox that allows you to make whatever contraption you really desire. For me it was boats. Hours and hours of building in the vehicle editor and maybe a few minutes actually playing the game itself. But those few minutes were worth it. Seeing your creation come to life and seeing that it works as intended really fills you with a sense of satisfaction. And I rarely get that with any games. 
If you aren't a real creative tinkerer type then this game still has a lot in store for you to do. The workshop is FULL of awesome craft for you to use on the many multiple stock and user created missions available. 

This game doesn't need a beefy PC to run. With more recent updates the game runs smoothly. I haven't had any issues with it crashing or being a pain and i'm running on Linux using Proton. The platform that's supposed to be the most unstable. 

Its well worth the asking price. Updates are dropped VERY frequently that add new balances, patches and items to play with.
Yes buy please
Great Game

This isn't a game you can play for just an hour a day and expect to figure out everything. You will have to dedicate lots of time to understand the basics. But when you look upon and use your creation, it will be worth it. If you understand basic to complex logic gates, you can make your creation do anything whit little input from you. The laws of physics are obeyed in this game so driving anything is affected by the wind, waves, and flooded compartments. There are currently 2 main game modes; career and creative, with the option to customize either mode for difficulty. In career mode, you complete missions for money, bonus parts, and research points to unlock more parts. In creative mode, you do whatever you want with no restrictions. You can also adjust the weather and spawn tsunamis and megalodons (yes, they exist in this game). This is a peaceful game, there are no weapons and I doubt the developer plans to put any in. If custom naval combat is what you want, play From the Depths. For those who want to get a sample of what it's like to play as the coast guard, this is the game for you. I also would like to thank the real coast guard for everything they do. This is hard enough, I can't even begin to imagine what it's like in real life!

Where do I start?  Mastering and learning the game mechanics? The building or even the logic. As people we are obviously not the same, if you are reading this review you are probably a vehicle person. Don't like ships? That's okay, you can make yourself an aircraft of any sort. Don't like aircraft, that's okay, you can make yourself a automobile or train. Don't like building? Why don't you relax and modify a nice vehicle from the workshop and watch it sink. Don't like how a plane flies? Fix it yourself!                                                
          
         If you are into how things work, this game a treasure trove. Here you can create your own transmissions, constant-speed propellers, guided missiles and autopilots. While you are out testing your vehicles you will find yourself constantly dis-satisfied with 
your own builds and in the logic world fine tuning until you reach perfection. Then comes the joy and satisfaction you want,
seeing your boat take tsunamis and the highest waves, your missile hitting it's mark, your plane making it to the Artic and your submarine surfacing after a long and harrowing underwater exploration. Maybe you are just happy that what you have learned in the dungeon of geometry class actually applicable and useful.  


        Or maybe you feel without closure, that you could've done better, well pal, you have all the knowledge and dedication to make it the right way, your own way. Whether it's a flashy yacht or a rustic ocean liner, it's a reflection of what you like to represent you in a vast and diverse world of ideas and imagination.
Great game. Great value! i've played AAA games for 60€ less than i play this masterpiece for 17€! can't put it down. i hope it gets more islands and better multiplayer support.

Welcome to the only thing you're ever going to do with your life from this point on. I've been playing this game since the early beta and it's only gotten better over time. The physics are great fun, the graphics are beautiful even for the low poly style the game has, it can still create beautiful views to accompany you on your journeys and missions. There's a full array of fun missions, progress based unlocking of parts and if you prefer it, a creative mode where you can freely build anything (and I do mean anything) your heart desires, simply check out the workshop and you'll see what I mean. One of the key features of this game is the advanced logic, you can even build your own microcontrollers, these little microchips can be made to do anything, from flashing some lights to making a hundred foot high robot walk around. If you prefer the easier life, there is also a simple mode for both creative and the progressional missions but I highly recommend getting used to advanced mode as quickly as you can as it will make your experience far more fun. All in all, this is a pretty advanced and fun game for £15 with a lot to it and a lot more on the way, plus a huge community on not only the official discord but the many, many others that have sprung up over time because this game brings people together. This is one purchase you won't regret, unless you enjoy having free time.

This game scratches my itch. Allowing you to create anything you want in any way you want it's the truest of physics sandbox builders.

No mtxs, no grind, no bs. 

Obviously in an early access state while there continue to be bugs the game develops at a rate you can see with updates every Friday. 

In terms of building, this game really caters to those of all skill levels ranging from simplistic modes where you don't need to worry about pipes, fuel supplies and a lot of small details to a full fledged advanced mode capable of have creations with self programmed pids, huds and touchscreens. 

Fear not though folks who prefer to just plug and play, with an active workshop with thousands of well made creations the option to just mix and match from the creations generously uploaded is one that many choose. 


For the tinkerers like myself this allows me to mess around with lua control systems and routines and everything you could possibly want all without having to download or faff around with a single mod. 

Frankly this game is already great and I hope it only gets better, that being said I would be remiss to not mention the one great big flaw of this game currently which is multiplayer. Currently well, it just doesn't work too well (stuttering is pretty bad) and there is no coop building.  The Devs have said they are working on it but it'll probably be a while.

That doesn't take away from the great proposition this game offers though
Current it is my game of choice.

Overall a well made game that I reccomend buying.

My third review...

I've come to terms with the fact that this game is not the detailed maritime world I want it to be, but it is the best sandbox maritime experience I can find.

I have spent a lot of time with the game, and 99% of that has been building creations then trying them out in creative mode. I've dabbled with the career, but it just isn't compelling...hopefully that will change.

If you're looking for a sandbox game that is generally maritime themed, has a beautiful sea simulation and allows creative building then this is the one.

If you're after a fully fledged simulation / maritime role play ...then add it to your watch list and see how it develops.

There is literally no other game that exists where I can drive my own custom ship through rough waves and storms, through hell and back. *No* other game can scratch the itch that Stormworks does and I love it! There's nothing like riding a ship through bursting waves and pouring rain in the dark of night... all you see is up, down, up, down... so awesome.

I have played 593 hours. This game was really good, until this update: v0.7.17 (The Fuel Efficiency Curves Update). Ever since then the game has gotten worse and worse. I would still recommend this game. There is a lot of tutorial videos on youtube. But not so many videos on gearbox's and gear ratio's, as they say they are build specific. before update: v0.7.17 the best gear ratio was 
1:1 1:1 1:1
2:1 3:1 1:-1 now it's all different. So for Building a new creation I recommend doing it on a creative world without limited fuel. Set your build up as though it is limited fuel, just add fluid spawners to your custom fuel tanks. Keep your engine room and engine controls simple until all your gearbox and propulsion testing is all set, as i'm sure there will be some changes.

The game itself is really good! Optimization is way better after the Optimization Update, still not so good but definitely improved, updated every week and nice community. The lack of the game are the physics, that are currently orrible for planes. A plane can't take off in 10 meters, also landing, stall physics and speed of planes are to rework.

This game used to be excellent until a recent event that has completely changed the game's fate from possibly being another Kerbal Space Program but with boats, to another abandoned voxel game.

People started discovering how to exploit the game's poorly simulated physics to create infinite energy by wiring a diesel engine to crap tons of small generators. This prompted the developers to create a major balance update that completely ruined all forms of electricity in the game other than pre-charged batteries (which were impossible to charge again). Everything was nerfed to be hilariously inefficient and every single vehicle on the workshop no longer worked at all. Fortunately, they pushed out an update about a week or two later (I'm not sure, the important part is that it came out and it didn't take months and it fixed things) and now electric generators created a reasonable amount of electricity again while still fixing the exploit.

This would be all well and good if it weren't for the fact that the developers are once again completely rebalancing the game's energy physics. They just pushed out an update that completely changes the way engines work; all vehicles that directly wired engine power (i.e. not into a bunch of generators and then using electric motors to power wheels, which considering the last update, these were all considered broken, and still don't work nearly as well as they used to) no longer work barely at all. My speedboat's top speed has been cut into a QUARTER of before and has even worse fuel consumption. Not to mention that the electric nerf update cut the speed even of fully diesel vehicles in half already, so now everything is just outright stupidly slow with outright stupid fuel consumption.

The best part is, they didn't tell us how to make a functioning vehicle at all. They just showed a bunch of engines running not connected to anything that provides resistance. So now we're once again left in the dark as the entire workshop is full of nonfunctional obsolete vehicles and no idea how to properly use the engine, but this is a lot worse than the electric update because now NOTHING works.


[h1]--------------------------------------------------------------------------------[/h1]


The point I'm making here is that the developers are making gameplay changes that are so major that the way you design vehicles in the game [strike]other than basic piping[/strike] has to change entirely... [b]EVERY TWO WEEKS.[/b]

Of course, the fanboys are going to play the "Muh Early Access" card, but after the last few years of using steam, most people are sick of this kind of thing and are just going to move on to something else. If you're one of them, I'm your cue.

There's also this ret@rded giant shark that eats your entire ship to pieces and they don't want to add guns. But solid rocket boosters are A-OK, as long as they distract everyone from how broken this game is.

[b]THEY CHANGED THE PIPES AND USED A MEME IN THE UPDATE POST. Granted, it was a good change. But it was still cringe. Hopefully they continue making good changes. A little LESS meme cancer wouldn't hurt either, though...[/b]

Tips for new players:

You will be forced to play your first game in 'normal mode' which is a stripped down version of the full depth this game offers, but it's not as bad as it sounds. The simplified easy mode is actually pretty comprehensive and you'll have a lot to sink your teeth into before ever jumping into proper 'survival mode' (with advanced vehicle mechanics).

Tips for building:

- Know these shortcuts:
  - TAB - opens/closes your inventory
  - X - toggles the eraser mode
  - CTRL+Click - selects the block type under your mouse cursor so you don't have to search for it in your inventory
- You can click & drag pyramid blocks to create angled shapes quickly.
- You will probably want to use X-axis symmetry most of the time.
- Building vehicles can be slightly tedious due to having to rotate & flip blocks in so many different directions all the time. Use symmetry to reduce that work.
- Change the build camera from orbit mode to free mode if you aren't used to 3D editing environments. This will allow you to move around more easily using the movement keys (WASD) and Q/E for down/up.

General tips:

- Design your boats with plenty of interior hull space so that they'll be able to float on water.
- Don't make your boats too top-heavy or you'll have stability problems. Adding weight at the bottom of your boat is an effective way to balance out the mass above the water line. But this means your boat will be overall even heavier, so you'll need more free space inside your hull  to increase buoyancy.
- If you want a way to get below the deck of your ships you'll need to use the door or hatch components. This is the only way that the physics simulation will know that this area is sealed (when the doors or hatches are closed at least). Be sure to place these well above the waterline on your deck, otherwise they'll get flooded and your ship will sink even though realistically it would be fine. This is an unfortunate but necessary side-effect to make the simulation possible in real-time, but it should become less of an issue the bigger ships you build.
- When you're doing a mission and you have to travel a few kilometres by boat, and your boat isn't that fast, it can be a little boring if you have to stay at the helm to push the throttle and make course corrections. To mitigate this you can set a throttle and rudder trim by holding the left ALT key. Then you can get out of your seat, walk around and inspect your ship, and check the map/mission/tech screen. However, don't try to be too badass and get out of your poorly designed submarine at cruise speed because you might fall off and have to start over.
- When you get into bigger ships and harder missions, and you have researched the necessary technologies, you can build advanced systems to control and automate your ships and other machines. Heading hold, GPS waypoints and roll stabilisation are good things to add to your ships.
- You may want to build robotic arms to manipulate mission objects (cargo). Be sure to build them robust enough for the intended purpose. If your robotic arm is too heavy and big for your ship and/or the cargo, you won't have a good time. Make a more humble arm and/or a bigger ship.
- The 'medium ship hull' preset is a good size starting point for a nice, sturdy towing ship. Just add your own helm, some railings, a winch and enough engine power. If you want to go bigger you have to create your own hull, and I suggest breaking up the basic shape a bit more, so that it doesn't look too flat.

It's a good game, and will become even better. We can sink some hundreds of hours easily, crafting ships, aircrafts or submarines. Right now it has not the complexity of SE for instance, and the physics aren't top notch, but, Devs are reponsible and doing a good job.

SUMMARY
This is one of the best "games" I have ever played. I say "game" because it's really an engineering simulator. Stormworks lets you engineer what you want, how you want, and take it for a spin in a huge open world. Well done, devs. Great concept, great execution, great work.

LENGTHIER REVIEW
Stormworks is an engineering simulator but with game elements (missions, objectives) in a large open world. If you just want to make a contraption, you can jump into Creative mode where all components are available. You can produce whatever kind of contraption that takes your fancy: air vehicles, sea vehicles, land vehicles, trains (yes, there's a rail network!) and stationary contraptions.

The contraption editor is multi-layered, which means there's different views for different things, i.e. views for component placement, electrical links, and logic. Whilst some logic blocks are available in the editor for placement directly onto the contraption, you can use microcontrollers for projects that require more complex logic. Microcontrollers have their own editor, in which you can place logical operations and functions into a microcontroller and specify inputs and outputs.

Stormworks is not easy to get to grips with due to its complexity (and there are a few issues at the moment, like with the way buoyancy is calculated) and I've had many hours of frustration, but once you get used to it, it's incredible what it allows you to do. You'll be spending quite some time learning the ropes before producing anything decent. Also, quality contraptions take some time to produce.

Things I've made as of typing: a heavy lifter with crane, two jet planes, a tri-prop plane just because I can, two helicopters, jet boat, and recently, two sizes of load-adjusting electrical generators (i.e. engine throttle adjusts depending on the electrical load)

If you like problem solving and engineering, get it now!
I would most certainly recommend this!

[h1] After about a full day of playing this game, here are my experiences: [/h1]

Me and a friend pulled off some sick helo rescues, with rescue divers and winch operations. I felt like an actual coastie

Me and a friend put out some fires on ships and lighthouses 

Me and a friend did some cargo and tanker operations

Me and a friend broke our save beyond repair because we crashed so many ships together and sank them all

For someone who enjoys maritime sandbox games, complex ship systems, and coast guard stuffs, this is the game for you. There are endless possibilities about what you can do in relation to sailing/captaining/crewing a multitude of vessels (Merchant, Coast Guard, Military, Civillian).

[h1] Pros: [/h1]
+ Amazing ship building system

+ Extremely complex logic systems for winches, engine starts, circuit breakers, fuel pipes, etc (easy to get a grip on. Its the possibilities for complexity that's the best)

+ Fantastic physics and game engine

+ Logic systems are up to par for people who aren't computer wizards

+ There are hundreds of ships for download if you don't want to build a ship

+ There are hundreds of extra missions available to download to expand upon your gameplay and playstyle 

[h1] Cons: [/h1]
- Multiplayer runs your server (through steam friends) at the lowest person's framerate. Say your friend is getting 10fps and you're getting 200fps, everyone connected plays at 10fps since it runs the lowest person's performance

- Hoses and fuel can be buggy (With limited fuel activated)

- Advanced/Basic ship system. Some ships are built with "Advanced Vehicles" disabled which means there are incompatabilities if you are running with advanced options enabled/disabled

- Water physics can break stuff on your boat, like cargo boxes, NPC's and other attached items

- Vanilla missions get repetitive

This game, it's complex, rough, hard to play but also fun, enjoyable, even challenging in many ways.

While the casual modes allow for really fun and complex things to be made, the advanced mode increases this by a factor of 3. This does mean that difficulty can be an issue since the learning curve requires youtube videos to figure out how to make some things but also the simple mode can give you the freedom to make mistakes without wondering why and watching a lot of videos to catch up.

This game was worth it to me on sale and at full price, it's not a game that'll keep your attention as long as something as factorio or space engineers but it's decent enough to have fun with friends on and it's an experience on it's own.

It has bugs, sometimes a great many but it's playable enough to consider a decent game still, try it, have fun with it and enjoy what you can with it. The game is still expanding and with player mods will expand even more.

It's pretty awesome. The graphics are kind of subjective. You either like the style or don't. Personally, I think they're pretty okay, and serve the game well enough. At times, they're even downright beautiful. Either way, the big thing here is gameplay, and it's good. Really good. I just have to say this though... DO THE TUTORIAL. Building ships and vehicles and upgrading them on the workbench is so awesome once you get the hang of it, but without doing the tutorial for a basic understanding, or looking up some guides, it's super easy to get frustrated (or maybe that's just me, because I'm a big dummy). My second recommendation is to avoid the Workshop content for a while. A lot of it is broken, and I also feel like if you're not using your own creativity and problem solving ability, you're missing out on a large part of what this game is. Now then... onto to the other part: The actual missions. So far what I've seen are all really diverse, or at least randomized enough that things stay interesting. The dynamic weather and ocean are formidable opponents. Taking my slightly modified tutorial speedboat out on her maiden voyage to deliver some parts to the nuclear plant, got real interesting real quick when a storm brewed up and the seas got rough. I'm honestly surprised I didn't capsize, though I did have to go swimming after my cargo a few times. I felt an honest sense of relief when I got them delivered. USPS ain't got **** on ME!!! Seriously though, this game is something special and I can't wait to see what else the devs do with it.

can u plz optimize for AMD!!!! PLZ make this priority!!!!!!!! My buddy has the amd a8-6600 could u at least optimize it for this processer. Im willing to send back feedback on how it works..... PLZ HELP

Stormworks...

Stormworks...



Where to start honestly.



Alright then the music.


The music is really cool and intense, the music also start when you do something such as entering workbench or starting a mission.



Price.





Yes as I last recall coastguard carnival simulator admission prices are $25 which is quite reasonable.







Community.





Eh..




naggy



But that's not anyone's fault thats just happened because youtubers play the game and a whole lot of 6 yr olds start playing and know nothing.






Quality.




Graphics are simple, HOWEVER they are so because of the high pc requirements for the water physics etc.




UIs (User Interfaces / Menus) Very well done the UIs are easy to understand and looker very clean and polished, starting from scratch is easy as many buttons have clear descriptions, the workbench UI is well managed and neat, however a few items lack descriptions which needs to be changed however the game is in early access so small things slip through.




Game fun.


This game is very fun and by my nearly 500 hrs you can tell, the game is realistic making it very hard but also extremely satisfying when something goes right.




PC power requirements.



Ahhh here we are...


The game recomends a minimum i5 6th gen with 4gbs of ram.

Disclaimer, if you don't mind low-ish graphics and the in-ability to spawn some large ships or massive creations or maybe many many small creations without lag then sorry.

Minimum I have seen the game run is on a i3 8th gen 8gbs ram, but with 0fps.

I currently use a i7 quad core with 32 gb ram and I am fine.

I also use on my laptop a i7 quad core with 16gb ram.

Any i5 6th gen + should be fine.

Anything below = CERTAIN 0FPS.


And no of course a chrome book can't run Stormworks.


But what if you have a Mac?


Some macbooks can run Stormworks well.

Most struggle for FPS.


The Mac desktops are OK but not great at running the game.


Overall.


For good FPS to vehicle count / size ration use a custom built PC with minimum i7 core or above.



Multiplayer.




Multiplayer us being developed and currently has a lot of issues.


A player count above 3 players is a bad idea.


optimal player count is 2.


Multiplayer has a few bugs in terms of teleporting and stuffs.


Multiplayer framerate is dependent on the two PCs and internet connection.


Fast internet connections isn't the only factor or the main factor.


PC speed is.




Difficulty.


Hard.

Well let me rephrase that.


Hard to be good.


Thats better.


Good creations are hard, bad ones are easy.





Gameplay.


Career is challenging and time constrained.

Creative is fun and exciting but can be frustrating.

Hardcore is downright hard af.




Update speeds.


The game gets a minor update weekly every Saturday depending on where you live.

A major update is released every couple months or sooner.





Devs.



The developers are always responding to questions and are quite kind.







The developers listen to ideas btw.




Overall worth.



9.5 / 10 


Why 9.5?


because the game isn't perfect.


nothing is..

I love this game but multiplayer is horrendous. I've done all the suggested methods of improving multiplayer performance to having the best computer host with best internet to making sure all the ocean features are to the minimum. To no avail nothing has helped. Now it's be forgiven if it was a recognized issue, but it's not. All the discussions within the community on the subject lead to no conclusion or a lambastment of the OP on how they need to upgrade or don't play the game online at Starbucks. Single player runs great but who wants to do a mission that requires a helicopter alone. And all the updates its just add-ons and new features and nothing addressing the multiplayer issue. As soon as multiplayer is fixed I'll be changing my review to positive.

Stormworks is basically a building game in which you make vehicles to perform (mostly) coastguard type missions. The missions you complete can be anything from delivering critical supplies to rescuing submariners and putting out big fires. The vehicles you can build range from simple boats to massive ships, helicopters, airplanes and even (oddly enough) trains and now rockets.

As well as playing in the sandox "creative mode" you can play a career mode in which you accumulte research points for different parts (like Kerbal Space Program) and money for the different bases. The career mode also offers options such as a survival and permadeath mode. The missions offer a lot of variety and the map is HUGE: To get to the relatively new Arctic area, you can spend upwards of 30 minutes on a reasonably fast train.

The building can be done in either basic or advanced modes. I've only 'dabbled' in basic mode so most of the following refers to that. All building is done with blocks and creations can sometimes look a little 'minecrafty'. There are lots of different kinds of blocks, lots. After building your boat (or other creation), you'll need to give it engines (which need a fuel and air supply, exaust and a connection to a propellor). You'll need to connect the engine and a rudder to a pilot seat to control the boat. Then you'll need to provide every part with electricity. And this is just a basic boat. If it sounds daunting, it's because it is, at least at first. After practice, it does become clear how much thought has gone into the interface and the feeling of satisfaction at having a working boat is great.

I love Stormworks. I love that you can get into your creations and walk around, I love the complexity, I love the variety. In fact, this may be my favourite game of the last five years. But, as you might have guessed, my main gripe at the moment is the accessibility. I want this game to be successful, it deserves to be. While adding tips etc. may be pointless at the moment due to it constantly changing, by 1.0 they HAVE to have decent and wide ranging in game tutorials - rather than relying on the (admitedly superb) tutorials available on youtube by fans of the game.

Stormworks: Build and Rescue is a game where you can build your own ships, helicopters, planes, and even land vehicles - and then play missions with them. As the game title suggests the focus is on rescue and emergency service vehicles. 

There are two modes in the game for building: 
The first one is the normal mode. This mode is very helpful for new players and makes it easy to build functioning vehicles and to learn how to build vehicles that dont look like a painted box with an rotor on top. ;)

The second mode is the advanced mode. In this mode you can build more advanced creations with for example own jet engines and stuff. If you are new to the game i would recommend you to bring some patience, because you will need a few trys to make your creations work.

I strongly recommend watching some youtube videos in order to learn how the advanced building system works.
As an alternative  you can download other players workshop creations and see how they are built, or directly play with them.

When it comes to mission playing there are multiple missions given by the game. The workshop offers even more missions.

I really enjoyed every minute of playing Stormworks. For me the game was totally worth the price.

I have played many different voxel based games and physics sandbox type games, and this one is so amazing that it feels like a dream.  The complexity of advanced mode is very satisfying for those of you who are into that.  There is a lot of nuance in how you integrate the components with one another and with the control inputs for the pilot / driver / captain.  The developers have done an outstanding job in making things intuitive despite how much potential there is for complexity in vehicle design.

The real kicker that makes this game shine, in my opinion, is that there is a lot of fun, dynamic gameplay to actually put your designs to use.  This gives an excellent sense of accomplishment for things that you work hard on.  Many games in this genre allow you to create things, but the world around you feels somewhat emtpy.  However, Stormworks does an excellent job of providing a sense of purpose, challenge, and progression.

I love this game. 

Let's take a look at why:

You build vehicles such as ships, locomotives, cars, trucks, airplanes, jets and helicopters. 

In Advanced Mode, you also build the working parts of those vehicles such engines, cooling, drivetrain, electrics, piping, transmission, ECU, computers, radars, sonars, etc.

The best part is that you have missions to test the things you built and then you can easily share them on the Steam Workshop.

If you like Space Engineers but feel you lack something to do with your ship once built, Stormworks is right for you...except there's no space stuff but you know...

All mechanics work very close to the real world so if they built it in the real world, you can probably build it too.

Stormworks is a fun, openworld Search & Rescue game. It features a career mode in which you are required to complete missions to earn cash and make bigger boats and do more missions. Creative mode allows you and your friends to build and test anything you want. The game has issues with lag when a big or complex enough vehicle is spawned in but reduces when out at sea. The devs of Stormworks are focused on adding content but still have yet to release an optimisation patch to help deal with the lag. I would reccomend the game as long as you aren't going to play with more than two other people because the framerates start to make the game unplayable. Singleplayer mode is well optimised but the servers need some touching up.

This is a very fun game. The physics are good and the editor is quite easy to use after a bit of learning. Overall, the game can be a bit complex and vehicles may require super human reflexes depending on what you are doing. This in mind you should be prepared to either press a lot of buttons, or work out potentially complicated control systems for your vehicles. Alternatively, you could let the workshop do that for you. The campaign mode is fairly relaxed most of the time, allowing you time to do what you please and collect the boxes of new parts around the map while also having to be ready for potentially urgent tasks. Creative mode is a good place to learn about mechanics and test designs without worry.

Stormworks is a great game for those who just want to derp around and build ships, planes, trains, cars/trucks, amphibious vehicles, submarines, anything really. There are fairly regular updates that either fix or add content (though at the same time break other things they fix but hey, no one is perfect!) Another nice thing is that the Devs actually have their own public discord where you can meet other creators and even ask the devs some questions or even find help from the community! 

There's still some things I'd wish for them to add in, but time will tell if they do or do not. Overall, this game is fun, especially with friends, you're not just limited to "search and rescue", you can also make custom missions with your own parameters, or you could just set sail and explore the world! If you like building (especially ships) I'd highly recommend this game to a group of friends, that way you can share in the hairbrained ideas and experiences that are bound to take place once you enter the vehicle workbench and let your ideas flow! Granted there are some bugs here and there but the devs are actively looking to try and make the game better every day!

This is an amazing game and I have a lot of fun but now I'm frustrated beyond belief and the engine/electric nerfs in recent patches. 
I was able to deal with the slight waterjet nerf awhile ago by adjusting my power sets. Before patch 0.7.10 every craft I had ran with very efficient diesel-electric or all electric powerplants and I had impressive ranges on everything. After the 0.7.10 patch, I couldn't get more than a kilometer (if i could get off the ground/out of harbour) before I ran out of power. I tried every combination of engine, gearbox and generator that I could fit into my main crafts and unless I went pure diesel I couldn't produce enough power to move far. The Devs have completely destroyed any chance of a true diesel-electric hybrid that a lot of ships are. Obliterated electric submarines to where we are back to cold-war tech with diesel engines but can't do much submerged. Before the nerfs, I would recommend the hell out of this game. Now? Absolutely not.

Huh its been 67 hours already? Well first off ill give you a brief overview of the game. Stormworks is a physics, vehicle building, logic, simulationish game about creating boats, ships, helicopters, planes, cars, trains, cranes pretty much anything that you can think of that you would need to: rescue people stranded at sea, put out boat fires, explore the ocean floor and put special equipment there and thats just to name a few things. Go crazy make a boat that holds a boat that hold another boat. Also the game has logic gates that are very easy to use and understand so its a decent place to get some circuits/logic experience.

Edit: I happen to notice a lot of comments talking about the batteries and electric power. I cant speak for how it was before but I create advanced boats with the current build of the game based only on the tutorial and my knowledge of how smaller boats, like watersport and small offshore fishing boats, work and my batteries work fine they dont drain, I cant speak for making an electric only ship cuz I havent unlocked the last tier electric equipment but a normal ship works exactly how an experienced boater would expect, and yes a brand new starter battery will drain very very rapidly trying to start an engine that refuses to do so. Within a minute for sure.

As of this review

Pros:
Decent graphics
Good physics

Cons:

Good game, worth the current $20 price. Graphics aren't amazing, but the actual core gameplay is awesome right now. I've played for 25 hours at the time of posting this and I am thoroughly hooked. If you enjoy building games like Kerbal Space Program and Factorio, you'll probably love this. It has a similar feel to KSP around version 0.19 - the core mechanics are there, the game is already fun, but there's still plenty of room for polishing and improvement.

A few interesting things of note in no particular order:

[list]
[*] When the weather gets windy, the waves can really pick up and you may find yourself going up and down hills of water on a speedboat trying to reach an injured fisherman to get them to a hospital.

[*] It looks like the devs are doing weekly updates.

[*] Advanced mode is for people who love to get into the nitty-gritty. Pipes are used to connect power and fluids, so hooking up a basic diesel engine would involve coolant in, coolant out, fuel in, air in, exhaust out, and power out. You'd then probably want a gearbox and clutch before you connect it to your propeller or rotor. Builds can get beautifully complicated rather quickly in advanced mode.

[*] Have you ever played a game with robotic parts and wished you could hook them up to sensors to get them to automatically activate? This game has that. You can also build your own microcontrollers for them using logic gates, latches, etc. or even using Lua scripts.
[/list]

There are a lot of YouTube videos out there if you want to learn to play the game or just see what it's like, so give those a try if you're still on the fence about picking this up.

By a long way, this is the best "engineering" sim/sandbox of recent years, its a beautiful combination of simple and sharp visuals, fantastic dynamics in the day and night cycle, the beautiful environment (from peaceful coloured sunsets, to dark grey storms that will RUIN your creations) everything here is really well done. Of particular highlight are the vehicle systems, starting with a truly superb editor that makes it easy to transition from designing small vehicles, right the way up to huge tankers and aircraft - but beyond that, its the integration of the systems in advanced mode that make it so satisfying, designing your own logic and control systems, firing data down composite networks, and feeding video up from hard-to-see places - its an absolutely joy to play, and a beautiful place to be.

Highly recommended to budding "engineers" bored of the usual grind. Amazing work by the devs, really excited to see how it develops :)
