And you can sink your ship with a blow or 2 from the megalodon. Highly recommended.

I love this game! When I first bought it, I found that it had graphics, and physics like none other. Just the way that the water filled rooms on ships, and the way that aircraft flew... it was amazing! At first, I didn't think I could make anything, but after they added the advanced vehicles, I decided that I should give it a shot. I threw myself into the deep end, and I've made several successful vehicles on the workshop. These vehicles include helicopters, cars, and airplanes. After just a few days of experimenting, it all started to make sense.

Even if you can't understand the way that things are built, you can simply go to the workshop and download things. With the constant development and updates, new programming and automation can be incorporated into creations. The creations are becoming more and more advanced, and there are so many that it's impossible not to find one that doesn't fit your needs! It's a great game, with a great community behind it!

As for some of the negative reviews, most of the people posting them have very few hours on record. One complained about it being hard to make things. I assume that they didn't know about the workshop. not to mention the fact that creations do NOT have to be complex and super over-engineered. My most successful creation is one of my simplest. It has well over 1,000 downloads at the time that I am writing this. Trust me, with a little time put into experimenting and testing, anything is possible. Also, the developers are by far the best developers I've ever seen! It's not often that you see a development team that actually listens to what the players want in the game!

I love this game, you may not, but I ask that you give it a try. Thank you for your time.   :)

One of the best games out there if you like open-world physics games!

The good:

- Building stuff is simple

- With some creativity, you can build practically anything

- One of the few games whose waves are actually an obstacle

- Simple yet charming graphics

- Weekly updates

- Devs actually listen

- Few bugs and few glitches

- Steam Workshop support

- Decent amount of customization (not great, but better than some games)

There are a few aspects of this game that need some polishing - infinitely strong fuel hoses capsizing massive ships, winch ropes passing through and getting stuck in just about everything, random backflips and sinking after low speed contact, but I can see myself coming back to this game for years to come. I love the problem solving aspect of designing logic systems, drivetrains, fluid handling and ballasting. I love the customisable and flexible LUA, sensors, microprocessors and propulsion. I love the way the weather and wave physics interact with my creations. I love testing the things I build against the rescue missions the game generates, and I love exploring the world as it expands. The Devs seem to be providing regular updates, both resolving existing issues (hopefully they'll get to the ones listed above soon), and adding new features all the time.
I would highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys solving problems through an engineering or creative lens, and any enthusiast of vehicles large and small.

Excellent game, with endless hours of fun for both the expert and the newer player because of the customizable difficulty levels. 

Various logic blocks, along with ways to create advanced logic systems (memory r/w, switch boxes, PID controllers) exist. There is even a Lua code box within microcontrollers which allows you to make basic Lua scripts. These can draw on top of video feeds, allowing you to create overlays other things.

Best of all, the game has basic fluid simulation, which prevents sealed compartments from filling, and damaged or open comparments from slowly filling with water. The game also has basic pressure simulation for air and water.

There is a simple mission based campaign mode (Like Kerbal Space Program), with a tech tree if that's your thing.

Some cons however are a slightly laggy multiplayer, which has some bugs but generally is stable. Vehicles also do not break into pieces on impact, the physical shape of the boat remains the same. However, parts can get damaged which reduces their functionality.

Overall the game is a great buy. It does not go on sale due to strict no-sale policy, so get it while you can before a planned price increase sometime in 2019 I believe.

[u]Pros:[/u]
~ Great Dynamic Weather (Foggy, Windy, Heavy Rain, Light Storm, Heavy Storm)
~ Adjustable Day/Time Cycle Speeds
~ Fantastic Physics Dynamics (e.g. Shape of Boat changes handling, up/downwind affects flying, etc)
~ Sample & Advance Building Modes, making it suitable for all levels of building skills
~ Simple, but effective graphics that suit this kind of game.
~ Good Music & SFX
~Actively being updated plus Content being created for the game

[u]Cons:[/u]
~ Big learning curve and takes awhile to settle in
~ Not much of a Story, as it's currently just a progression Sandbox or Creative
~ Building can be slightly frustrating
~ When using Larger builds, it can put pressure on your system making it lag/crash from time to time
~ Good Selection of items to use, but... still needing a lot more. 

[u]Overall:[/u]

I've been looking for something to get my Engineer Mind into, and with a lot of let downs I was starting to give up. Until, I came across this savour! Not only has it got a good building and logic system to make more or less anything, the gameplay really makes the game shine! 

At this moment, I've only played 50 hours in both Career & Creative but I can say for sure, this is worth the money! I understand it's in Alpha, but really has been worked on by some great Devs! They have been listening to the Community for Suggestion and the Workshop has some great creations from it's community!

Regardless if you've never played an in depth building game before, or you have played these types of games for years. This is one of the best in my library and I am addicted too it! 

Only problems I found is that it can get a bit laggy with some larger builds and doesn't work that well on some certain gaming rigs. You need a computer with a good Processor and GPU to get smooth gameplay. Other than that, its just got the standard bugs you find in any Early Access game. 

So is it worth it?  Hell yes! Get it cheap while you can! You will not regret it!

Its a pretty good game. I would recommend it for everyone, it does require a little logic as there are a lot of things you need to learn, but you will learn it as you go on. The game has a Career mode which is basically campaign mode, limited resources, money, etc.
There is also a Creative mode, where you pretty much have unlimited everything and a creative menu, which you can use to edit the weather and time, you can also spawn a tsunami which is pretty fun. The main selling point of this game is the creativity and the vehicles you can make (and download off the steam workshop). This game doesnt require you to have a NASA computer but is pretty laggy at times when you have really big builds and when your at your dock/airfield, once you go away from it, it shouldnt lag as much with huge vehicles.

The satisfaction in this game comes from creating and engineering vehicles to serve different purposes. Just know that the missions themselves are not going to make this game enjoyable. The missions aren't amazing, but building a vehicle and being able to then use it on missions is pretty fun.

It's a promising vehicle sandbox game with a lot of advance functionalities, probably more than any other similar games out there already. No there is no weapon yet, and from what I heard it won't be the priority for development.

But what really makes this game shine is the dev behind it. I read from Wireframe (nice game magazine btw) that the dev is a very small group, but the rate they pump out updates is just astonishing. AND every few updates there would be a game changing feature added to game.

And the game also supports custom controllers (hotas stick, driving wheel with clutch), which I think is a big plus compare to other vehicle building games. It just makes controlling your plane/car so much easier if you happen to have those controllers for other games. 

It does have some cons in terms of fluid simulation and aerodynamics in general (I think the devs are focused on the electronics part right now), but I'm pretty sure they will be addressed soon by those hardworking folks.

This game is an interesting mix of lego like vehicle building and rescue sim with interesting weather effects and a nice large sandbox world with plenty to do and see.

The big problem is the game runs really slowly with anything more than a small vehicle in it. I can just about run it with a medium sized rescue boat or helicopter but as soon as you get anything larger the game really starts to slow down and lags badly. Put a container ship into it and it is impossible to play it.

Practically all of the user-made models don't work as they come, even the devs made examples are broken in some way. You usually have to alter them in some way to get them to work properly - sometimes the engines dont start, sometimes the various controls are not connected properly, sometimes you cant even get inside the vehicles. I dont know whether this is deliberate to force you to work on them yourself, but when all you want to do is import and model and try it, it does get a bit frustrating after a while when it happens to nearly every model you get.

Another issue is the rate of increase in difficulty - when you start you begin with something small like a speedboat, but the games missions soon force you to make a plane or a helicopter or a submarine, often requiring a working winch or water cannon system, etc. And that is when the problems start, because making one of those complex vehicles, that will actually work properly, is very difficult compared to making a boat or a car. The missions need to be designed a bit more of a friendly manner for beginners or non-qualified engineers.

Overall the basis of the game is quite fascinating, but if devs cannot figure out how to optimise the game it's not going to be possible to play it. Its a natural thing to soon want to start building very large and complex vehicles. Presently you just cannot do that. So its a great idea but they really need to figure out how to make it practical with today's computing technology.

I've played more than quite a bit now so I thought it was time to leave a review. My favourite type of games are games where you have to use creative skill and logical thinking to make something usefull, and then use it. If you're one of those who gets hooked on games like minecraft, space engineers or general building games, then this is perfect for you. 

The game is still in development, and you will notice that, but the amount of content and quality is still more than enough to make it worth your time. The developers have lots of first hand contact with the community over discord and release new updates every week with either new features like new building components or stuff like additions to the world or campaign gameplay. There's a huge world to discover and you'll be impressed by how detailed the physics is within stuff like airodynamics, fluid pressure, temperature and even underwater pressure. Pumping water out of an airlock while 200 meters under the ocean will no doubt take some time. 

The community is small enough for you to easily come in contact with people on discord and share knowledge as people are always willing to help. Which is good since the learning curve might be a bit steep, but there's some good tutorial lying around to help you get started. And to quote an old slogan from a well known building game: "The only limit is you imagination", and your pc specs, and your skill level, but you'll get there.

Got a mission to deliver a fisherman to a fishing boat. Picked him up, ransacked every house in the village but found no loot. Disappointed. Jumped in my trusty rescue boat and heading out to the fishing boat. Had previously made some tweaks to my engine and got distracted looking at my gauges and accidentally plowed into the fishing boat at full speed, capsizing it. Managed to toss the fisherman into the water nearby - cha-ching - and got paid. That's when I saw the sharks circling. Tried to rescue the crew to no avail; the captain was trapped in the cabin and drowned, the sharks did for the rest. Took my hard earned pay and scampered off. Frankly they shouldn't have been parked there.

Next mission was to medivac a worker on an oil tanker. Cruised on out in my boat and hopped aboard. Thought the tanker looked nice so I commandeered it and slooooowly cruised off to the hospital. Ran it aground on the beach, grabbed the sick worker in a fireman's carry and ran up to the hospital. Cha-ching! Payday again.

Honestly not sure which part is more fun; spending hours designing and tweaking vehicles (advanced mode only please) or goofing off during missions. Really fantastic game.

A good bit of fun, you'll need to have a decent GPU, however. I have a HD 7850 2gb running at stock speeds, and it struggles with the game running ~40 fps at lowest settings. Optimization is a tad bit of a problem, hopefully they'll improve it.

I've decided to update this review because the first one didn't do enough justice to why this game is so great. It doesn't have super fancy graphics or needless violence but what it does have is charm and wonderful mechanics all packed into a wonderful idea!

The premise is simple: Build a vehicle and do some missions, Start on basic, Build a boat, get across the pond and get some money.

Easy right? throw in some waves, weather effects that can blow you out the air or even down into the sea or giant tsunami's that feel the need to impose RIGHT as you have that final survivor literately danging from your helicopter barely able to make it high enough without being blown back into the ocean!

what about a submarine? sure you can build that, Make it nice and air tight maybe throw some seats in there.

Well that's what this game is, Its testing you and your friends to build a stupidly accessible amount of vehicles and to beat the objectives around the world map as you grow your rescue company or just mess about in sandbox! There are alot of details i'm missing out like the need to keep warm or you'll die of hypothermia, you cant be in the ocean too long exposed or you'll get torn to shreds or hell even just building a ship that doesn't sink in the port but all this is something everyone should atleast try once.

It might not be a high octane battle royale or a serious FPS shooter but you will be sweating like a fat man at a buffet when that tsunami decide's to smack your little speed boat into the nearest rock because life's just unfair :^)

and if that doesn't interested you just check out the workshop for some serious fun toys~

I've had this game for less than two weeks, and already have over 70 hours. This is a gem of a game. Read some of the other reviews for in depth reviews, they're all quite accurate. As someone who's always been into building things, and has a love for mechanical things like cars and boats, this is absolutely perfect. Being able to customize every little part about your own ship and being able to sail across the ocean in something you're proud of, is something really cool. There is a steep learning curve with the advanced ships feature, but after getting used to it, it is the only way I play. Very fun game! There are a couple minor flaws, as others have said since it is Peer to Peer servers, if one person in the session is laggy (internet lag, or even alt-tabbing), everyone else gets it. Also, since I mainly play on multiplayer, i've gotten to have a love hate relationship with grabbable objects, such as fuel hoses, or handles. If you are not the host these objects will move about 1/4 of the speed as host, so refuelling your own ship can be a hassle at times.

I'd rate it a solid 9.5/10

Hello Stormworkers!

Thanks for reading my review.

This is one of the best SANDBOX GAMES ive ever seen (Beside Brick Rigs)

Everything has been made so nice, the physics looks pretty realistic, the builds from the Stormworks Community is amazing, and it even has Multiplayer (but sadly no Servers)

Multiplayer is ok, atleast we can play with 6 Players (incl. Host), but it can be really laggy, looks like the Multiplayer could still need some optimization, or Servers like in GTA ONLINE.

The only thing i dont like so much is, that damage is just shown as scratches, and nothing can fall apart or get a hole inside the hull, and that there are no bigger editors, for bigger vehicles.

But i still can recommend this game to everyone who like playing physic sandbox games.

Small Pro/Contra List:

Pro:

+Good physics
+Multiplayer
+You can build everything you can imagine
+Has surrival, and advanced technology and logic
+Great replayabillity
+Nice and active community
+Developers wich listen to the community
+Frequent updates and patches
+Nice and huge map (now with arctic biom)
+Discord Server where you can also meet the developers
+Bug Report and Feature Suggestion Tool is avaiable direct in the main menu
+Has big possibilities, and its still in early access

Contra:

-Laggy Multiplayer with only 6 Players (I would expect more players,
because for some missions and activities we could need more players)
-Some bugs (but sometimes really funny, like flying ships)
-Too small editor space

One of the things, the game could need, is some more weather systems, like tornadoes, and some natural disasters, to bring bit more action in the game.

Thanks again to all who read it completely till to the end.

Very big thanks to the developer for the game and all their time and work, the developers, the community, and the workshop creators have invested, to make the game like it is at the moment, and i hope there is coming alot more updates and stuff like that^^

Basically its a great game with a lot of features. Its also a lot of fun to play with friends.

Do you like:

1) ...Lego Technic?

2) ...the hit animated children's early 00's cartoon, Rescue Heroes?

3) ...entire rooms dedicated to large, elaborate train loops?

4) ...those weird, highly specific simulator games Europeans foam at the mouth over?

5) ...your job as a plumber?

6) ...to ignore your duties and get messages pop up telling you how someone in the Arctic froze to death because you can't reach the mission site as you haven't gotten away from your starter island?

7) ... make submarines specifically to crawl up to flaming tankers, then breach the water's surface armed with rows of water-cannons to put out the fire?

If you said yes to any of these, then you will like Stormworks: Build & Rescue. With a simple to learn, difficult to master building system - you build anything from small jet-skis or ski-doos to giant Coast Guard motherships decked out with custom made helicopters, dinghies, rafts among other vehicles. The actual vehicle construction is incredibly minute: You make the hull, distribute the various necessary systems to maintain an engine (air, exhaust, coolant, fuel and engine output), link the various buttons, levers and auto-mated systems to various mechanical and data outputs and then spawn your vehicle, hoping that you linked up all of the internal systems properly.

After your one-rotor transport helicopter turns into a four-rotor fire fighting, diesel-tugging flying aircraft carrier - you must then prepare for various missions with solutions that simply cannot be solved with a single vehicle, causing you to develop your Coast Guard fleet in a way to maximize coverage of your service, lest you stay in bed and skip all the pleas for help as you wait for a mission you can actually handle.

The games visuals are blocky and simplistic, but are nonetheless pleasant to the eyes.

The audio is below average, but it is to be expected when almost nothing is prebuilt and prepared.

The physics are surprisingly robust and thankfully leave out certain aspects of physics that would cause the game to be incredibly difficult/tedious to manage.

The mechanics are fairly easy to learn after a few short tutorial videos or some trial and error and can be applied to any type of vehicle archetype you can think of (trucks, jet skis, helicopters, jets, prop aircraft, gyrocopters, motorboats, corvettes, trains, tug boats, cruise liners, submarines, oil tankers and even rockets). But the depth is presented with a 'redstone' (if you are familiar with Minecraft's 'coding') mechanic that allows for complex interactions between different portions of your vehicle.

Easy: Linking a button to your engine to start it up.

Medium: Connecting a PID Controller to an altitude reader and using it in tandem with a keypad to enter specific coordinates that are then relayed to a helicopters up/down collective system to allow it to auto-level itself at a specific altitude.

Difficult: Entering the scary world of microcontrollers to create an automatic transmission to help reduce lever/button bloat on your submarine's control base.

Overall, despite being an Early Access game, to me it shows a similar effort and quality put forth similar to other successful Early Access games like Rimworld. I would also recommend it to parents of kids who like the mechanics of various types of vehicles as the game can provide an excellent outlet of creativity. It completely lacks any sort of typical violence presented in modern games, as all the missions involve rescuing people or cargo from precarious situations.

The game is currently an 8/10 for me, but might possibly reach higher as more parts, missions and mechanics are introduced!

So I havn't played much yet, im about 17 hours into the game. I bought it originaly thinking Id play for a weekend to give me something to do but I dont think other reviews give the complexity and what you can do in this game justice. The game gives you a whole set of sensors and mechanical parts to play with. With them you can design and build just about anything.  I just finished adding a cruise control system to my boat complete with input consoles and displays so you can just input coordinates and the boat will drive there. It comes complete with a micro-controller design system that lets you add pretty much any logic you can think of (It even includes memory, flip-flops, clocks, control logic, you could design and build a fully functioning cpu with it).

Want to make a pool with pumps and buttons that can fill to differn't points? Can Do

Want to make a deployable rescue system that detects when the boat is sinking opens hatches and launches lifeboats? Can do

Want to make a boat that deploys a roof in the rain? Yup

Want to build a crane on your boat for moving aircraft up onto the deck of your carrier? That works

Spent 7 hours and was repeatedly stymied by bugs. I never really got used to the slidey (icecube on a skillet) interaction with the ground. Most of the time I spent on this game was troubleshooting undocumented arbitrary things like how the generator can't be used inline with a drive shaft and why do my wheels freak out when they touch the ground. It will take you longer than the refund maximum of 2 hours to find out that this game is a poor facsimile of From the Depths or other physics sandbox games in its current state.

Pros:
-Fresh art design

Cons:
-Almost no documentation
-Bugs are present that would not normally be in a game this far along (As in why introduce trains and such when the career mode is still so far from playable)
-The physics "Feel" is uncannily slidey and erratic. (No crisp movement, and stuff often freaks out when they collide even slowly)
-Too expensive, spend $10 max

Great game

This is basicly “LEGO technic - the game” with procedurally generated missions where you save people, put out fires, transport etc.

You can build pretty much any type of machine that moves on this earth, car, truck, train, plane, jet, helicopter, ships from dingeys to submarines and aircraft carriers (although the build areas are too small for real sized ones they can be quite large anyway).

You have engines, rail tracks, wings, rotors, magnetic grabbers, propellers, water nozzles and highly customizable programmable blocks to play with, I’ve played a tidy amount of Space Engineers which is similar to this but in space and I have to say this runs smoother and has better tools for building than it does. 

One thing to say however is that troubleshooting your creations that don’t work properly can be a ‘beach’ and you might spend hours trying to get something really complex working, and the game really doesn’t hold your hand.
An example: I just spent a couple of hours building my first jet engine on a test bed, but the engine wouldn’t start, I racked my brain but decided to google a tutorial instead of doing it the hard way, turns out I had placed the components in the correct order but I had thought the arrow that indicates air flow direction was indicating traveling direction so I had to turn each component 180 then redo all the fuel piping since it no longer lined up. That took me 2-3 minutes, if I had decided on trial and error it might have taken hours before I had figured it out.

9/10 would sail away into the sunset with this game.

Game's awesome, the logic and the parts building are pretty sound (Even if the part rotation needs some work in my opinion) 
Nothing like building something in this game and seeing it work and going to take out to the seas to see what will break first.

Singplayer is fantastic but the multiplayer needs some work. The sync issues and the lag is horrible and anything bigger than a small speedboat will lag the game crazily bad for all parties. Because of the Peer to peer system the game has right now.
Which causes some weird things to happen for the non-hosts. Like tethering is near impossible with how the networking works right now.

Game is very fun, and if the multiplayer is fixed it will be a gem.

This is a great game. One of the best games out there and it has steam workshop and amazing creations. I would buy it again and again.

There are two parts to this game - the vehicle building and the missions you get to use these vehicles in.

If you play in "Advanced Vehicles" mode - the building part is outstanding. The tools for it are great, the editor works really well and the copy/paste functionality and ability to have modular blueprints is amazing. For example - I can design an engine setup of 16 engines and the panel to control them, then copy and paste that into a different ship. I can then paste in my gearbox controls and paste in my pilot seat setup from an existing build.  This takes the bulk of tedium out of the process - you never really find yourself building the same thing for 20th time.

Really I can't say enough good things about the building tools and the flexibility they offer. The parts selection is vast to the point of being overwhelming. In short, whatever plane, ship or chopper you want to build - you can do it here. In fact, you can build flying ships if you're so inclined...

So here comes the bad part - you built your amazing vehicle - and decide to do some missions - that'll be fun right?

Well - it's not. The bulk of the missions are hauling runs, take 4 scientists from here to there, bring these 4 crates over here. I get it, rescue is about taking things away from danger. Except in the vast majority of these missions, nothing is actually happening. You're just hauling some boxes that you need to pick up 4km away to the drop off point 7km away. Then you get to haul 4 dudes from the village over to the oil rig - all in dull calm weather.

Career mode also falls flat on it's face as the reward pace is very slow. In 20 hours of doing career runs, I still don't have anything bigger than the small engine greatly limiting what vehicles I can create. I guess I could keep putting time in and maybe just maybe I'll eventually get the blueprints I want - but it's slow and every single time you are rewarded with items you already have it's a slap in the face. The dull missions and inability to buy blueprints drag the enjoyment of the game way down.

I really wish all missions had some sort of risk to them, I should never find myself watching netflix while being Sea Uber to a bunch of scientists who want to get to some island. Where is the risk? Where is the challenge? Give me something. Give me something to worry about other than the soul crushing boredom of watching the 6km distance slowly drop to 5....4....

It just isn't fun to run deliveries for hours only to realize that not a single reward you got brought you any closer to building bigger or cooler ships.

There is a mission editor in the game, so I suppose I could fix all those dull missions myself - but it's not really what I signed up for and worse yet - they aren't added to career mode. The bulk of the player base lives in creative and just builds cool stuff - if that is what does it for you - buy this game. You will not find another title with the same level of detail applied to terrestrial vehicles.

Unfortunately if you actually want to have a sense of thrill and excitement when you use your creations, this game will leave you hanging. At least at this time - it's still an EA game and if the devs put the same amount of effort in the missions as the building tool set, it will be pretty good.

In short, I very much recommend this game if you want to play around with building stuff. I can't recommend this game if on the other hand you want to play around with the stuff you build....

I don't write reviews for games. But, hell, I feel like this is needed. 

I cannot stress enough how much Stormworks means to me. This is a fantastic game that really lets me allow my creativity to flow. The Singleplayer, while others claim it's boring, allows me to test designs and build to my heart's content. The multiplayer is equally as enthralling, especially when my friends and I are trying to build something ridiculous. Many laughs have been had there. 

Forever, I've felt like I've had so many ideas in my mind of stuff I wanted to make (I used to love Legos as a kid) but I'm not too awful capable of drawing anything/physically making anything. My hands just don't work like my brain wants 'em to. But, Stormworks presents an easily accessible outlet for those vehicle designs and brings them to life. 

I do have a few quarrels with the game. The sizes on some of the basic building blocks can certainly be tweaked. I'd really some smaller blocks just to add a bit of detail, and maybe some rounded ones. Also, the vehicle physics still need a little work, but they're good for what they are. 

Aside from those two things, I find Stormworks to be a true gem and I play it nearly every day after getting yelled at by customers. It's a great, stress-free release. 

Thank you, Sunfire, for this game.

Sincerely,
Dominus

I'll be dead honest. The game is wonderful, it has a niche feel that actually brings me back every time.
The updates have only gotten better and better. I feel as though there is a possibility this game might not be given the popularity it deserves.

But that's where the good part of the review ends.
The only bad thing is the multiplayer. Being PTP, it's overly lackluster and runs at the lowest client's performance. Causing numerous issues both with those with mediocre internet and PC's meeting the minimum requirements.

Now, I can imagine someone saying "lul you just have bad net" but I'll slap them with a list of games I enjoy on dedicated servers with zero issues with latency or ping:
-Arma 3
-Battlefield (3,4,5)
-War Thunder
-Minecraft
-Farming Simulator
The list could honestly go on and on.

To me, the content is wonderful, but if you're looking to play with friends and you know that one of you has bad internet, don't tease them. They'll want to give up the moment you get "Player is slowing down the game" messages.

Unique, fun, and challenging gameplay. Create unique machines and vehicles and attempt to carry out all sorts of missions in a fictional seascape.

This game is really like no other game out there. There are multiple gameplay modes, such as creative for those who just enjoy building machines and testing them, to career permadeath survival modes which require you to take care before taking off on your first test flight in your new helicopter.

There is a very brief in-game tutorial that the game requires you perform before you can try other game modes. The tutorial really only covers the Basic version of the game. So Advanced vehicle creation, configuration, and all that it entails is something you'll really have to go looking online for. Luckily there are a ton of YouTube tutorial available, and an official Discord channel to help.

The progression in career mode is fun. You're given a small starting budget, and tasked with some basic missions like ferrying oil rig workers. As you complete missions, you gain money and unlock new parts to create more complex vehicles which can accomplish more difficult jobs such as handling large sensitive science equipment.

Everything factors into the missions. From weather, to time, to distance, to the mission objective itself. Will you have enough fuel? What's the weather like, will your boat be able to handle the rough seas? Will you need more seats than your craft has? Each mission can send you back to the drawing board as you edit and work on your vehicles. Eventually, you'll find yourself handling a fleet of Coast Guard, tanking, and shipping equipment throughout your growing number of owned island ports, and other industries. 

There's also Career mode in multiplayer, but at the moment, there is only one host and that host must be online for the players to continue wherever they last left off. 

The devs are active and post an update about every week with some new content, large or small. 

This game is definitely worth the price if it's something you're interested in.

So, I rarely ever want to give a game a bad review because I made one of the worst VR games in the short history of VR, but I know what it takes to make a game. I gave it a good, solid chance.
Here are my issues with it:
1. It is obvious that the developers know their code but they ignored the first (and really only) rule of gaming: make it fun. It is obvious that they are Type - A personality: very organized people with a strong sense of order and solid ethic - they just lack creativity and the artistic endeavor, to again, make it fun. They jumped on the (terribly overdone) minimalist Minecraft boat (pun internded) and attempted to inject a lot of complicated mechanics.
2. Why do I care how the freaking engine is wired to the battery and why do I all of a sudden have to be an electrical engineer? The game is called Stormworks not Electricianworks.
3. I spent 15 minutes in the tutorial to pick up a stupid crate and then put it in the boat. This was just a load of annoying. Again, not fun.
4. Then I had to spend another 5 minutes driving the boat a seemingly useless 800 billion miles to a hospital. It's like they thought if they made you drive a boat REALLY far that it makes it a BIG game. No. It just makes it annoying. Then I finally get to the pier (remember, this is an unavoidable tutorial that does NOT allow you to open sandbox mode until you finish it). So, I try to jump out of the boat with the annoying box/crate and throw it up on the pier while i jump on the pier (what the hell?) and I'm missing and not understanding these mechanics and at this point I'm beyond annoyed - I'm angry. It's now feeling like I paid to do algebra homework. I run the stupid crate to the stupid hostpital and anti-climactically drop the crate in the dropzone. Woo frikkedy hoo, I gain some random "i-don't-care,-I-thought-I-was-going-to-drive-boats-and- helicopters-in-crazy-weather" parts and money and bluprints and I REALLY don't care., I frikkedy run down to my boat because I can't run fast enough to escape this game and I feel like a spoon-tracheotemy would be more fun at this point. Here's the kicker - I have to then return to my island or whatever, so I try to turn my boat around. What happens? I beach the stupid boat and can't un-beach it. Game over. I'm getting my money back.

Guys, a little friendly advice - stop taking your game so seriously because it comes through in the gameplay. Get outta the office/house, Go get drunk. Get laid. Punch someone in the face (actually, strike that last one - this game already made me want to).

Your game is simply. Just. Laborious. And. Dull. And. Excuciating. I. Want. To. Kill. Myself. Now.

This game has one of the best logic systems out there in a building game, and the developers are adding more. They're actively helping their community with a discord channel and public bug tracker ingame.

It's got a great vehicle building system and lots of missions to test your creations with. You could succeed with something simple, but if you want to go nuts and build something amazing, you can.

I've built working computers in this game and at a managable scale and operational speed, not planet sized and dirt slow to work like it would be in minecraft. Others have built huge scale detailed aircraft and ships.

I would definately recommend this game, it's only getting better.

One of the most interesting games that has taken me by storm. It's still very rough around the edges, and there are a lot of aspects that need significant improvement, but even now there is a lot to do, and a huge variety of challenges to overcome. I personally would recommend having a go at it without the advanced mode first to get a basic hang of the physics, and then enabling it at the earliest opportunity. 

I may have spent roughly 20 hours just honing the finer aspects of a helicopter again and again over a process of fine-tuning and iteration.

Be warned, however, that the netcode at the current time is not gentle for playing across great distances. You will have significant issues interacting in person with any sort of physics prop that exists in the game, though mechanical operation, driving, flying and such seem to not at all be adversely affected.

If you become easily addicted to games like Kerbal Space Program, look no further than Stormworks to indulge in your next creativity-fueled fix.

Brilliant game, of course there is the glitches with boat damage and collision physics (to be expected with an E.A. game) but it is really simple in it's concept and design, the building can take a while to get used to but the creations you can come up with are limitless.
Of course, it is a shame there is a max size a ship can be (unless with custom missions) but I can imagine this is because even ships built in the space you can build can lag up the game until you get to open sea.

I'd love to see the pressure mechanic apply to boats aswell, of course this may mess with submarine creations- but maybe we can apply a press logic module which allows the player to change the pressure of the ocean on the creation- that would be great. Of course that would be expensive in career.

I'd also love to see maps added into the game, there is a map already, but I'd prefer a block which you could place onboard a ship which you can view the entire map without exploring it. Of course the 'm' map can still exist, but the boat map block has it all explored, of course the counter to this could be a more pixelated image.

A story or proper objective would work really well, depending how you go at it, I'd love some sort of story where you explore some under water cave or investigate an anomaly.

I'd also like more diverse creatures instead or just sharks and fish, also- I'd wish they would be a lot more dangerous since sharks spend half the time too far deep in the water, and most the time don't attack you since there is only one or two nearby. Larger creatures like Krakens and Megalodons could roam deeper waters.

Also, block damage I would like to be a lot more interesting, instead of just scratches it would be great if blocks could break off under too much pressure, I would hope this would make rooms vincible instead of invincible, this would work really well with the pressure mechanic I mentioned earlier, with glass breaking or shattering. Hopefully this would make players careful in battering water and create more diverse sinking options.

I would also like wind to rock airplanes or something airbourne, since otherwise planes / helicopters are immune to virtually everything apart from running out of fuel.

That is all I have to say, this game is great and I'd would want to see the playerbase expand. Imagine 8 players in one server all creating flying trains. Overall, there must be a setting that disables / enables the suggestions mention. Since it would help people to do roleplay or whatever in an undersea base. Or a flying base in the sky.

This game has gone so far in it's development, and I never anticipated it to be as good as it is now. The features that attracted me to this game was the building ( the advance building is very impressive ), the cool missions, the water physics, and how players can walk around ships freely while they are moving without constantly being pushed backwards. I love how the game detects sealed compartments and keeps water from not only visually clipping into them, but also if water does get in, the ship might sink. I am very glad that the devs added trading and trains, because this opens a whole new world of economy. Previously, there was not a very good use for cargo planes for example, other than maybe supply drops that haven't been added yet. But now I can see the devs adding products to buy/sell like wooden crates that would be perfect for a cargo plane to transport. They have currently added the ability to buy/sell fluids like oil that make oil transport ships and tank train cars very effective as an economy tool. As hinted before, I would also love to see physical cargo crates and passengers also as part of the economy. With the direction that the devs are going, this game would be vast because of all the roles that people could play. To name a few: passenger train, cargo train, coast guard ship, fire-fighting plane, rescue helicopter, transport helicopter, transport ship, tanker ship, passenger plane, cargo plane, research boat, research sub, semi truck, bus, and ambulence. The possibilities are endless. They haven't yet added research into the game either, but based on all the trenches and underwater locations, it's almost safe to speculate that the devs have plans for it in the future. That brings me into my next point, the developers of this game. They frequently release new updates, which let's the users know that their purchase of the game very much supports it's development. They are always adding a few interesting features here and there to keep the community interested as well as major updates now and then. The graphics of this game are amazing too. Some people criticize the low poly art, but I appreciate it because in my opinion, it looks great, and my computer is a little outdated so the low poly helps save some frames. I get lag whenever I travel to the nuke reactor. Lag in this game is interesting because the physics engine slows down along with the graphic frames. This means that you won't miss out on any of the action if you do lag, but it is also very boring to complete a mission 50% longer simply because it is at the nuke for my case. As my last point, logic has greatly improved the game. It doesn't matter how good you are at using it because there are all degrees of difficulty in your logic creations. You can use simple logic to add interesting lights, more advanced logic to hold and altitude of a plane/ helicopter, or you even have the freedom to create a complex full autopilot for a ship where you simply enter the coordinates of your destination, and the ship does the rest. I recommend this game not only for what it is now, but also for what it will likely become.

Excellent game if you're looking for open ended sandbox gameplay in a career mode style where you do randomly generated missions in a huge map in vehicles you built yourself. I suggest playing in survival mode, because it's so much more satisfying when a vehicle you built, actually works. Survival difficulty has a more advanced building system, for example you have to build systems to make your engine actually work, like cooling, fuel tanks, batteries, generators, exhausts, air intakes, etc, and you have to connect them up with pipes, and some of the stuff you build can be programmed by you, for example gearboxes where you can change the ratio. It is such a good feeling when you built your first working engine, and working vehicle, and complete missions with it. You can make a vehicle as simple or as complicated as you want. You can build anything you can think of. As long as the laws of physics allows it. Oh, and the game has a dynamic weather system, which is great. Some days there is a huge storm, and others is very calm and sunny. 

TL:DR  If you love building simple or complex vehicles and machines, and use them in various missions in a huge open world with dynamic weather, then this is a must have.

This game has been a pleasant surprise for me, I barely had the news of it since it mixes (excellently) two very precious genres for me, construction of vehicles and rescue.
The game engine runs great even in an old system like mine. 
To sum up:

Pros
-Powerful and simple 3D editor to build vehicles
-Undemanding game engine
-Missions mode to unlock parts and resources in the game
-Creative mode
-Wide selection of parts and parts
-The physics manages to transmit the difficulties of the operations according to the climate and the time of day.
-Opportunity to share designs in the Workshop
-Multiplayer (in development)
-Customization of avatars
-Very few Bugs so far (at the moment the developers are active)
-Tutorial

Cons
-Little information about the use of some parts, a manual is missing but this is acceptable due to the early state

Final words
If you are accustomed to early state games then this is a very necessary acquisition, you will love the fast developing pace, constantly adding fixes and new content. If you are a fan of the construction of vehicles with blocks you must also have it and if you like rescue games too.
I think this game stands out from the others similar in the combination that makes the genres, has much of what you can find the avid builder and designer of vehicles and makes it more interesting by giving your designs to have rescue plans to meet.
For me the price is in line with the content presented so far and the possibilities of development are enormous.
Everything will depend on the management of finance of the developers, the success in sales and the participation of the community, if these factors point in the right direction we could be facing a jewel.

This game is a lot of fun to play. If you enjoy building boats, planes, helicopters, submarines, etc then you should get this game! The game has a multiplyer / singleplayer campaign like mode. Theres not a story to it, but you get a certain amount of money to spend and have to do missions to unlock more parts to build with and more money. So a friend of mine asked me if I liked boats, I said "sure, i guess". He recommended this game, it was fairly cheap, i played it. It was cool, then I stopped playing it. Then I started playing it again, and boy are they doing constant updates to it. I've owned it for a few months, and they have done some amazing updates and they just keep coming.

It's fun. Insanely fun. I really haven't done any missions (i've done a few), I spend most of the time building, testing, and tweaking my ships. I've made some ships where you have a jet turbine to haul butt in the sea, but if the turbine becomes damaged, you push a button and out folds some propellors to take you back in. Logic gates have allowed me to detect when my batteries drop below 75%, and initiate a diesal engine which then powers my generators. It's fun.

I recommend the game, the people behind this are awesome with their updates.

This game was quite a bit of fun when I first purchased it and for awhile after that. 

However with recent updates it has become apparent that the developers don't do much play testing before they push out updates. 

There have been so many changes to the core gameplay and how engines work that it's difficult to keep up with and make working ships. The advanced mode content was a very welcome change but has since become a chore as electricity generator, propeller function, and gearboxes received a large nerf. 

Just today the devs released an update where vehicles spawn without fuel and require filling before setting sail. They added a filling station to the stock island but you can't even get the fuel connector over the railing on the side of your boat slip.  Not to mention that once you get it hooked up you have to climb all the way back up to the tank to start the filling process. 

This just demonstrates their obvious lack of play testing of their own updates. This combined with the fact that they push these updates out on Fridays when a lot of people have time to play on the weekends just leads to mounting frustration with this game. 

Seriously.... Give it a pass until it's out of early access. Maybe the devs will get their act together and push less "first-pass" content.

Have you ever been dissatisfied with the state of Space Engineers? Have you ever been wanting to drive a boat while having no idea how? Have you ever wanted to build a base while not playing Minecraft? If so, this is the game for you! This game's music is so good, it rivals even the legend Minecraft. The graphics are also amazing for a sort of low poly game. The physics rival even the best games, such as KSP. For someone who knows little to nothing about boats, I found it easy to master the mechanics (at least not advanced mode) of how to make a boat or base. Also, the fact that this game is multiplayer makes it even better than most games on my PC currently. This is one of the games I highly recommend, along with KSP and Gmod. One thing that would make this game even better would be the addition of weapons for competitive gamemodes, but until then, the game is already an 11/10.

My experience with Stormworks so far is great, i'm a huge fan of sandbox games like this where you can create your own contraptions to achieve your goal, make it as simple or as complex as you want to. Also the workshop have many great vehicles to play arround with or to get inspiration from.

The game also have a survival mode that I still have not tried, but i'm sure can provide a lot of fun for those who wish to get a greater challenge.

Pros:
- Build what you wish, your imagination is your limit.
- Performance seems to be good, at least for me. (on a mac book pro with no dedicated graphics)
- Great value for your money, game has a lot of content allready and gets continually updated with more blocks and features

Cons:
- Game is not in a good balanced state at the moment, for example engines, gearboxes etc (as of November 4 2018)
- Due to early access and frequent update vehicles often break between updates.
- Again, the game is Early access and can from time to time do wierd stuff. This will of course get better over time as development progresses

A little rough around the edges. Very unoptomised, likes to crash. But if you can get over that you'll find a game similar to Space Engineers or Kerbal Space Program. 
It's a lot of fun, with a promising career mode and one of the best building systems I've ever seen. If you like technical stuff, logic nodes, circuit baords all the rest it's a treat. 
In the future I can only see this game getting more and more incredible, my only worry is that the developers become 'stuck in their ways' and don't listen to the community. While at heart it is a rescue game, expanding the destruction so that blocks can be destroyed and adding some form of weaponry would certainly go a very long way in multiplayer sandbox.

I know I said I all but swore off engineering games, but here we are again.

[b][i]Stormworks: Build and Rescue[/i] has all the complexity of any other engineering-based sandbox experience, with a really captivating world and nautical theme.[/b] It isn't perfect and surely feels like an Early Access title, but there is still a lot of neat things going on in here. First off, the artstyle and overall world aesthetic is beautiful. The ocean water physics is the best I've ever seen, and is a high point for the immersion. Being on the ocean in the middle of the night is legit scary sometimes. 

[i]Essentially, while there are a variety of modes, the core 'career' mode has you start with a minimal access to building parts and a small amount of money to modify your ship.[/i] You gain money by doing missions. You find parts scattered around the world. You can alter day/night cycle by sleeping. Weather can change day-to-day, and the world is really neat.

[b]Pros:[/b]
+The artstyle and overall world ambience is beautiful and very immersive.
+The sandbox missions and day and night cycle all work really well to add more 'game' to the engineering/building experience.
+The ocean water physics is the best I've seen.
+Building is easy enough to wrap your head around.
+Steam Workshop is a great touch here.
+Lots of options for everything from building a custom career mode to display options.
+Multiplayer would be fun.

[b]Cons:[/b]
-Needs further optimization.
-I'm not an engineer, but from what I gather - the ship building system is not purely logic/reality based. That's okay for me, but I think some people may want to know that they need to learn this system.
-Dare I say the physics system is about 10% just too wonky or fiddly. Cargo flying all over and losing passengers in some pretty cartoon-ish ways. Again, not a deal-breaker, but something I should mention.

[b]I'm having a good time with this one.[/b]

Its a great game, there's a few things needing to be improved otherwise this game is fun,exciting and a good way to get the creative juices flowing. Can't wait to see the next update, and i cannot wait for new content.

I didn't know what to expect from this game.  I was at first overwhelmed by the looks of the game.  Anything that gets you to design anything is usually a bit much for me.  My creations in other games never really look like much, but this game makes it easy and fun.

First you do the tutorial which covers the bare basics.  Movement and simple design in basic mode.  The tutorial is the bottle feeding before you eat your steak.

After the tutorial you can continue in that game mode or start a new game mode and the difficulty options are plenty.  Sharks, health, fast travel and moving your vehicle back to base are just some of the options you can click.  Also there is starting money, starting island and the other like.  Creative mode and career/survival mode are also tossed in there.

The game is 99% water.  The rest are islands with unique structures.  An island for a hospital, one for a airport, one for a nuclear power plant and so on.  

As you start the game, you design your first vehicle which typically is a boat if you chose the default start.  Missions are given to you either while you're exploring or sleeping.   Mostly of what I've seen is "deliver this person/good to this other location".  Sometimes they get a little redundant, but...they get a little interesting sometimes.  Completing these missions grants you parts/blueprints or money.  Mostly all three at once.  You can have a part in your stock, but if you have the blueprint you can still buy the part if it's not in stock.  Ideally you complete missions, build bigger and more robust vehicles and buy more real estate to support your endeavor.

The world you play in is a little dry.  No AI other than what's involved in your mission.  I would like to see the occasional AI boat/plane or helicoptor go by every once in awhile.  You can explore though.  During your travels you may come across loot crates which can also contain parts and money.

The vehicle building though?  COOOOOOOOOOOL.  I have spent many hours in career and creative mode tinkering with the tidbits.  You want to build an electric ship and charge it with another vehicle?  YOU CAN!  Want to build a sub?  YOU CAN!  Want to build a refueling tanker for helicopters and other ships?  The available tools at your fingertips just amazes me when constructing.

If you want a game that gives you desire to see what you can come up with next then get this game.  Missiones, traveling, building.  What's not to like?   And the game doesn't appear to be dead after the last update that added jet engines.

Was on the fence about this one for ages. Picked it up because why not. No regrets.

You've got an engineering layer that is demanding but also rewarding and extremely versatile. It took me ages to build my first boat in advanced mode, and so help me she's a piece of junk, but she is mine. Few engineering games have that enough of a sense of variety about them to create that sort of a bond. Stormworks lets you get away with building pretty much anything, as long as it floats.

The simulation of the sea is fantastic. Sometimes it's this big comfy blue blanket you can putter around on all day and everybody is friends. Other times the wind, lightning and waves are trying to batter you to death. The only thing stopping them from doing that is the ship, boat, helicopter or whatever other machine you've built to protect yourself. So you need to build it well.

Lastly the world is so wholesome. You transport important cargo, you rescue people, you help people out with their day to day stuff. It's low key and comfy a lot of the time but there's often a life or death situation waiting round the corner. Rescuing people from mother nature throwing a hissy fit is a hugely underrated activity in games.

It's early access and at the point I'm reviewing it reliability is an issue, but it loads up pretty fast and autosaves often so it's more of an inconvenience than the sort of issues that'll cost you hours of design time. It's also pretty easy to play multiplayer with a few friends if one of you has a reasonable PC and connection to host it, you don't need a server. The game handles multiple players on the same vehicle really well too, so playing the missions in a group is easily done and fun.

So, yeah. Highly recommend. Perfect game if you were into things like Space Engineers but wanted better multiplayer and more ways to put your vehicles to use.

PS It looks a lot like Interstate 76. Stampede's poetry would not be out of place here.

I've played a lot of crafting/building games, but this one pushes the bar to a whole new level.

Simultaneously a triumph of both the genre and 'how to do early access right', the development over the last seven months has been nothing short of staggering. Progress is steady, community feedback is given the priority it deserves without overtaking the creative vision of the designers, and the game is kept fresh and interesting with every new update. New mechanics, new concepts, new mission types... the game just keeps on giving every time.

The recent addition of the Survival update put this game on a similar level to Kerbal Space Program for me, in terms of complexity vs reward; the more effort you put into your vehicles, the more versatility they have. The mechanics are intuitive and flexible, the depth possible with creations already trumps anything possible in other sandbox games... whether it's setting up logic circuits to control systems, creating custom doors, or attaching vehicles to each other, Stormworks does it better than 95% of other games that attempt these things.

The vehicle editor is incredibly robust, and it's clear that the creators of the game have a passion for playing other similar games. All of the mistakes you'll see in other, similar vehicle editors are completely absent, replaced instead with more functionality. It's simple to use, intuitive to learn, but rewarding to master; the perfect mixture for keeping building fun.

Having objectives and missions right from the beginning of early access means the game isn't starved for content like most of its peers have been, and makes the game incredibly playable and fun even in its early stage of development. Missions are also available on the Workshop thanks to the Mission Editor, basically giving you a potentially infinite amount of replayability.

The last time a game showed this much potential during an early stage was when I first experienced KSP. For me though, despite not having the ability to travel to space, the flexibility and depth on offer here is far superior. An incredible achievement on many levels, if you have any interest in the genre you owe it to yourself to play it.

Stormworks = I like it ;-)

My first rescue mission was a failure since i had accepted a mission to move and deploy a drone, however i had no machine to lift the drone form land and into the ocean.

My next mission was to pickup 4 inspectors and sail them to another location and i thought that is simple and a good beginner mission but I was very fast reminded that sometimes in life things are not that simple.
The beginning was easy i just sail to an island and ask them to jump into my small boat and off we went, with calm sea and I thought to my self this was a bit ehh borring... But after sailing a few km the weather all of a sudden started changing and the waves become 1-2m high and I kind of enjoyed my self since my little boat was doing pretty good without tipping over or anything due to me being a good skipper.
A few minutes later things changed dramaticly.... the sun went down and night came, and a big storm started out on the ocean and my simple transport mission now all of a sudden turned into a kind of survival kind of thing since I was again and again hit by 10-20m high waves that throw my boat arround and i desided that it was hopeless to sail and instead i turned the boat towards the waves and just lay there still "riding" off the storm.
The storm was a huge surprise to me and i instant knew this game was something special and cool.

After 10-15 minutes like this and saving my people two times from being flushed into the ocean  i think the wind changed direction and all of a sudden i could use the waves and use my boat as a kind of surfboard just sailing on the top of hte wave in the direction i had to go... I fast sail the last 1,5km to shore and was almost dreaming about kissing the island when i see it... To my big surprise it was not an island that was my destinaton but an Oil rig out in the ocean, with 10-20m high waves hitting the legs of it, and the stairs i should climp up was hit by big waves again and again.. actual my little boat even was on top of the waves somethimes up so high that it could have landed on the stairways so some insane waves that no little boat can handle.... But once at a time i "pickup" the inspectors and climp up the stairs and ask them to stay up high while i get the other... But they did not always listen and was ripped away by the ocean and i had to save them yet again, while swinning and climing thinking that now im gona die.
But finaly i delived them and got my 1000usd for the job...  I was so happy and proud i did it, since it was really difficult.
Then i started to explore the rig and found some spare parts i could use for my future ship and other details such as a sling i could have used as an elevator for the inspectors  ( dooh )..
Anyway I continue and bought my self a small island with a container crane on it and i bought a medium size hull with a chair, wheel, and engine and propellar... so now i have a medium size ship that is much more stable for my next mission even though i could not afford to build a cocpit or anything on it.. but the foundation is there and it can be used and ih ave BIG hopes this will make my life more easy.

The ship building with blocks work really well, and you can even assign commands to buttons such as turn on engine, lower this, or move crane and such stuff. THat is cool and give you a kind of this is a real ship/plane/heli/boat you are operating.
You make things work by dragging lines inbetween blogs.. Example from battery to pushbutton to engine and then when you press the button the engine will start.
In the lastest update the game now also have gearboxes, and fluid systems so you even have to run pipes to/from your engine with water form the ocean to cool down, and fuel lines to the engine and excaust and air intake to make the engine work.
I think this is really cool and add so much more to the game since now you cant sail forever but need to example refule your helicopter or ship just like in real life.
You can even make a hollow sealed room and use it as example one big fuel tank, or as water ballast tanks in ships or submarines.
By the way the game come with an craetive mode and a careere mode that let you select what kind of gameplay you like.

In freeplay you have all parts avaliable from the start so you can build anything, and you can even select a simple or advanced construction options so example making the enigne work is more simple.
in career mode you have various difficultys and again options about if you want all parts avaliable and if you can die, injured and such things... if you die you just respawn in your base but typical loose your ship and it will cost you to spawn a new one. 
A cool think about the game is example helicopters that you can make hover above example a ship.. with the hoist system you can grap the sling and if you design the sling well you can while you are in the sling go up/down and even attack the end of the sling to a ship if it have a connector so the sling dont move away... example not so cool if your helicopter is in a hover and the ship are pushed away by the waves, then how you get up again ?  ;-)
In career mode you start out with xx amount of basic things but as you complete missions you get random new parts, or you can find the parts in the game world.
I think this work really great... ( but i hope they someday make a research tree so people can unlock the parts they like the most since it can be a bit tiring to do missions and not finding a specific part that you really want.

Other thing i like about the game is that the game world is a "seed" and random generated as far as i know. And the weather is changing all the time, and can really make things easy or even hard.
That is so cool... the waves on the ocean is very well done, and wind and physics well cool.
- let me give you an advice....: becourse you can sail, does not mean you have to sail.
with other words if there is a big storm with giant waves, then maybe it would be better to stay in the harbour than sailing, since you sometimes just have to give up fighting the waves and just ride off the storm just laying still with the stern into the waves and wait.

The game is in early access but it is pretty cool, and i have high hopes for it, and i can imagine having a rescue crew in multiplayer slining down my buddy to a ship with a helicopter and such.

I can today highly recommend the game, and its even cheap.
the game also today have more missions and variation than example 1 year ago, so there are more to do such as fighting fire, rescue submarines and transporting cargo and more passengers missions.

PS.. i forgot to say that the physics in the game is really good.. .Example your little boat is effected by the amount of people onboard and get tail heavy and such things... that is a nice detail.. and same goes with larger ships that carry heavy things, you need to think about the design and weight balanst tanks, fluids, electricty and such things ;-)

[h1]Intro[/h1]
Overall the game has a ton of potential, however, certain aspects still require extensive further development, in-particular, multiplayer which at this point is almost unplayable. The concept the game brings to life however is amazing, and as someone who does SAR in real life, having a game where you can custom build and edit your rescue equipment, and then perform rescues with said equipment is awesome.

[h1] Pro's & Cons[/h1]
[b]Cons[/b]
[i]As of writing this review these are the notable cons I have taken notice of, this review will hopefully be updated as the game improves.[/i]
[list]
    [*]Unplayable multiplayer: You will spend most of your time lagging and having FPS issues.
    [*]Sparse "rescue" events: Many of the events are delivering supplies and putting-out fires.
    [*]Optimization in general: Needs a ton of work, to run big and complicating builds you are going to need a beefy computer.
[*]Multiplayer can only be played with Steam friends, so no open servers, yet at least.
[/list]

[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
    [*]Amazing concept, which has a ton of potential.
    [*]Steam Workshop integration.
    [*]Weather is really cool and it is rather fun to operate boats in massive squalls and do missions.
[/list]

[h1] Verdict[/h1]
[b]A game that touches on an exciting neich and has tons of potential, but that is still very much in early-access.[/b]
Overall, I like the game and recommend it to anyone that once viewing a few YouTube "let's plays" of it thinks it would be awesome, because it is. However, it is essential to note that it is still [i]very[/i] much early-access, and as such there are bugs and optimization issues.

Short review here which I can add on to as I go. I've played this for around 90 hours at time of writing. Love every second of this game. Perfect mix of creativity and mission driven setting. Logic system is very simple and easy to connect things with a basic understanding of flow in fluid dynamics and PLC's (programming logic control). The physics are mostly good. I think they could use some work though. Gravity seems to be off a bit.

Things I'd like to see better worked:

Lighting system needs work. For example: I have a boat I built where there are exterior lights lining the hull, just below the water line. I made them blue. Flip lights on and the surrounding water glows blue...and so does the inside of my whole boat in all rooms. Seems to be light bleeding in through material which isn't right. These's also this static looking thing when you use search lights at night. Odd rendering going on there.

An option to use US system OR Metric system. Each cube is a quater meter. So four cubes is one meter. When you look up a boat you wanna build and it's 400' long...leaves some one having to do some math to figure out what that is in meters and quater meters (9.75" is one block). So better scaling would be cool.

The size limitation of dock I can understand if your dock is enclosed in a building; like the starting island. But when you buy an island and the dock is just one side and the rest is open to the ocean. Why should there be a size limitation for size of anything? I got one boat I want to build that's 610' long to scale. The longest one can build (and this involved me going to XML files and changing perameters around) was 255 blocks in one direction and then another 255 in another plus the block in middle so 511 blocks. This limitation, I understand, has something to do with programming (0-255). But having the ability to only build a boat thats 127.75 meters (415.1875 feet to be exact) doesn't cut it for the big boats we want to build.

I've noted my mouse skipping accross the screen as I pan over to click anything. Not sure what that's about. I don't think I've noticed it in other games I play. So I'm thinking its unique to Stormworks and should be looked at.

The basic color options are nice and will satisfy most applications. But the option to have a color wheel and pick any color would be awesome. Unless it's there and I've missed it this whole time...

Having different sized windows than 3x3 or 3x1 would be cool. Maybe implement a system where one could make, for example, a window size any size by using the grid system the same as the blocks do and the price goes up accordingly to how many blocks you've used to make say a 5x7 or a 6x11. Price per block size for window real esate used.

I keep seeing lots of comments about implemting weapons. I, myself, do not prefere weapons as there are so many shooters out there already. And I think adding weapons is just going to create and enviroment where people are getting shot all the time just because people want to be trigger happy and feel good about themselves...There are certian weapons mounted on some coast guard boats, I'm aware. But they have little impact to what this games ideas are. I saw some one elses comment about there aren't somali pirates so don't bother with weapons lol
The only thing I would suggest is to give an option for a mode for weapons. If someone wants to host a server with weapons on then good for them. But otherwise, I see no need for a weapons system. Not what the core game is about.

This one here is a big one I wanna see fixed. And that would the buoyancy calcs used. Yes, buoyancy is used to model a boat but it's also displacement of fluid. They go hand in hand. Having to have an enclosed system is silly to keep your boat floating. How would anyone build a ship for carrying logs?! (not that logs are in this game...idea maybe?) By these rules it would never work. You see my point...

This is another big one I wanna see fixed or at least modified. The current state for logic components is you push a toggle button. And that button is the sole providing eliment for providing power to a device. Last time I checked, buttons on their own don't provide self power. You need a power supply. I see there is a logic node for doing just that. It is a "power supply" That node, in perticular, is almost usless at the moment because buttons provide power on their own. But I think it would be more realistic and allow for better logic system control if say you could add an electric generator to be run off the engines when on and have batteries for when engines are off. Submarines use this very method. Some subs run off batteries for 1-3 weeks at a time. Same thing in a car. Turn key (or push button without clutch and/or brake) and it goes to accessories running off a battery. I thnk some bigger ships use diesel/electric combinations and trains, I know, use that. All that noise you here from a train is just diesel generators. Electric motors are doing all the pulling ....I'm pretty sure you catch what I'm saying here by now.

Maybe give an option for heavier and/or bigger weight blocks? Having to add 150 weight blocks to get the boat balenced correctly is a lot of work. From comment above this. Batteries are heavy and can be used as weights too.

Give a system for how much power is what and how much weight is what. Basic engine is 20,000...ok 20,00 what? Rampaging stallions in the stables? Cute babies, cow power, kilowatts? And the weight. Each block weighs 1...1 what?! Each weight block weighs 10...10...WHAT!!? See what I'm getting at? As someone who does engineering for a living. This drives me bonkers lol.

I'm sure there's more I can say and I will as I progress. Overall this game is so freaking awesome. I can't put it down. If you love designing, building and engineering. And then implementing your designs to perform this is the game for you.
