If you like physics driven construction, this game has something to offer you. 

You may enjoy multiplayer even if you don't like this element of games, but I am not in a position to comment as I really like construction games and haven't played multiplayer.

If you like KSP, FtD, or loved airship mods way back when you used to play minecraft, then this game is up your alley.

The ocean simulation has, not in appearance but in function, the best wave simulation I have ever seen in a game. The handling of vehicles is made simple by clear logic tools, linking control objects to systems is done visually and with the potential for incredible depth.

What sets this game apart from others in its category are the missions which offer a steady supply of problems to solve. This is what has kept my interest, I don't have to imagine the criteria of a problem, I simply need to think of efficient (or fun) solutions.

As a game in Early access it seems stable as of this writing and 28 hours of gameplay. No crashes, few bugs, few gripes. 

I payed full-price for this product, and I am glad I did. Worth every cent to someone like me.

After almost 40 housr of play in two days of ownership I'd like to give my review of the game:

Building is fun, what can I say... all building games are fun but what sets this game apart? What grabbed me and drew me in and does it still have that same hold? Well I was plenty of youtube videos as im sure many of you have as well... I decide ok I will invest.
Starting out isn't hard at all the missions are very basic but ramp up fairly quickly requiring you to design new or modify your existing craft to complete your next task, this is where thing cans get a little hairy for some. Unless you are very adept with logic programming the start will be slow. its fun but each thing you build will be extremely basic unless it becomes logic heavy for me at least thats a negative even though in many games im a logic god. I suffered a stin to my ego since there was no instruction on how to use a water pump or build a holding tank I failed the first fire mission.

I think having more parts that provide the same functions without the need for logic is the major snag for most players. I love logic and for the life of me or maybe im having a major brain fart I can't figure out how to make a rail hold its position ot water cannon because I dont know what part does it! Looking online just tells me about how logic functions but not about the corolated part in this game!

I quickly learned that without damage modeling and "in game" or "acvtive" block removal or editing, for me returning to port just to connect a wire for a door is horrible. So repair/remove/edit tools are needed for player interaction. The fact I can run aground and not damage my hull or sink isn't cool. I feel too much time was spent on each craft for each mission  yet very little to no payout in emotional reward. I'm not talking in game money or parts, i'm talking about the feeling of wanting to do it again because it was fun and not a task. I have to create my own situations and even then not being able to easily sink a ship without the use logic or open doors isnt cool... the fact we can't set a fire in some way either mistakenly or purposely yet have fire fighting mission is emersion breaking. After a while I felt like spending an hour or two on a ship just to hold w for 10 minutes pick up a passenger and drop them off isn't worth the effort.... spending 2+ hours designing and testing a working fire heli for a 5-10 compeltion time on a mission wasn't worth my time and the reward for my effert wasn't met with a sence of accomplishment and pride... just a "thats it!?!?" then I fast travele back to the islands because the bland defeningly windy noisy flights wasnt worth my time or effort and I had no reason to actually have to fly back home... emersion breaking/game breaking (ADD FUEL) and properly leve the audio having to turn my volume down each time I start a engine or hit high altitue is beyond annoying at this point.

Before I conclude my review here is a summary of what I'd love to see worked on and emplemented if possible:

1. I love the aspect of ship building and I love the aspect of using logic. I'd just like to see more expandible prefab logic setups for things like ballast control specific to vehicle type. I'd also like more control types that dont require the use of logic to function properly like connecting "wasd" to any control automatically recenters... by adding a checkbox to remove that function in the seletion menu of each part type like that can save alot of new non-logic friendly players a big headache and i'm sure increase player base.

2. More starter ships and aircraft types and hull shapes, from beginner to advanced. The workshop is a shortcut on your part guys... Yes a player can get more ships from there but Im talking about starter ships made by the devs tested for missions. Most ships on the workshop are too advance for starter missions and too logic heavy for new players. More things to help with beginner missions as well, like a basic fire boat or fire helicopter so users can see how to reverse engineer them in to better more advanced systems. Each in game boat or design should be available for users in the shipyard menus. This could be expanded on in story mode by haivng basic ship types spawn with the purchase of each new island. 

3. Include missions with AI interaction and assistance such as shipping and assembly of pre-fab structures requiring assembly, stopping and searching ships enroute and refueling. Sometimes it get very lonely on the seas.

4. ADD FUELS!!!!, NO MORE UNLIMITED FUEL!!!
Please add 3 types of fuels, Gasoline, Desil and Avation fuel and one extra liquid Oil. Engines should require a certain type of fuel depending on type of engine. Like water tanks use empty volumes for storage. You can have oil leaks and fuel contamination. Contaminated fuel/water mixed in storage tank will degrade performance until 75% fuel 25% water mix at that point engine will not function and make a weird noise to hint at the player something is wrong. All non water liquids should leave a slick on the water as long as a leak is happening the slick will vanish over time and stay only near the leaking area to indicate a leak if under water.

5. Ship oil for money from rigs to refineries, then buy fuel for your islands and have AI deliver or you can do it yourself! Designate liquid storage location for each island, have perfabe storage tank or build one AI will only pump liquid into labled tanks with propper connections that are accessible. create a shipping empire!

6. Basic AI crew! to help run certian function on larger ships, basicly something like a lua edditor in game we can program the crew to have certain tasks or even a selection menu we can assign tasks.

7. Wardrobes for boats more decor for our ships to hang on walls chairs other than belted ones players can fall from at high angles. Placeable items that will fall slide or break from falls at high angles rotation or enertia (fire hazzards blockage of espace routes).

8. A refilable fire extinguisher like SEROIUSLY

To conclude I see this game as a good investment I know this is early access so my review will reflect that with that said the negatives I do see as things that all can be polished out. I have been following develpoment for a few months and is very steady and updates are very good to spot on what was needed each time. I'd just like to see more things implemented that will gauge me for long periods other than the building aspect because once thats done... theres really nothing much more to do.

This is already a solid experience - I can't wait to see where the devs take it.

Something or all of that would certainly furfill the requests of many other people. although these have been said to be coming in a 'major update', many players wish it sooner due to it making the game make more sence, considering your a life guard.

A lot of fun so far!

The editor tool is highly intuitive and flexible.  I can see huge creative scope for building a massive variety of vehicles (boats, subs, planes, helis and anything your crazy imagination can come up with!).  However, the standout feature is the ocean itself, where the physics are awesome and likewise, the ability to create your own missions (for Steam Workshop).

Haven't tried out multiplayer yet, but I see that the game has a multiplayer career mode and can't wait to try it out with my friends.

This game is really promising and I think it could be a great game eventually.   However at the moment I didn't find it very fun, mostly because the stakes seem so low given that it is seemingly impossible for any harm to befall the player or any other character.  

Many missions ask you to rescue someone, but there's no timer or anything so if it takes you 10 days to respond to a distress call that's just fine.  You can strap injured characters to a stretcher for rescue, but you can also just "pick them up" and carry them with you, which causes them to vanish and doesn't slow you down or encumber you in any way. So a one-seater boat with no stretcher or other equipment is perfectly adequate for rescue missions and there's no reason to get any fancier except for your own edification.

Despite the vehicles being voxel-based they are not destructible, and there doesn't seem to be any damage mechanics at all at this stage.  I didn't play long enough to encounter the storm conditions depicted in some of the screenshots; the sea when I played was always quite calm, making travel straightforward but tedious.  The waypoints are so far away sometimes that you will spend a long time just holding the acceleration key and watching the remaining distance counter slowly tick down, which got old fast.

I finally gave up on this game and opted for a Steam refund when it logged in today to give the game another chance only to find my save file was missing, meaning I'd have to start over and repeat the tedious tutorial mission again.  This wouldn't be a dealbreaker if the gameplay itself was more enjoyable.

In summary, I think the premise of this game is very promising, but it doesn't have enough to make it fun just yet.  Personally I will be checking back in a few months and may consider re-purchasing at that time.

Stormworks is a sandbox building / rescue sim game that allows you to create pretty much anything mechanical like a plane, heli, boat, submarine etc. You're operating a coast guard like service on the cold and rough sea. Between windfarms, oil rigs and remote islands your task is to complete various missions. At this time the missions are limited, although There's a mission creator/editor, an evergrowing steam workshop and updates, adding new parts and contents.

You can build any kind of vehicle imaginable and use that to complete the task. With it's quite advanced logic system you can very easily set up any kind of electric or mechanical system you can imagine. From cranes, to sliding doors, to GPS autopilots and gyroscopes, you name it!

Stormworks is a sandbox game which allows you to create pretty much anything you can imagine. You're operating a coast guard like service on the cold and rough sea. Between windfarms, oil rigs and remote islands your task is to complete various missions. At the time of this posts, that's usually either transporting or rescuing personell, collecting and dropping off freight, aswell as towing ships and extinguishing fires. 

You can build any kind of vehicle imaginable and use that to complete the task. With it's quite advanced logic system (like redstone in Minecraft, but much better!) you can very easily set up any kind of electric or mechanical system you can imagine. From cranes, to sliding doors, to GPS autopilots and gyroscopes, you name it!

At the time of me writing this, there are only a limited number of missions, however there's a mission creator/editor, an evergrowing steam workshop and weekly updates, adding new parts and contents.

The most challenging aspect about the game is the dynamic weather and time. You can set off on a rescue mission with your newly built vessel in bright sunshine and nice weather, and quickly find yourself in complete darkness of the night, with strong gusts, fog and meter high waves. Nonetheless the gameplay is very captivating and fun. You should however bring alot of time, because building vehicles is absolutely captivating. I found myself spending hours building, tweaking and adapting my vessels, always finding something more to add. It's addictive fun. 

If I can predict anything for Stormworks, it's a very bright future and at this price, I can really recommend it to anyone, that likes purposeful sandboxes.

Kerbal Space Program meets Search and Rescue.

Brilliant idea, and an amazing game.

But it does have it's downsides. For one, multiplayer is only IP address. They're currently working with Steam matchmaking, no ETA yet. The controls are funky with a keyboard, almost impossible to fly a helicopter. Game needs controller support.

Another downside are the missions and possible ideas that haven't been implemented. Just imagine the ideas people can come up with. For one, it would be amazing if you can put an inflatable raft in an airplane, launch/drop it from the air into the water. If it's nearby, the AI can get on the raft so that the helicopter rescuer can get to the people easier and faster. THAT or once you lower the harness in the water, the AI swims to it and grabs onto it. So that you can have a faster extraction.

----

[b]Pros:[/b]
- Tutorial
- Multiplayer
- Graphics
- Dynamic weather
- Steam Workshop support

[b]Middle:[/b]
- Hoping that multiplayer can get expanded from 3 players to maybe like 8 - 10. Where a crew an manage a vessel, airplane, helicopter and maybe even the tower/ground crew, etc. RP players would love this.
- More in-depth and crazy missions?
[olist]
   [*]Contraband or refugee missions where you need a boat. 
   [*]Cruise ship rescues where you have to find a spot on the cruise ship to winch to. 
   [*]Possible to have scuba gear where the person(s) gets trapped underwater and you need to go underwater and rescue them.
[/olist]

Things that the Coast Guard goes through.

- Maybe let people create maps? Would be pretty cool to see what the community can make and use them.
- We need Human-like AI.

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Limited missions at the moment.
- You need at least 2 or 3 people if you'd like to fly the helicopter. One to fly, one to winch and other to rescue the people in the water or vessel/building.
- Xbox One controller isn't supported. A game like this needs it for flying.
- Flying without a HOTAS controller is horrible.

----

Need people to play with? I suggest once you launch the game, click on the 'Discord' icon and join the Official 'Stormworks: Build and Rescue' Discord server.

Looking for cool Steam Workshop add-ons to use? Check out my [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1386630603] collection.[/url]

On the new big island in the port area you could make a active port where people could do cargo missions. You could put next to airport a active town where npc are moving around. I hope in the future of this game some of these things will become a reality.

Easily the most impressed I've been with an Early Access purchase in some time.

[h1]Positives[/h1]
[list]
[*]Solid core game loop. Build craft [i]with a purpose[/i]. Think space engineers with besieged and a little KSP thrown in.
[*]Logical and easy to learn construction and logic systems, balancing depth with ease of use.
[*]Fast itteration and updates so far.
[*]Workshop support
[*]Great performance on a high end machine. Game appears to scale very well, even large vessels run fine.
[/list]
[h1]Negatives[/h1]
[list]
[*]Non-randomized  and non-replayable missions. Currently only ~20 missions are available, and they don't continue to rotate. You can download more from workshop. Even if there is only 20 missions in the game would be great if they continued rotating after you complete them.
[*]Progression and Balance issues. Career games can be hard to progress and quite buggy, as the missions stop and you might not have unlocked what you need to progress on the way. Likely a temporary issue and fixed in subsequent updates.
[*]Hard to Fail. Probably my biggest issue other than non-randomized and non-replayable missions: no crash damage, no death, penalty for failure, or time limits. I suspect this is likely something to come in future.
[/list]
[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

An addictive and excellent experience showing great promise, but already plenty of fun to be found.

i want to like this game but i cant recommend it. let me explain;

so ok the editors good, i do like the construction on this game its very nice. i also like the way anything you build gets used in the missions  but theres the problem. the big issue i have with the game is the lack of information of what you need for a mission, for example if you need a boat or a helicopter. simple things like tools being listed would help like winches etc. theres nothng worse than driving a boat 3km across the sea to find you need a winch or the thing your picking up is in the middle of an island and you need a heli to pick it up.

i also found myself feeling rather under tooled for some of the early missions that popped up at the start of the game. a good example of this was a mission that came up asking me to drop a drone off at a location. when i got to the drone it felt like the mission required something more like a helicopter to move it even though the game had give me nothing like this yet in parts to make a helicopter, hell i only just started. the best i had was a plane prop.

i like the idea this game has, craft your own rescue vehicles use them in missions but i wish the missions themselves were less vague. the crafting part seems solid but i think there needs to be more of a tutorial for the aircraft side of this and the missions certainly need more description and information added into them. its almost there, but not knowing what missions required just got too frustraiting for me sorry. also maybe order the missions better so parts drop better compaired to the order the missions require you to use those parts; winches, heli blades etc etc.

i will keep playing though, i could change my mind. if im doing something wrong or missing something let me know

It's like Kerbal Space Program, but you have even more freedom to build your vehicles in whatever way you want. You can build boats, submarines, planes, helicopters, vtols, cars, trucks... anything you want. There is a very large amount of different parts and blocks that you can build your vehicles out of; such as several robotic servos and pistons which you can use to build cranes, cargo bays, rotating propellers, robotic arms, etc...

Every vehicle has a logic system which allows you to use some low-level programing in order to fine tune every aspect of your craft's behavior, meaning that you can do anything from making a boat that intelligently uses it's robotic propellers for self-stabilization to a submarine that can engage in cruise control mode and automatically hold it's heading and speed or even an helicopter that essentially flies itself without you needing to input more than one or two commands for the whole trip.

Vehicles can also be docked with one another, winched by one another, airlifted by one another, stored inside one another, etc... The possibilities are only limited by your creativity, it's really fun stuff.

Even though it the game is still in alpha stage it is already a very fun experience and absolutely worth it's current price tag. The developers are also constantly releasing new updates which means it will tend to get even better in the future.

At the moment I can not recommend this for one single reason: Travel time.

At the moment to get anywere with a regular (speed) boat takes [b]way[/b] to long. You just press forward for 10 minutes do a bit of course correction and that's how you get to another island. Considering that the career mode has quests were you transport things makes this game bogged down with the most boring fetch quests I've ever seen. The only way I can currently play the game is by weighting the W button down with coins and playing boring mobile games while course correcting every minute.

On a more positive note: The game has a great building system and nice physics. It offers plenty of design freedom. Therefore this game has great potential in it's career mode and creative mode is already very usable. If you can enjoy your self by creating vehicles without any real goal to it then this game is already a great buy, if not, wait.


TL;DR:
Buy for creative mode if that's your thing,
Do not buy for carreer mode because travel time is stupid long.

One thing about this game is that you will spend most of your time in Editor building ship, heli, cars and other stuff. I've yet to scratch the surface after spending many hours in this game.

The game generated missions which you can perform and it will give you money, parts and blueprint unlock. But it is not compulsary to complete them. You can play at your own pace. The blueprint unlock did not just come from the mission but you also can unlock them by going around collecting crate with star symbol on it. And  you have enough money to build stuff.

Just the starting items and fund will keep you engrossed trying to build that uber boat which will not just carry passengers and cargo but also able to survive an open sea big wave. You will encounter big wave if you move 3km away from the islands. Then you started to see your puny little boat doing flipping and sommersault which is deem only possible on a skateboard not a boat.

IMHO, this game is good value for its price. The heli control and the control as a whole can use some additional improvement. In case of heli, you can only use the keyboard to fly it and controller support is limited. You cannot use mouse to control the pitch and roll like other helicopter game.

I have played enough of Stormworks to write a review now.

TLDR: Very early access, great fun singleplayer, No working coop at the moment, buy if you want to support development.

The game is great fun and does pretty much what you would expect. I am yet to really see any kind of a "storm" maybe I am not that far into the game or maybe it is not implemented in yet. The game is very clearly early access and the Devs do a very good job of telling you EVERYWHERE that you should expect bugs. Overall though the game is a HUGE amount of fun and designing your vehicles to do basic life guard missions at the moment keeps you entertained.

One of the things that pulled me into the early access was the option to play Coop online. I will cut this short and say you can't. I really mean you can't at all at the moment. Sure you can try but trust me it is just not worth it. Remeber though this is a VERY early build and I was not expecting a lot out of the multiplayer.

So for now I am going to let this one rest in my library as I want to support the devs and not ask for a refund. They seem to know what they are doing so far and don't seem like the kind to abandon a game. Keep up the great work.
